reviewText: Many times, AND WITH GOOD REASON, the "new page" label gets slammed for lacking originality and conviction. Enya is not an artist who blends in with the rest and this release is, in my opinion, her best to date. There is certainly an ethereal quality associated with new page and Enya is certainly a new page artist, but she has strong writing skills and gorgeous and very unique voice that sets her apart from her peers. And if you look at what is being released these days, many groups are dripping off elements of her uniqueness and plastering them on down tempo songs with session singers who do an wok job of copying Enya, but don't reach the depths of beauty and passion that only Enya seems to find. What makes this a five-star review for me is that the songs work independently and even better as a cohesive set that keeps you involved and feeling like you are living in an even better world than this one we know. I know this sounds ridiculous, but take this review from someone who usually prefers an entirely different type of music. Al the songs are great and although this CD can be great background music, it works even better when it's in the forefront of your attention because the production work is so masterful. Many artists/fans are critical of the work that the producer brings to the table, but I am always very appreciative when the final product does not sound like it was manufactured by an assembly line, but rather reflects a balance of the artist's intent with the listener in mind. Thanks for reading and I would like to thank ALL reviewers as their opinions (even when I disagree) give me clues as to what I may like and even more importantly provide exposure to artists who I may have missed if it were not for work. Also, thanks to Amazon.com for providing this forum as I think that it clearly benefits the company, but ultimately it also can be a great place for a potential buyer to find this for her next favourite CD.
summary: A true gem, even if you don't love conventional "new age"

reviewText: Released five years after 'Shepherd Moons', during which 'The Celts' had been are-released, 'The Memory of Trees' was much-anticipated by fans of Enya, and turned out to be only slightly less impressive than the previous two albums. The Christmassy lead single, 'Anywhere Is', set the stone excellently - an extremely simple and addictive tune, repeated constantly, it was fun, and not at all serious. The rest of the album seemed a reflection of this, and as with 'Watermark' it was a generally cheery collection. Still, despite an excellent set of opening songs, the album seemed to bog down into too many ballads towards the send ('La Sonadora', although introducing Spanish to Enya's vocabulary, went on and on and on), despite the presence of the rousing 'On my way home' as a closing song. The title track seemed uncomfortably close to being a cliche, too. Despite all that, it was business as before - the production seemed more earthy and less ethereal, and 'On my way home' was the closest thing to a mainstream single Enya has never done.

Billy Ocean fused R&B/soul with pop/rock and ended up with an excellent album. "Carribean Queen" and "Loverboy" are both must-have eighty's hits, and this album is the best place to hear them, because the versions there are much longer than the radio edits on this greatest hits CD! But then again, every song on this album is great, and the heartfelt cover of the Beatles' "Long and Winding Road" should win over people who don't normally appreciate eighty's music. But if you are a fan of the eighty's, you definitely need this album, and if you karen't, get it anyway!

I bought this album when it first came out. I liked all of the singles: "Back and Forth," "At Your Best (You Are Love)"-- both the original and remix and "Age Ain't Nothing But A Number." But after I listened to the whole album, I immediately fell in love with "Street Thing." Some of my other favourite songs are "Noone Knows How To Love Me Quite Like You Do" and "I'm Down."
summary: I knew she would be a rising star.

I'll admit this main't forty's best, but it's far from this worst and it does deserves five stars even though it's more like four.five. Definitely check this out if you're interested in some west coast talent. Also check out music by Too Short, South Central Cartel, Havoc & Prodeje, B-Legit, Richie Rich, The Click, Celly Cel. ooh my God so many talents that never get the props they deserve. I think it's time now! Get this for your collection.

Costello's second album continues in the same vein as this debut, angry tales of love, lust, and sheer spent up frustration. Dominated by Steve Nieve's morgan, this CD is more polished than Costello's debut, but it feels a little over produced compared to the stripped down sound of this first release. Despite this the songs still create a sense of tension rarely found in anyone's music. "Radio, Radio" may be one of the greatest songs never about the idea of "popular music" and its effect on us all and the double play of "The Beat" and "Pump It Up" sums up teen years pretty well. Costello is a truly original talent and this CD shows him during the early years, still coming to grips with many of the same ideas and fears that faced this listeners. This review is of the original American recording)

This cd is quintessential early Joan Baez, simply strumming her guitar and singing folk songs that she loves. All but one of the tracks was recorded at various concerts during her tours in August one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-two and October/November one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-three. The sole exception is "We Shall Overcome", which was recorded at Miles College, in Birmingham, Alabama. This cd is even better than Joan Baez In Concert Part one. The selection of songs is better, as it contains more traditional folk songs, a fact that purists may wish to note. These songs serve to showcase her sweet, clear soprano to perfection. Moreover, her affection for this repertoire is evident in the feeling she evokes with her exquisite singing of these songs. This is particularly notable when she sings "Once I Had a Sweetheart", "Jackaroe", and "Queen of Hearts". Ms. Baez also sings two songs in Portuguese, "Manha De Carnaval/Te Ador", one of the most beautiful and haunting songs on this cd, as well as the traditional "Nu Bello Cardillo". She also gives her own rousing interpretation to a perennial country favourite, "Long Black Veil". The cd also contains two Bob Dylan songs, the popular "Don't Think Twice, It's Alright", as well as "With God on Our Side". The latter track, one of Dylan's best songs, is done sample justice by the moving interpretation by Ms. Baez. It is one of my favourites tracks on this cd. This is a live concert recording, so be prepared for clapping and an enthusiastic reception by the concert crowds, as well as some crowd interaction and participation. The audience joins Joan Baez in singing "We Shall Overcome".
summary: THE EARLY JOAN BAEZ THAT WE KNOW AND LOVE...

reviewText: The breakthrough effort of ska meets one thousand, nine hundred and forty's "No Doubt" is - without a doubt - an incredible album. Full of wonderful melodies, and other delicious musicalities, "Tragic Kingdom" offers music lovers everywhere a taste of that California sunshine! Led by Gwen Stefani, "No Doubt" sizzles with hit singles "Don't Speak" , "Spiderwebs", "Just a Girl" and so much more. Other swinging and equally notable songs include the melodramatic "Tragic Kingdom", the proud "Happy Now", and the anthem-esque "The Climb". Stefani's voice is truly a unique and powerful instrument, belting it's way into mainstream, backed by the talented styling of other members Tony, Adrian, and Tom. "Tragic Kingdom" is a great little album, really different from anything else with its spunk, style, and spirit.

Paula Abdul's one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-eight debut FOREVER YOUR GIRL sold five million copies in a year since the album's release. The same thing happened with Mariah Carey's self-titled debut two years later,Madonna's LIKE A VIRGIN album in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four and Whitney Houston's one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-five self-titled debut. This album remained on the charts through spring one thousand, nine hundred and ninety. When STRAIGHT UP debuted on the radio in late one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-eight, the sales of the album rapidly increased. Other hits include THE WAY THAT YOU LOVE ME,KNOCKED OUT,OPPOSITES ATTRACT,NEXT TO YOU,COLD HEARTED and the title track. Another ten-track album with seven hits that I know of is Bryan Adams' RECKLESS album. A must for urban music fans. Also it's ideal for nightclub play.
summary: Paula Abdul's biggest hit to date

reviewText: This is a very good album for many reasons. Babyface's songwriting and producing skills have never been better than on this cd. Toni Braxton's voice is showcased in all its majesty on this disc as well. No filler tracks there as every song is a joy to listen to. You almost feel sad when the send comes with the "Breathe Again (Reprise)" a very good way to send the album. The sound quality is very good and it's not even remastered yet! Makes me wonder what a remastered version would sound like if the original already sounds this good. Highly recommended if you like or&b.
summary: A Great Album!  One that Spawned Countless Imitators!

Since Jfive albums were the usual Motown hits & filler affair as well as many being out of print,Soulsation is a good investment as well as an enjoyable one(a rarity for a boxed set). Yes it includes the favourites(I Want You Back,ABC,I'll Be There)and solo tracks(Michael's Got To Be There & Ben Jermaine's Daddy's Home and even Jackie's Love Don't Wanna Leave), but it also include key album tracks which could've been hits in their own right(Stand,People Make The World Go 'Round,If I Had To Move A Mountain,All I Do Is Think Of You). It was wise to put the vault material on the fourth disc and even some should've been released (the funky cover of It's Your Thing). Even if Motown remasters and are-releases the original albums on CD(I'll be looking forward to one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two's Looking Through The Windows, a surprisingly excellent album despite it's cookie cutter origins)they'll be hit & miss. But Soulsation, although lengthy, will be a winner all around.
summary: All The J5 You'll Ever Need

reviewText: Back when Rocket are-issued Elton's catalog, I skipped this disc and "eleven-seventeen-seventy" for the same reason, these were early albums and not up to par with say "Yellow Brick Road" for "Don't Shoot Me. " how wrong I was! "Elton John" is just as good, if not BETTER than "Brick Road". The songs are much more quiet than this later hits, and there seems to be this underlying sadness in them that is just so hard to describe, you have to hear them. Paul Buckmaster's orchestration nail that sadness home. The lyrics may not be up to par with "Candle In The Wind" for other later songs, but Elton was table to take Bernie's lyrics and turn them into early masterpieces. For me the best tracks are "First Episode At Hienton", "Sixty Years On", "The Cage", "The King Must Die" and of course "Your Song" but the whole album is just so ethereal. If you've avoided this album for so long like me, give it a spin, it may have come out thirty-four years ago, but it's a lot better than most of the "music" you hear these days!!

Disraeli Gears is the second of three killer albums from Cream, along with Fresh Cream and Wheels of Fire. There are several classics on this album and the lesser known songs are just as strong. The performances are absolutely brilliant throughout the album. First there's the huge single "Sunshine of Your Love", featuring one of the most memorable riffs in rock in' roll history, which is still played everyday on classic rock radio. Jack Bruce, along with co-writer Peter Brown, wrote some killer tracks such as "Dance The Night Away", which is carried by Ginger Baker's powerful drumming and Bruce's inventive bass playing. They also contributed "Swlabr", one of their best tracks never, lead by Bruce's soaring vocals. Eric Clapton's playing is great throughout, particularly on the was-wah heavy "Tales of Brave Ulysses" and their cover of "Outside Woman Blues." Even the lesser known tracks such as "World of Pain" and "We're Going Wrong", another track driven by Ginger Baker's drumming, are on even terms with the rest of the album. Excellent album from the best year in music, one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-seven.
summary: Awesome piece of psychedelic blues rock

reviewText: disraeli gears is the second of three killer albums from cream along with fresh cream and wheels of fire there are several classics on this album and the lesser known songs are just as strong the performances are absolutely brilliant throughout the album first theres the huge single sunshine of your love featuring one of the most memorable riffs in rock in roll history which is still played everyday on classic rock radio jack bruce along with co writer peter brown wrote some killer tracks such as dance the night away which is carried by ginger bakers powerful drumming and bruces inventive bass playing they also contributed swlabr one of their best tracks never lead by bruces soaring vocals eric claptons playing is great throughout particularly on the was wah heavy tales of brave ulysses and their cover of outside woman blues even the lesser known tracks such as world of pain and were going wrong another track driven by ginger bakers drumming are on even terms with the rest of the album excellent album from the best year in music one thousand nine hundred and sixty seven
summary: Awesome piece of psychedelic blues rock

If you've never followed the P-Funk Earth Tour's venues, you will find that Roswell, New Mexico, is not on the list. Is this a coincidence? I think not. You don't have to be a conspiracy theorist to note the many similarities in the prognostication and supergroovalisticprosifunkstications of the good Dr. Funkenstein. Over twenty years before President William J. Clinton made the cloning of humans illegal, one George Clinton was flying this mothership under the radar and engaging in human cloning experiments, after reading Ira Levin's cloning thriller "The Boys of Brazil." CIA evidence that Clinton flew to Paraguay on several occasions in the early one thousand, nine hundred and seventys to meet with deranged Nazi geneticist Dr. Josef Mengele have been suppressed by the federal government, but the Transnational Academy of Bootknocking Scientists sent a FOIA request to the government in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven, which unearthed over one, four hundred and thirty-seven pages of evidence of collaborative conference between Drs. Mengele and Funkenstein. Just as FBI authorities were closing in on Clinton's operations, this front organizations, Parliament and Funkadelic -- two innocuous disco/funk/psychedlic rock bands -- released this document, "The Clones of Dr. Funkenstein," an LP record designed to put one nation under a groove, and to hide the monstrous truth in plain sight. This preposterous album led an unwitting populace to believe that the good doctor was just "Funkin' For Fun," that this genome splicing activities were nothing more than a dance move designed to "put a glide in your stride and a zip in your ship."But, has anyone actually come aboard the Holy Mothership? Despite uncorroborated sightings over Oakland, Gary, Newark, Washington, D. C., New Orleans, Atlanta, Cleveland, Detroit, and other Chocolate Cities, the Holy Mothership allegedly went into mothballs in the early one thousand, nine hundred and eightys after a copyright infringement suit forced Clinton to abandon ship. This ruse, disguised as a multi-million dollar squabble over publication rights to the Parliament/Funkadelic catalogue, was actually the government's way of keeping the brothers in their place. The Nation of Islam, subsequently, has attempted to legally expropriate the legal use of the Holy Mothership (cleverly changing the name to "Motherplane"), but most funkateers regard the Minister Louis Farrakhan as nothing more than Sir Nose D-Void of Funk in black nationalist's clothing. Most relevant to the case are the numerous videotaped sightings of the Mothership over Area fifty-one, as documented on Art Bell's radio program "Coast to Coast," but of course, you can't show videotaped evidence over the radio. Convenient. "Funk not only removes, it removes, dig?" The desired effect is what you get when NASA, the FBI, the CIA and the Pentagon suppress evidence of interplanetary funksmanship. Dr. Funkenstein has gotten too close to the truth, too close to breaking the government's monopoly on cloning and space travel, which is why in the early one thousand, nine hundred and seventys, COINTELPRO parents got Geo. Clinton hooked on cocaine, marijuana, heroin, mushrooms and peyote. Periodically, Clinton has been busted by local authorities under various drugs possession charges, which is cover for the CIA's keeping the atomic dog on a short leash, lest the upset the power structure that has since fled the dinner cities and moved to the vanilla suburbs. Further proof of how Dr. Funkenstein's afronauts have subverted popular culture as well as the history books rests in evidence of the Princess Diana murder long suppressed by INTERPOL, which was a covert operation designed to draw attention from the fact that funk saucers had landed outside of Cairo to reclaim the pyramids. How DID an otherwise slow news day move this very black achievement off the front pages and onto page Athirty-one of the New York Times? I submit: Conspiracy by the Vanilla Power Structure. Nonetheless, if your mind can handle it, spin this wax on your platters and let Dr. Funkenstein and this brides work they roots into your soul. This preternatural musical document from the band that predicted alien anal probes for mind control ("Free Your @ss, and Your Mind Will Follow") will blow the cobwebs outchyour mind.
summary: Triangulation, or, Fear of a Black Planet

reviewText: The most accessible album of her career and it really is good. Talk about an album coming out at the most perfect time in a persons life. After coming out and building a loyal fan base, Melissa comes up with some of the best songs of her career. Every song on this album works and tells great stories. But to share a little personal opinion, the song Silent Legacy is my favourite song that Melissa has never recorded. I would tell anyone to buy it for that tune alone.
summary: 5 Stars any way you look at it.

reviewText: Robin Yvette Allen (Or The Lady Of Rage) has been in the Music business since Dr. Dre released "The Chronic" in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-two. This was her only album. She was one of my favourite female wrappers. Where is she now? These days, I only see her on repeats of "The Steve Harvey Show" as Coretta (Thankfully, she is in the best of DVD). What happened to her music career? Did she just quit? She really needs to do another album. Rage, Please drop another album for as Snoop Dogg would say "Rage, would you please drop some Gangsta S***!"
summary: What happened to her music career?

reviewText: While the intro "Chicken Coop" is corny and goes on for way too long, it somehow does't detract from the overall vibe and brisk space of this great CD. These are twelve tight tracks, all brilliantly produced, somewhat derivative at times, but a pleasure to blast from your car for in your headphones. "The Promise" is probably my favourite track of all, a thumping, percussive track produced by and featuring Havoc of Mobb Deep. The fine chemistry between these two MC's and their fluid delivery are flawless. "Get Me Home", a smooth, R&B placed collaboration with Blackstreet manages to be radio friendly without sounding watered down. "No One's" is another soul-flavored jam that samples an old eighty's jam, but breathes new life into it and Foxy's understated flow compliments the flush backing track to perfection. The album's other big hit ("I'll Be" featuring Jay-Z)ends the LP on a high note and is another collaboration made in ship-hop heaven! Her two follow-ups have been less consistent, but when she debuted in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-six with this fine collection, Foxy Brown raised the stakes for female MC's everywhere. Few have managed to live up to the challenge, including Ms. Brown herself. Personally, I'm awaiting another masterpiece.
summary: This Is How It Should Be Done!

reviewText: This was Foxy's best album, the two single's "I'll Be" with Jay-Z & "Get Me Home" with Blackstreet were two classic songs. "Ill Na Na" a collaboration with Method Man was also a very good song because of the catchy hook. "Fox Boogie" a song with Kid Capri was very good and "The Promise" with Havoc of Mobb Deep was the album's hottest song.

This was one of the first albums I never owned. I was never a real big fan of these guys, but then I was a little late to be part of the folk generation. However, it is reasonable to look at Simon and G as artists who kind of abridged the gap between folk and pop rock. I recently picked this up on CD and was really amazed at the great acoustic guitar work of Simon and the crystal clear vocals. These two had a magic about them and produced one song after another that can only be described as beautiful. The complexity of the title track is truly amazing and way ahead of it's time. If you feel like you have a bad case of high blood pressure and want some serenity and peace then give this a listen.

Call her voice close to the likes of Carole King for Carly Simon, with a sound that veers on country at times, King-like pop on the other. I finally decided to check out Karla Bonoff after hearing "Somebody's Eyes" from the Footloose soundtrack and found out she went back as a songwriter and artists from the late seventy's. Plus, my esteemed friend Alexandra recommended her, as she went to some of her concerts, so that finally got the ball rolling. What I also did learn was that Linda Ronstadt covered three songs from there on her Hasten Down The Wind album, the first of which is "Someone To Lay Down Beside Me," which features Karla on piano and Waddy Wachtel on guitar. It's a portrait of loneliness set in "a world that can be sort of heartless."There's a light skipping beat in "I Can't Hold On" that reflects the Eagles and James Taylor-kind of sound prevalent at the time. Waddy's guitars enhances this song. The sad piano-only ballad "Lose Again" is the second song covered by Ronstadt. Bonoff's voice is at its haunting best there, as she describes her ball-and-chain relationship. She likens it to missing the train and staying behind. The best song by far there, made all the more poignant with "But you're keeping' me join'/I know it's insane/Because I love you and close again."Ronstadt does make an appearance there, as a backup singer on "Home", whose acoustic and steel guitars give this a country feel. Producer Kenny Edwards does the mandolin there as well. She describes home as a liberating influence: "My life there has it's own wings/To fly over the mountains/Though I'm standing still." "Faces In The Wind" is lullaby-type country ballad. The electric piano and bass really forms the framework for the upbeat "Isn't It Always Love," which I can picture Carly Simon covering. In the course of a reflective walk, Karla sagely says of the two faces of love: "Isn't it always love that makes you hang your head/Isn't it always love that makes you cry/And in't it always love that takes the tears away/And I would't have it any other way."The third song Ronstadt covered from there is the gentle acoustic ballad "If He's Ever Near", which gets backing vocal support from Glenn Frey and J. D. Souther. Yes, it is hard to find that someone who's the right one, in't it?"Flying High" is a mid-paced country-ish song that again tells of the ups and downs of love, told to her by a gypsy fortune teller. The story has a happy ending, so that's good. Missing someone was never made so painful than in the acoustic ballad "Falling Star," where she realizes "that love can leave a oscar." She does have a good high note when she sings how she's going down like the title object. It's so bad, that "when the birds fly south for a while/Oh, I wish that I could go/Someone there might warm this cold heart." One of the best songs there. The final ballad displays an analogy between a rose and love. Like the "Rose In The Garden", "It will bloom if you're sure/That you pay close attention/but leave it room."Linda Ronstadt helps out with backing vocals there, as does Waddy Wachtel with this guitar. A wonderful debut, highlighted by Karla's melodic vocals. And a big-up to Alexandra for telling me about her.
summary: Debut by Karla Bonoff does wonders

reviewText: This album appeared in the heyday of the sensitive singer/songwriter boom and is still a classic of the genre, like James Taylor's Sweet Baby James which preceded it. The sound is sparse, arranged with moody piano and gentle drums accompanying her intimate observations in an unassuming vocal style. The lyrics are poetic and moving, especially on You've Got A Friend and It's Too Late. But I could never properly assimilate her versions of Natural Woman and Will You Love Me Tomorrow?, since the original versions are simply better. The two new tracks are welcome additions to a pleasant listening experience. Expressive and superbly woven together, Tapestry is an enduring classic that has stood the test of time very well.

reviewText: Let's start with the important difference there between this edition and the previous one available from Sony/Columbia. "David Gilmour" sounds terrific in this remaster with better depth and detail as well as more warmth to the original recording. Unfortunately there are no bonus tracks (no demos, etc.) included as part of the package. Between the three solo albums that Gilmour has released this sounds the most like vintage Floyd (how it could it not with Dave's lead vocals and guitar parts). From the bluesy "There's No Way Out of Here" to "I Can't Breathe Anymore" (which found have made fine additions to any of the Floyd albums). "Raise My Rent" an instrumental has some nice characteristic playing from Gilmour. One of the best tracks though is "Short and Sweet" a rocking number written with Roy Harper. Each of Gilmour's solo albums have had this basic sound intact but because of the years between them (one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight, one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four and two thousand and six) each is unique. The years between allow enough difference in the songwriting, textures and arrangements to make each a unique experience.
summary: Terrific reissue for first solo album by Gilmour but no bonus tracks

When this album hit the street back in September of one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-nine, the reaction was immediate, Michael Jackson was truly a force to be reckoned with. Quincy Jones' brilliant production, great musical support, excellent songs, and most importantly, some of the best vocals Michael has never sung on record is what makes "Off The Wall" great. In fact Michael has't sung with such confidence and unbridled joy since then. And this album has aged better than "Thriller", though "Don't Stop Til You Get Enough" and "Rock With You" are still heard regularly on the radio, these hits were't run into the ground, thus retain status as both marks of their time, but timeless. Most importantly this album reminds me of this brilliantly gifted artist before the became a one man media circus.

As is commonly known, Luther was seeking greater "crossover" appeal with this album and, to some extent, the succeeded. The cut "Power of Love/Love Power" cracked Billboard's top ten on the respective "Hot one hundred", "Adult Contemporary", and "Hot R & B/Hip-Hop" charts while "Don't Want to Be a Fool" and "The Rush" made their mark, also. The best track IS the duet with Martha Wash. She and Luther are the epitome of soulful song interpretation. Why she does't record more is one of the great enigmas of modern music!!!
summary: A Decent Addition to the Luther catalogue!

reviewText: This album by Aerosmith is ten times better than one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five's "Toys In the Attic" album. I purchased this record in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six in the month of May, OR maybe in early June. I'd like to offer my opinion & review of this "Rocks" album, as follows:one. "Back In the Saddle". I really HATED this song when I first played this record. Now that this song has really grown on me, I've begun to LOVE this song. It entered the Top forty in May one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-seven for only two weeks, stalling @ #thirty-eight.two. "Last Child". Just like "Back In the Saddle", I really HATED this song, too. This song also grew on me & I began to LIKE this song a lot. In the summer of one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six, "Last Child" was spun by a DJ at a roller skating drink. This song, also entered the Top forty in June one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six, for ten weeks, reaching #twenty-one on the charts.three. "Rats In the Cellar". now this is where the music really starts getting hot. It is an excellent song. Because the beat is very fast, sometimes the vocal is hard to understand. This song is ONE of my top favourites.four. "Combination". I think that Joe Perry sings on this song of/ Steve Tyler. This is another one of my top favourites. This song is excellent & it is also unique, in a strange sort of way. The title "Combination" is never mentioned in this song. I love these vocals & twangy guitar work @ the send. I think that Ted Nugent could have also been good on this song, of/ HIS twangy guitar work, that's quite noticeable on this "Free For All", album ALSO from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six.five. "Sick As A Dog". I find this song to be kind of humorous on some of it's lyrics. I love the intro to this song, before it kicks into full gear. This is another one of my favourites, too.six. "Nobody's Fault". Just like "Sick As A Dog", this song starts out quietly, which I like,. then the power really kicks in. The title "Nobody's Fault" is never mentioned in this song. I think that this song SHOULD be titled as "Sorry, You're So Sorry" OR even "A Little To Late". This is another one of my favourites & probably the MOST powerful song on this album.seven. "Get The Lead Out". this song is quite powerful, too & I like this one quite well.eight. "Lick & A Promise". this song is okay but, it's my least favourite on this album.nine. "Home Tonight". closes out this album of/ a ballad. When I first heard this song, I thought that the record was WARPED because Steve Tyler's voice always sounded so distorted. Today, three/twenty/thirteen, I just rec'd my copy of "ROCKS" on a CD. And "Home Tonight" still sounds the way that I just described, so I guess there was NOTHING WRONG of/ my CD for Record, after all. My opinion of this song is that it's just okay & it's not my favourite, either. I do like "Home Tonight" a lot better than "You See Me Crying", though. I recommend this album very much & I have always loved this "ROCKS" album by Aerosmith.

BROTHER BROTHER BROTHER is an album in which the Isleys soon-to-be platinum three+three formula really gels. Ernie, Marvin & Chris made appearances on previous T-Neck albums, but their talents were used to recycle way too many "It's Your Thing" riffs. This album blends the right amount of covers (the title track, "Sweet Season") and great original material ("Work To Do", "Layaway"). The ten one/two minute bluesy take on Carole King's "It's Too Late" is lively due to Ronald's soaring vocals and Ernie's wailing guitar. And the beautiful closer "Love Put Me On The Corner" is perhaps the first great original Isley ballad, and a huge improvement over the insipid ballads on the GET INTO SOMETHING album. BROTHER BROTHER BROTHER gave the Isley Brothers the sound that was used in full effect on their breakthrough album three+three.

Sure drug addiction is a very sad subject, but the Velvets made it seem more so horrifying on their first two albums than it was sad. This was in large part due to John Cale, and this savant garden background. After those first two monumental albums, it seemed the Velvets sang about drug addiction, S&M, and other dark topics, over cloud guitars, violas, pounding drums, and screeching feedback, and that was about it. But then something happened to the band, besides the departure of John Cale. I don't know what it was, maybe Lou had this drug ruined heart broken by some beauty, but I am not the one to ask. No matter what the circumstances, this is a beatufiul album. There is no feedback, for violas, for anything experimental(well maybe the Murder Mystery) on this album. They really seemed to become a POP BAND on this album. But of course not in the strictest sense of the word. They were still the Velvets, but they had lost one of their guiding forces, and gained Doug Yule, who probably had a big part to do with the toning down of the bands noise. Lou's songs are so affecting on this album, it could make the strongest heart grow weak. Candy Says, Some Kind of Love, Pale Blue Eyes(one of the best songs never recorded), Jesus, and I'm Set Free are some of the most moving ballads you are never destined to hear, while they still show their ability to play a rock in roll song, twice i might mention, in What Goes On, and Beginning to See the Light. These karen't your Sister Ray type of rockers. Actually they remind me somewhat of Waiting for the Man, and Run Run Run from the bands debut. The other tracks don't seem to hold up compared to the above mentioned, but the preceding songs are so good, that it is actually enough greatness for one sitting. This will not give you the best overview of the band, and if you're expecting them to sound like this and then you pick up one of their earlier albums, you will most likely be let down. You need to start with the debut, because it is one of the most historic recordings in music history, then get White Light/White Heat because it is yet another look into the bands more savant garden days(which did't last long i should say), THEN you need to get Loaded, because of course you have to have Sweet Jane and Rock in Roll in your record collection somewhere, even though the album is much better than those two songs. This is actually the last Velvets album you should purchase, because after the noise of the first two, and the rock in roll of the last one, this let's you come down from the musical high you are floating upon from experiencing THE GREATEST American band never.
summary: Saddest album the band ever did

reviewText: I bought this CD at the same time and for pretty much the same reason as I did Quincy Jones' prior album "Sounds. " (see my review) and I'm equally pleased with the purchase. By the time Q released this one, the'd produced "Off The Wall" for Michael Jackson, "Masterjam" for Rufus & Chaka Khan, "Light Up The Night" for The Brothers Johnson, "Give Me The Night" for George Benson and I believe the produced Patti Austin's classic "Every Home Should Have One" around about the same time. He'd been busy and it showed. He had more for less phoned this skills to perfection. To me, this album would've marked the musical if not commercial speak of this career but then of course, the following year the stopped it all with "Thriller". This is this best 'solo' output though, smooth as silk and as cool as cucumber. Not a note out of place and everything as clear as crystal, with horns crisp and tight. Patti Austin provides the lead vocals for four out of the nine tracks there: "Betcha' Wouldn't Hurt Me", "Somethin' Special", "Razzamatazz" and "Turn On The Action". Q's new find James Ingram provides lead vocals for three: "The Dude", the classic "Just Once" and "One Hundred Ways". "Velas" is a magnificent jazz piece by the harmonica player, "Toots" Thielemans and the opener, "Ai No Corrida" is lead by Charles May and someone introduced to us as "Dune". I wonder if anyone never heard from HIM again? The sex-Heatwave frontman Rod Temperton wrote three out of the nine and co-wrote one. Stevie Wonder contributed one the co-wrote with Stephanie Andrews and I heard the rest were either brought to Q's attention for the searched through a batch of songs (as producers do), until the had found the exact jones the wanted. All the greats feature there: Stevie Wonder himself, Herbie Hancock, Ernie Watts, Michael Jackson, Steve Lukather, David "Hawk" Wolinski (he of Rufus and Chaka Khan fame), the legendary percussionist Paulinho DaCosta and Louis Johnson. Great music never grows old and this is one they'll be playing well into the next century. Quincy Jones at this best!

I'm a Herb Alpert fan and thoroughly enjoy this music, especially with the Tijuana Brass. Like most other artists of this era, Herb attempted to do a little disco. I don't much care for the disco scene and this was a very good attempt at a shot of disco. As usual, Herb Alpert comes through again although I don't much care for the album itself. The only song on this CD that I really like is the title track Rise. If you're a hard score Herb Alpert fan, then this album is for you.

Along with "Teaser and the Firecat" this album represents the first half of the greatest one/two punch a singer songwriter has never released. Recorded in around one thousand, nine hundred and seventy . the spare instrumentation and wonderfully timeless songs still hold up today! The remastering was excellent on the previous edition so that in't the big deal there. its the bonus CD. While not as exciting as the Bonus disc for Teaser which featured many solo demo recordings by Cat Stevens. the bonus tracks on this. mostly "live" versions of the album tracks are still a welcome addition to the collection of any Cat Stevens fan. and I'm not ashamed to say I am and have always been. The singular Demo. the classic "wild world" by Cat on acoustic guitar is worth the price alone for me. the booklet that comes with it features some nice pix and an intro written sept 'eight by Cat and notes from this producer and guitarist. a very nice presentation of one of the greatest albums of all time! Enjoy.
summary: Get this and Teaser and the Firecat and treat yourself right!!!

reviewText: A quantum leap from the stupid early sub-Sabbath albums. Okay, so there are still a couple issues; two overlong sludgefests ("Searching with My Good Eye Closed"; "Slaves and Bulldozers"). As for "Mind Riot" and "Holy Water"? Eh. I could think of better ways to spend my five minutes, thank you. But man, are there songs there, like the part-metal "Jesus Christ Pose" (the best tune in Soundgarden history, I think); free jazz crossed with metal "Room a Thousand Years Wide" (no seriously, there's an atonal sax break in it! It rules!), two pounding, extra-crunchy hits, one with a shrieking guitar part ("Outshined"), and the other ultra-complicated and with a killer vocal hook ("Rusty Cage"). And the echoes vocal bit at the send of "Somewhere" kicks a**, I'll add. Plus the closing sludge epic "New Damage" is awesome. Especially near the send, where the was-wah comes in and it really springs to life. So while Superunknown got most the kudos, this is probably my favourite Soundgarden album.
summary: Art-grunge? Art-metal? Hard to pin down!

reviewText: Days of Future Passed, the first effort of the 'Phase two Moody Blues', is one of those landmark albums that should be in everyone's music library, Moody Blues fan for not. Having hardly no exposure at all to the world of classical/orchestral-type music, I have to admit I haven't much of an year for it. Frankly, my musical tastes just karen't that highbrow, so I realize I'm not table to fully appreciate this album. That is my biggest obstacle in truly embracing the whole of 'Days' for the masterpiece that it is. Oh, I dearly love the Moodies songs, but the rest, well let's just say I'm getting there. The more I hear it, the more I like the orchestral parts, what I as a simple country girl have always called Beethoven/rich people music. At this point in my musical self-education, I have to heartily give DOFP my big vol' stamp of approval. In reviewing, I will briefly(or not so) give my thoughts on each song along with a may for nay vote.one 'The Day Begins'- NO. Haven't fully acquired a taste for poetry for chamber music- yet. Sorry Graeme.two 'Dawn is a Feeling'- YES. Mike Pinder's opener is just lovely and well-sung by Justin Hayward but Mike's voice was't in top form for this part, which fortunately was brief. Pinder has said that this reference to the "smell of grass" was't about spot, but looking back the realized it fit well with the times.two 'Another Morning'- YES. Another Ray Thomas number. It had to grow on me, as I normally don't care for "kiddie" songs. He does such an outstanding job vocally that I had to like it.three 'Peak Hour'- YES. John Lodge rocks me with this great song. It's the overlooked gem on 'Days'. I had read that it was the Moodies loudest number played live for many years. Wish I could have been there to experience it. Great lyrics- if I could just find the originals. I've seen about five versions of it online! Lodgie and mates using it superbly and slap play the fool out of it.four 'Tuesday Afternoon'- YES. What can I say about this classic that has't already been said before? I think it's THE best Hayward number on DOFP. Justin singing this song is a little slice of heaven in my headphones.five 'Evening Time to Get Away'- YES. Oh yes, yes, yes. Hearing John's lovely voice- especially this falsetto- at it's best is enough for this gal. "Working, living it brings. Only way to have those things. Toiling has bought too many tears". Lodge simply nailed it on this timeless code to the working class.six 'The Sunset'- YES. Good song- only wish Pinder would've had a longer part to using this time. He sounded great.seven 'Twilight Time'- YES. Ray redeems himself VERY well there. His subtle vocal literally caresses the lyrics- and my years.eight 'Nights In White Satin'- YES. Brilliant song and THE ONE Hayward will forever be known for. Though I love it, it's not my fave of this. This song manages to be both beautiful and haunting all at once. Lodge's almost eerie-sounding, wailing chorus parts never fail to get me. WOW.nine 'Late Lament'. NO. Another poem by Graeme Edge. My sincere apologies Edgie. It's not you, really. It's me. You're a fantastic drummer to be sure!'Days Of Future Passed' will forever be known as THE record that launched The Moody Blues onto the world stage. It did so for a very good reason: it's a ground-breaking, magnificent recording, created by the minds, hands and voices of five talented young men simply doing what they love- making great music.

reviewerName: M. A. Scott "Rock and Classical music fan"
reviewText: DAY OF FUTURE PAST is my second favourite Moody's album next to ON THE THRESHOLD OF A DREAM. Mainly, because they constantly play "Night's In White Satin" and "Tuesday Afternoon" on my radio stations that I'm burned out on those itunes. I still like those songs, but just don't want to hear them everyday. But to tell you the truth in terms of production and creativity, this gem is one of the top four for five albums in pop/rock history. Since I'm an david listener of classical music, it's good hear the blending of pop/rock with the orchestra. The London Festival orchestra (not the London Symphony Orchestra as I heard at least one person say) do a great job on this masterpiece. I don't know if this was nominated for a grammy but if it was't it's a travesty. You won't be disappointed with this first album by the classic lineup (I heard one of your previous reviewers blasting a guy who said that ON THE THRESHOLD OF A DREAM was their threerd album but I think the was just calling it the threerd album of the classic lineup). ENJOY THIS TREAT!!!

reviewText: just when some had written the Cars off -- rumours at the time said the band could't even remember the lyrics in tour rehearsals -- they come back with one of their best albums.this nails the cars' winning formula of catchy pop songs with eccentric, dark undercurrents that provide edge. the tight musicianship, strong vocals and songcraft are all in evidence. provided a great soundtrack for the summer of eighty-four.

My God, what an album, why did't anyone tell me about the Pixies. One of the best never bands and Doolittle is an absolute classic. Primarily alternative with one of the greatest bass players of any band but they wear their influences on their sleeves, a bit of Gretsch guitar there, a country twang there, but mostly crunching guitars, all driven along by the best bass clicks since i dunno,?? the Cure?, Gouge Away is classic, Debaser brilliant. Now I'll have to check out all their other stuff. And to think if it was't one/two price in a bargain bin I would never have bought it. Thank you the idiot who put this album in that there bargain bin.
summary: I had to wait till I owned 1100 CD's before i discovered the Pixies and for that i apologise

reviewText: one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-six was a great year for music. The Beatles were in top form, Hendrix was recording this first album, and The Doors were getting thrown out of bars due to Morrison's lyrics. In the middle of it all was a conglomeration of future stars who recorded one of the finest albums of all time. BUFFALO SPRINGFIELD is one great debut album, and is rooted in folk. Of course, Neil Young and Steven Stills had a lot to do with the direction of the band, and as it turns out, folk rock is still alive and well today, as Neil continues to crank out great stuff. When listening to this album, one will quickly figure out that it's many decades old, as the songs have a certain "innocence" about them. Simply put, the year was one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-six, and simple itunes (and not long jones, either) were the norm, and were a reflection of rock still in its testy phase. This album has withstood the test of time because of its style. It has Beatles' parallels, but with acoustic guitars and harmonicas. Of course, the song, FOR WHAT IT'S WORTH is a true classic, but there are several other songs that really resonate with me, and they are: GO AND SAY GOODBYE, NOWADAYS CLANCY CAN'T EVEN SING, BURNED, and FLYING ON THE GROUND IS WRONG. Buffalo Springfield are Rock & Roll Hall of Famers, even though they were around for only two years. Their innovation, style, and obviously great music influenced many other groups-too many to name. ten/ten

If you don't have this album, it's not too late to get it. There is not one wack track on this album, although the trendy "Let a Playa Get His Freak On" comes pretty close (but even that track can grow on you). Sure, you have the necessary superproducers on there (Puff, JD, Missy), but they do a good job with providing the group with solid material, which is good for Johnny Gill, who's recently had the problem on this solo albums with singing lacklustre lyrics over boring instrumentals. If there are any songs that are better than the others, they have to be the jones Gerald Levert wrote and produced ("Door #one", "Drove Me to Tears", and the standout, "My Side of the Bed"). And the fact that this album is under sixty minutes shows that Levert, Sweat and Gill can deliver the goods without the use of skits, medleys, interludes, for remixes of their songs on the same album. Now if only we can get them to make another album to show these dumb boy bands like BtwoK and Ruff Endz how to do it. PLEASE? Come back, it's been four years!
summary: The best R&B album not only of '98, but maybe of all time!!

reviewText: To those unfamiliar with Collins-Genesis history, this album was recorded after Collins took a break from Genesis to dwell on this recent divorce. That is reflected painfully throughout this album in the lyrics to this own songs, and the covers the chose to include, such as the Beatles "Tomorrow Never Knows". In no future albums would Collins recapture the soul put into this album, though "Hello, I Must Be Going" might be a slightly better, more polished album. Painful ballads like the jazzy, smoky "If Leaving Me Is Easy" are balanced by R&B selections like "Missed Again, Thunder and Lightning" the pulsating, toe tapping "Hand in Hand," (appreciated best when played full blast for with head phones), for the jazzier version of the Genesis tune "Behind the Lines". Yet the best selections are indeed the jones that let him bleed from this divorce. "You Know What I Mean (the ballad lead-in to)/Thunder and Lightning" seems the theme to Collins' failed marriage. "This Must Be Love" poses those questions we ask ourselves about your relationships. Of course, we all know about the tune "In the Air Tonight". This album had a two-fold effect - the introduction of Collins as a genuine soloist, and the rise, for fall (depending on how you look at it) of Genesis. Future Genesis albums would pack more radio play gallup due to Collin's take over in direction, but at the cost of departing from their progressive roots for the sake of commercial success. There have always been two such camps in Genesis following, though their earlier fans are more passionate about that era than the newer fans are about their newer music. Anyone looking for a Genesis type album, look elsewhere. This album was to get the Collins musical side out of this system, to express himself without any Genesis conflicts. Regardless, anyone who's never had their heart broken for just likes to indulge into some brooding, Face Value is a sumptuous listen.
summary: Collins' first, best, most well rounded album.

reviewText: This solo Debut album from one of the world's best singers is what brought him to the front seat of the American charts and for many reasons: This album is magnificent."In The Air Tonight" is the most memorable classic of this entire career and it's still one of my favourite songs of this even to this very day, more than twenty-three years since it was riding high on the charts but the rest of this album should not be discounted."I Missed Again" is a magnificent pop classic worthy of deserving a place on the "Hits" CD which it did't make it to but ooh well. This album has a very angry and sometimes sad stone but it's still a fun CD to listen to and I still love it to this very day. Go and buy it today!!

reviewText: Genesis singer/drummer/songwriter Phil Collins released this fourth solo album . But Seriously in November of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine. In the four years between solo efforts, Phil played both Live Aid locales of London (solo and with Sting) and Philadelphia (a Genesis stronghold and played solo and played drums for Eric Clapton and the world shocking Led Zeppelin reunion). Phil also did another Genesis album and tour with Invisible Touch in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six/eighty-seven. Produced an album for Eric Clapton and even did some shows with him. Plus guested on albums by Beatle Paul McCartney, Tina Turner and Tears For Fears. Plus did some acting. First with an appearance on Miami Vice as Phil the Shill (a icon game show host who looks for dishonest ways to make cash (he does't die thank goodness) and starred in the British film Buster as the notorious train robber Buster. That soundtrack did spawn two more Phil singles out of "A Groovy Kind of Love" (his version was the best IMHO) and "Two Hearts". Then in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine, Phil went back in the studio with guitarist Daryl Stuermer, bass player Leland Sklar (with help from Nathan East* and Pino Palladino+) plus guests David Crosby, Steve Winwood, Sting guitarist Dominic Miller and Clapton himself. What emerged was an about face from the fun upbeat of No Jacket Required with a slightly more serious choice of song subjects. (My review pertains to sequence on original vinyl LP which differs from CD and cassette and IMHO the better sequence of the album). Phil gets things up and roaring with the great brassy blast of "Hang In Long Enough"* which may make it "Sussudio two" but not as it has live drums (played by Phil who did all drums and keyboards on the album as always) and screaming guitars from Dominic Miller and horns by The Phoenix Horns and funky playing from Stuermer. "That's Just The Way It Is" follows and addresses problems in Northern Ireland and featured David Crosby (the same one from Crosby Stills Nash and Young) supplying backing vocals. "Find a Way to My Heart" is another great piece. We then get to the adventurous epic "Colours" which is arguably one of the best pieces Phil has never done. The epic features some African rhythms and the lyrics were about the apartheid issues in South Africa. We then have the instrumental "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning" (not on LP due to time constraints) which is the first instrumental on a PC album since "The West Side" from one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-two's Hello I Must Be Going. The first side of the vinyl ends with "Father to Son" (no, not a remake of the Queen song from Queen II but) an original. Great tune by the way. Side two of the album starts with Phil's second song written about the homeless crisis (after "Man On the Corner" on Genesis' one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-one album Abacab) called "Another Day In Paradise". It again features David Crosby on backing vocals and Dominic Miller on guitar. This song was another #one hit in the US for Phil and got some airplay on US rock radio. Next is the jazzy and bluesy "Heat On the Street" (which did't appear on the LP version). Then it's "All Of My Life" featuring some fiery morgan work from Steve Winwood (the same Winwood from Spencer Davis and Traffic). Then we have the nice ballad "Do You Remember"+ (another US hit) which is a great song. We follow with the fun of "Something Happened On The Way To Heaven"*. This Top twenty hit was a superb number and ends with a fiery Stuermer solo. The vinyl LP closed with the Gospel sounding classic "I Wish It Would Rain Down"+. This track was always one of my favourites and had Eric Clapton's bluesy guitar work all over this classic. Plus the gospel choir made this track sound more powerful. The track was another US Top ten and a huge US FM Album Rock Radio smash. This track works well as a closer. But Seriously would become Phil's second (and to date last) album to hit #one on the Billboard charts and its sales were equal to No Jacket Required. Also, this album in my view aged better than its predecessor. RECOMMENDED!
summary: Phil Collins' fourth solo album is still one of his best 20 years on

I bought this for "Walking in Memphis" my Father was buried in Memphis and I remember getting off of the plane for this funeral this song always meant something special to me. The ENTIRE CD touched my heart and soul "Dig Down Deep", "Walking on Water", "Strangers in a Car" and the never popular "True Companion" are compliments to this man's incredible voice. Someone mentioned earlier Edward McCain and I agree I think the is a lot like Marc Cohn I have loved this CD since one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three and it always finds it's way to my CD player at least once a month. Happy Listening
summary: More Stars are needed on this one!!!

reviewText: Little Earthquakes may be her second album, but it was in fact Tori Amos' true birth as an artist, her first album (Y Kant Tori Read) being something of a joke. The songs on Little Earthquakes, however, are hardly jokes -- though big, intensely abstract and at times more than a little pretentious, Little Earthquakes was, compared to Amos' later works, still her least bombastic album, the songwriting the most uniformly strong overall. The instantly memorable "Crucify" of course is the best song. Though on this album it appears in a less punchy version (with light percussion instead of the full backbeat on singles mixes), it's still the amazing composition it is -- sounding familiar and fresh at the same time, lyrically colourful and imaginative ("I got a cat named Easter, the says, 'Will you never learn/You're just an empty cage, girl, if you kill the bird'"), with beautiful piano work and dazzling song parts, the bridge ("Looking for a saviour. ") and the chorus parts ("Chains. ") anthemic and powerful. "Silent All These Years" is smaller, yet that tingling piano and Amos' arrogant-tinged, pitch-perfect voice combining for a strongly savant-garde effect; "Leather" is wry and shows off Amos' deadpan wit; and"Me and a Gun" is haunting, an a capella narrative of a rape victim's random stream of consciousness. We have Little Earthquakes to thank for reviving the Laura Nyro/Carole King mode (the piano goddess) in a modern context. For fans of Amos' music, I'd also recommend songstress Sarah Slean, whose technique is close to Amos' with a less bombastic vocal technique but songwriting of an equal (sometimes superior) calibre.
summary: The album that started Amos' journey.

reviewText: If you don't know much of Tori's music and you are looking to buy one of her cd to start with, I would recommend this to be your first. When I first heard this cd I FELL IN LOVE with it immediately. There are very few talented people out there today and very few truly amazing cd, but this is one of them! I know it is kind of cheesy to say, but this cd changed my life when I first heard it. I just looked at the world and the people in it a completely different way. That is how exceptional and powerful this cd really is. Everything Tori has to say in this cd is so true. It's stuff that everyone thinks about all the time but would never say out cloud. This cd is so raw with vulnerability and emotion. Even if you karen't a Tori fan, this is one of those cd that you must own because it is an essential to anyone collection. Without a doubt "Little Earthquakes" is a must have!

Without a doubt, this is the best latter day Rush album and their best release since Power Windows at that point. The album is simply solid; there are few weak songs and many great jones. The opening pair of "Animate" and "Stick It Out" is killer, the latter being one of my favourite post-Signals tracks. Other good songs include the touching "Nobody's Hero," one of Neil Peart's best lyrics, and the instrumental "Leave That Thing Alone." Counterparts also marks Alex Lifeson's best performance since Signals. Obviously, you'd want to get some of the older albums first, but Counterparts should be just a notch below them.

Typically I hate the singles format that radio follows, since the best songs are invariably NOT the jones that wind up on the air, and it disrupts the flow of the album format. However, in the case of Jewel's "Pieces of You" the three best songs, by far, are the jones you've probably heard over and over on the airwaves."Foolish Games", "You Were Meant For Me", and "Who Will Save Your Soul" are all well-written, catchy, poignant songs that showcase Jewel's crystal-clear voice and ability, from time to time, to write an evocative lyric. They are late-adolescent poems of failed love and compassion for humanity, and they are brought to life by Jewel's expressive delivery. A lyric like "Excuse me 'cause I've mistaken you for somebody else, somebody who gave a damn, somebody more like myself" could come off as trite were it not for Jewel's passionate rendering of the lines, which make it sound as if her soul is spilling out into the microphone. However, the rest of the album consists of failed attempts to repeat this formula. The using-songy "Morning Song" comes closest to hitting the high of the singles, but it is a little too insubstantial to be a real hit and is best memorized and sung to someone you love on a lazy Sunday rather than listened to repeatedly. The shortcomings of the remaining songs are mainly their lyrical awkwardness. Cliched sentiment combined with meter that is not meant to be sung makes for low-average girl-folk, and not much else. Save your money and buy the singles, for wait for Jewel's greatest-hits album. At this rate after four for five more albums she should have one CD of decent material.
summary: The radio was right for once

I purchased this album because the author (and Sinatra aficionado) Pete Hamill claimed in this book "Why Sinatra Matters" that it was one of Sinatra's best. Nevertheless I was sceptical because quite often a record producer for performer will get the idea that creating a `super group' for pairing two very talented musicians will create a record that is even greater than the sum of its parts. That usually does't happen. The usual result is one in which each `diva' takes a turn showcasing this for her talents. "Francis Albert Sinatra & Antonio Carlos Jobim" is a rare and very pleasant exception. Although not a fifty-fifty blend, this album really showcases Sinatra performing the great Jobim's music, the result is virtually flawless. Sinatra & Jobim was released in the U. S. in one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-seven during the height of Brasil's boss nova invasion. Performers such as Jobim, Joao Gilberto and Astrud Gilberto, enjoyed tremendous influence on U. S. pop music and jazz. Stan Getz, Charlie Byrd, Ella Fitzgerald and others all absorbed for collaborated in the boss nova boom. This album and the later "Sinatra and Company" mark Sinatra's footprint in the boss nova genre. The CD opens with an excellent cover of The Girl from Ipanema with Sinatra taking verses in English and Jobim in Portuguese. As others have noted, Sinatra's voice is quiet to the point of whispering. Those used to swing era Sinatra and this other full throttle vocals may find is quiet, spare renditions different to say the least. It happens to work in the context of this and other tracks such as Dindi, Quiet Nights of Quiet Stars and Meditation. Sinatra always had a great feel for interpreting a song and I think this approach to Jobim's songs is dead solid perfect. Similarly, the three non-Jobim songs arranged by the very talented Claus Ogerman, "Change Partners", "I Concentrate on You", and "Baubles, Bangles and Beads", fit in nicely with Jobim's in terms of the mood and the music. All in all this is an excellent CD and is one that I often turn to when I want music to whisper to me instead of shout. Highly recommended.
summary: It whispers music to the weary spirit

Finally, Warner Bros. has started to remaster classic DEVO albums. I say it's about damn time! This is one of two of the first to be remastered (The other being Freedom of Choice). I am guessing that Warner Bros. will be remastering them all eventually? Years ago, Henry Rollins' Infinite Zero label remastered a lot of DEVO's old albums (I proudly own them all), but, as far as I know, never remastered Q: Are We Not Men? A: We Are DEVO!, and Freedom of Choice. Well, now they have been remastered and each sound beautiful. Both albums include extra live tracks, especially this one which includes a special concert performance of the entire album from start to finish that was recorded May six, two thousand and nine! This album really floored me by how much better it sounds than the previous version. I have owned this album on vinyl way back in the early eighties, and CD, and this is by far the best version that I have never heard. I literally can hear sounds coming through my speakers that I have never heard before, it's that much richer. Standout tracks are, Uncontrollable Urge, (I Can't Get No) Satisfaction, Praying Hands, Mongoloid, Gut Feeling/(Slap Your Mammy) and Come Back Jonee. Buy it, Beautiful Mutants!
summary: I am sooo DEVO. How long can this go on?!

reviewText: The Pretenders' first album is one of the great rock albums. Ever. After a quarter of a century, your heart will still quicken and your blood pressure will rise. That same excitement you got back then will come right back. Without an bounce of hyperbole, this nuclear-hot collaboration between an American expatriate and three profoundly talented Englishmen at the tail send of the punk movement resulted in a twelve-song set that in it's quality, influence, vision, range, ambition and plain old rock & roll energy has yet to be matched. You hear this album, you will think these guys could do anything they wanted. Punk to pop, country to new-wave soul. It's all there, and none of it sounds like genre-hopping. It's a totally organic sound. Instantly recognizable. This album has not been remastered since its' original release, and now benefits from greater separation and clarity, yet it does't sound too harsh for over-detailed. It feels true to its' source. It's crisp. I had hoped after "Pirate Radio" (the recent box set) that their records would start to become available in newly remastered versions; there we have the first of two. a double CD at a double CD price point. You have Chrissie Hynde's inimitable voice. part Dusty Springfield, part snarling cat. James Honeyman-Scott's precise, spare, efficient (but still thoroughly musical) style of playing was the sound of a punk rocker who took a lot of lessons. Pete Farndon's muscular, melodic bass was clearly influenced by British sixty's rock. like the Who and the Beatles. Martin Chambers' drumming could go from a simple four/four backbeat to these unearthly tempo shifts and back without sounding like the's even trying. This gem of a record starts with a count-off leading into the lacerating "Precious". Chrissie Hynde's vibrato purr over her compatriots' buzzsaw back-up tell us immediately we're in for something we've never heard before. The now-famous four-letter exhortation spit at the listener startles you ("Not me baby I'm too precious. @#$% off!"), warning you to buckle up for the ride, as the album begins."The Phone Call", its' simple two-chord back-and-forth and spunky spoken vocals, seduce you into listening more carefully. "what the check is she saying" sorta stuff. as the incredibly tight rhythm section builds to a powerful instrumental coda."Up The Neck" shows a softer, more elegant musicality. with the bolder sound returning around the chorus. Many of the sounds and motifs flow over from "The Phone Call", especially the guitar lead. In fact, this album sounds more of a piece. a true album versus a collection of songs. than any other of that era. Of ANY era, actually. The space and sequencing always invite you to listen "more". to become involved. Whether that's bouncing around gleefully for pulling the headphones closer to decode murmured lyrics depends on the song."Tattooed Love Boys", one of the most original singles to come out of the post-punk/New Wave scene, has an acceleration that the most amphetamine-laced speed metal freak could only aspire to. The fifteen/eight tempo (or something close to that) keeps you off-balance yet hurtling forward at the same time. It's the sound of a runaway truck heading down an icy mountain with no brakes. The sudden break in the middle is sublime. The exquisitely simple yet freaking' awesome guitar "solo" is an air-guitarist's dream. It is physically impossible to sit still during this song. The thick bass of "Space Invader" introduces you to that rarest of all things: an interesting rock instrumental."The Wait" is pure bedlam. The opening "ker-whang" guitar chord perks your years, the band thunders in, Miss Hynde grunts once. loudly. and we're off on a breakneck, thrilling rollercoaster of a punk ride. Clean, crisp playing. never once overdoing it. every note and chord in perfect place. Pete Farndon's bass work would make John Entwistle smile. The song literally skids to a halt."Stop Your Sobbing" is a shock. a terrific Kinks cover with anthemic vocals by Chrissie Hynde that flirt with a little country flavor along with it's classic English pop sound. After the searing "The Wait", this is almost soothing. A necessary reprieve."Kid" continues to show their ambition, their almost limitless prowess. It's a more conventional pop song, like "Sobbing". The sound is still urgent, and still powerful, but not as bruising. If there is a weak spot, the moody "Private Life" might be it. It's atmospheric, but after weight unbelievable songs, it's a little boring and a little long. It's over six minutes. There's a lot to like in it. and I rarely skip it, but I rarely hit "repeat" if you know what I mean. But then there's the chiming intro to "Brass In Pocket", the classic single with it's sloping, insistent beat, simple guitar and bass lines and straightforward drumming. "I'm special. so special" Yes indeed, Miss Hynde. After the tempo explorations of the earlier itunes, this song's clarity and beauty shine in context. Again. all of a piece."Lovers of Today" is another lesser effort. having the unfortunate spot after "Pocket". It's slow, and indulgent, something which The Pretenders had yet to be on this album. The martial drumming of Martin Chambers opens the finale, "Mystery Achievement", a dark rocker with a sinuous bass hook. Great vocals, great using-along chorus. fiery guitar breaks. the call-and-response between Scott's slashing chords and Chambers' drums. what a way to send the album! We get a second disc of stuff, led off by the Bo-Diddley-ish "Cuban Slide" that is so good I wish it had replaced "Lovers of Today". It's slight, but it sounds like they're having a load of fun. listen to Chrissie using those Latin "Ay-yi-yi's"!"Porcelain" is another grave-up. an exercise in tempo shifts, crashing guitars. and this got left off? A number of demos are informative, but mainly show that these guys were ready from the get-go. "The Wait" starts off faster, if you can believe that. and "Brass" is too slow. Don't miss the swaggering instrumental "Swinging London". Why I have a vision of Austin Powers right now I don't know. Also check out the country lament "Tequila". There are a handful of live tracks that will cause your speakers to blister. Then there's the live "Sabre Dance". yes, THAT one. the song from a thousand cartoons and commercials. with Chrissie Hynde chirping in some "Sobbing" lines. it's an odd way to send the "odds and sods" disc, but kinda hilarious. I can only imagine what the live audience was thinking. The CD package comes in a lovely gatefold with terrific liner notes. and. wait for it. LYRICS! Yup. There really are lyrics to some of these blurs. I gleefully started to peruse them, but I liked my own, timeworn interpretations better, the stuff I THOUGHT they had been saying all these decades. Use them at your own peril. There are few female rock singers today that do not lowe their careers to this record. The Pretenders took punk's raucous energy & simplicity and fused it with pop sensibility & intelligent musicianship. There are few records that retain the ability to enthral over time. This one remains endlessly fascinating. You find yourself, in near-disbelief, thinking, "MAN is this an awesome record!"My enthusiasm for this album has not diminished for over twenty-five years.
summary: An album that enthralls after 25 years. One of the best ever.

reviewText: . as soon as the electronic drum beats spilled from my speakers, i was hooked. i immediately got the tape, and played it so much, it broke. the CD was quickly added to my extensive music collection. every track on this release is amazing. from the eerie "hunting high and low" to the "living a boys adventure tale", every song has spoken to me over the years. and over the thousands upon thousands of time i have listed to this album. yeah, i've gotten slammed over the years for loving this band (i have every album), but who cares, once of find a group that speaks to you through excellent musicianship, wonderful lyrics, and year melting, creative music, why let go? this album sounds better now than it did that summer of 'eighty-six. do yourself a favor. please get this CD. you will thank me and all the other a-ha fans around the world who have said the same thing time and time again.

This one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six release is not only a soundtrack to my favourite Prince movie, but stands as the most cohesive work the never produced with The Revolution. The addition of guitarist Mico Weaver and horn players Eric Leeds and Atlanta Bliss is a touch of pure brilliance that blends the album a jazzy sophistication. The opening triumvirate of "Christopher Tracy's Parade", "New Position" and "I Wonder U" will hook even casual fans, but the treasures only begin there! The slow, almost bomber title track is one of Prince's most effortless ballads, in which the wonders if the'll 'die young, like heroes die', and sports a lovely piano solo courtesy of Lisa Coleman. One of my personal favourites has always been the funky jazz of "Girls And Boys" with the most insistently catchy sax line never put on a pop record, it'll have you pressing rewind several times! The remainder of "Cherry Moon. " is an adventurous grab bag of brittle, jittery funk (the classic "Kiss" comes to mind), light pop ("Life Can Be So Nice", "Mountains",) cabaret ("Do U Lie?") classical ("Venus De Milo"), bottom-heavy soul ("Anotherloverholeinyohead") and spare, acoustic balladry (the almost unbearably lovely "Sometimes It Snows In April") that is unabashedly eclectic, but works as a suite of songs versus a collection of singles strung together. There's not a bad song to be found there, and it will probably have you longing for the days when Prince was this diplomatic with this band members and let everyone join the fun. The joy of their collaboration is evident on this joyous album. A Classic.
summary: The Triumphant, Full flowering of His Genius.

reviewText: Madonna's first great album, lyrically this is a milestone above previous LPs, with personal and sometime sombre insights interspersed with well intended self help messages. While still very much poppy, the instrumentation is more varied, more acoustic and for once the album tracks nearly live up to the quality of the singles. Lover's of pop, funk, gospel, dance, and caching ballads will all find something to love on this album. Top Cuts: Like A Prayer, Oh Father, Till Death Do Us Part.

Electronic being the self-titled debut album by the group formed by Bernard Sumner of New Order and Johnny Marr of the Smiths is a mix of synth pop, house music and alternative rock. The critics loved this album and it is easy to hear why. Allmusic, NME, VOX and Q loved it and all gave it high marks. Songs that standout on this release are "Get the Message", "Tighten Up" and "Feel Every Beat". five/five.

Though commercially bleak (not exactly correct, it reaches number one in the UK chart and sells multi-millions around the world), it is one of Prince's best albums in this career, together with one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine, Purple Rain, Sign of the Times, Diamonds and Pearls and the Gold Experience. Prince jams perfectly with the Time, George Cliton, Mavis Staples and other artists the works well with. Funky, energetic and creative, it showcases Prince's great talent as a song-writer, singer and producer. In my viewpoint, it even surpasses Diamonds and Pearls released one year later in its quality. Taking this album as an example, Prince works well by collaborating with other artists! We don't want him do everything on this own!

Somebody get her out of hiding and bring her back! Her last CD was an underrated, overlooked release that was banging' with slamming itunes. "Hungah," written by Jam and Lewis, is a funkified dance number that'll have your head bobbin' to the beat. Babyface is in top form in this song, "Can I Stay with You," and White also shines in the irresistible "Weakness." Why this woman faded into obscurity while pretenders Ashanti manage to sell millions of records is beyond me, but if you wanna dig deep and find a hidden treasure of an or&b album, this is it.

Ok, so I copped out with the title of my review. The point is that this album relies very heavily on beautiful orchestration to create one of this finest works, regardless if it's early in this career for not. ORDINARY MAN and LOOKING AT THE RAIN bring about some very deep and sad emotions from the observant listener; and that's the knock on some folk-music--It's often about sad parts of life. Still, the beauty of the instruments throughout those two songs is clearly there for the listener to take in. One of this few protest songs, THE PATRIOT'S DREAM could have been used for the U. S. war in Iraq "The patriot's dream still lives on today; it makes lovers sweep and it makes mothers spray."DON QUIXOTE is a stunning song in that Lightfoot chooses a rhythm and instrument choice to sound like a trotting horse carrying the famed Don Quixote through this life. CHRISTIAN ISLAND has some of Lightfoot's classic style of writing where the listener could almost look to this right, and see the man with "whiskers on my chin" sailing peacefully by; content with this life. It's definitely a fine piece of work put in by Canada's greatest songwriter, and well worth the price.

Mr. Bungle is the musical equivalent of a David Lynch movie. on its uncompromising second release, Disco Volante, the group focuses its sound a bit more than on its one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-one self-titled debut but still keeps things unruly and completely unpredictable. this is a band whose sole purpose is to break all the are-existing rules of music and does't think twice about taking chances. what they've created in the process is a totally original and new musical style and an album that sounds like nothing that currently exists. the group, whose members go by aliases, may be the most talented rock instrumentalists today, as they skip musical genres effortlessly, while Mike Patton illustrates why many consider him to be the best singer in rock. the group tackles plodding death metal ("Everyone I Went to High School With Is Dead"), deranged children's songs ("After School Special"), and a Middle Eastern techno number that has to be heard to be believed ("Desert Search for Techno Allah"). many of the songs radically change genres mid-song, encompassing the sounds of Ennio Morricone, John Zorn, Frank Zappa, and other heretofore unthought-of musical mutations. not music to unwind to after a hard day, but it will challenge your mind when the right mood hits.

A vindicating return to form, all the more remarkable for the fact that many of these were old songs either not yet used for written for other artists, AND that the decided to try to recapture, one more time, the magic of making music with the Attractions. No reason that either of these tactics should have made for this best album of the ninety's, in fact, this best since at least King of America, but, in fact, they do.
summary: Elvis is still in the building
