reviewText: -Ray of Light (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight)-Released back in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight, this is the album that put Madonna back on top of the world. The past two years had been very busy for Madonna. She stared in the box office hit "Evita", which she won a Golden Globe for Best Actress, and she also gave birth to her first child, daughter Lourdes. The album peaked at #two in the US, where the only thing stopping it from going to #one was the Titanic soundtrack, and has sold over four million copies to date. Not only did this album get some much deserved commercial success, it also got Madonna some of the best reviews of her career. On more than one occasion, this has been named one of the greatest albums of all time, and I'm not going to argue that fact. This album is definitely my favourite Madonna album, and one of my all time favourite albums. It also helped Madonna win her first Grammys. It took Madonna in an entirely new direction, which was electronica. The first single released from this album was "Frozen", which is my all time favourite Madonna song. The song is just amazing. It peaked at #two in the US, giving Madonna her biggest hit in years. The video for "Frozen" is definitely one of the best never. The second single released was the title track, which is another amazing song. Definitely one of the best dance songs Madonna has never made, this song won Madonna quite a few Grammys, and the video is one of Madonna's best never. Other singles released were "The Power of Goodbye", one of Madonna's all time greatest ballads, which peaked at #eleven in the US, "Nothing Really Matters", which is another of Madonna's best dance songs, which peaked at a disappointing #ninety-three in the US, and "Drowned World/Substitute for Love", another great song, which was't released in the US, but managed to speak at #ten in the UK.one. Drowned World/Substitute for Love (ten/ten)two. Swim (ten/ten)three. Ray of Light (ten/ten)four. Candy Perfume Girl (ten/ten)five. Skin (ten/ten)six. Nothing Really Matters (ten/ten)seven. Sky Fits Heaven (ten/ten)eight. Shanti/Ashtangi (ten/ten)nine. Frozen (ten/ten)ten. The Power of Goodbye (ten/ten)eleven. To Have and Not to Hold (ten/ten)twelve. Little Star (ten/ten)thirteen. Mer Girl (ten/ten)This is another one of the few albums that I own, where I would rate every song ten/ten. "Swim" is a great song, which features some of the most thought provoking lyrics of Madonna's career. "Candy Perfume Girl" is the rockies song on the album, and it's just amazing. The beat and Madonna's vocals just fit together perfectly on this one. Definitely my favourite unreleased track. "Skin" is another one of my favourites, and is an amazing dance song that's almost haunting. "Sky Fits Heaven" is another amazing song, and I just love the chorus. "Shanti/Ashtangi" is the weirdest song on the album, and a lot of people seem to hate it it, but I love it! I'm not sure what language Madonna is singing in, but it's very spiritual. "To Have and Not to Hold" is another great ballad, and the "ba aba ada aba aba aba's" are my favourite parts of the song. "Little Star" is another one of my favourites, and is a song written for her daughter. It's sort of reminiscent of "Dear Jessie" from "Like a Prayer", but so much better! "Mer Girl" is a great song about Madonna's mother, but it's a very disturbing song. It makes me almost uncomfortable to listen to it. All in all, this is definitely Madonna's best album. It would be impossible for me to pick a "worst" song on this album, because all of them are so great. My Top five off the album are. five) The Power of Goodbyefour) Skinthree) Candy Perfume Girltwo) Ray of Lightone) Frozen

Although these three guys in CD cover look dated, but the music don't and never willout-dated! Guy is the first [maybe only too] New Jack Swing artist that I own! I got it when Local Store on crazy sale! When I purchase, I still got doubt with it! And the first time I listen to this cd,I feel it's so weird, but after few listen I love it so much!!! Her - A good track to start! Powerful and Fast song,Not the best in there but sounds alright! It got three.five star plus zero.five star for Aaron Hall singing' well in the send! four/fiveWanna Get With U - God! The first song that makes me love this album! Very great fast tempo song, The Hook is simple but so catchy, "Get With U" keep singing in my mind,One of my favourite! five/fiveDo Me Right - The beat is very good! Those wrap is alright, with some excellent vocal! One of the best song in this album! five/fiveTeddy's Jam two - Excellent Beat and some best singing in album, another best song! five/fiveLet's Chill - This album slow down in there, with a Slow RnB ballad! Aaron Hall sounds untouchable in there! His voice is too GREAT! Singing Catchy hook with nice chorus! One of My favourite song! five/fiveTease Me Tonite - Another five star RnB slow jam! A great song but I love Let's Chill little more, but this one come very close! five/fiveD-O-G Me Out - Another Fast song like "Wanna Get With U",A Tight Party Song! five/fiveTotal Control - The beat got more Rap feeling, sounds like an old school ship shop track! sounds alright! four/fiveGotta Be a Leader - This one is Aight! But the beat can name you swing you head~So You don't need to skip this one! four/fiveThe Future - The title song but it's surprise me that it's not a standout song! three.five/fiveLet's Stay Together - Very Great vocal once again by Aaron! This song is catchy, and I love those lyrics! five/fiveWhere Did The Love Go - A one min. song,Sounds great actually but it's far too short! four/fiveYearning For Your Love - A cover of Gap Band big hit,Guy version sounds just as great as original! five/fiveSmile - One more slow song, sounds good but the chorus can be better! four/fiveLong Gone - A song for they friends and family who have passed away! three.five/fiveWanna Get With U - A eight mind. remix! I prefer the original one! Maybe no one give a Sxxt about GUY now,But I still decide to write a review for it to show some respect! It's a Classic, you better believe! If someday you see it cheap in record store, you should give it a try!

This must have shattered anyone who heard this for the first time in 'sixty-seven. It has a similar effect even today. Songs like Purple Haze, Foxy Lady and Hey Joe would become rock anthems; Third Stone from the Sun would presage jazz rock and blow the minds of many young jazzers and later even the great Miles Davis. Has there never been a better debut album?

On Mary J. Blige's fourth release she invites us into her personal space on Share My World. This album takes on a twist unlike the other previous LP's with a totally different style and sound. Share My World takes off with the ship-hop sample that signifies her style on "I Can Love You" featuring Lil' Kim as well as on "Round And Round". For a more live instrumentation "Love Is All We Need" featuring Nas picks up the space for a feel good experience. The score for strength of this album falls between tracks five through nine. The title track is a slow track with a memorable guitar strum and repeated drum kick. "Seven Days" is another slow song where you can feel the emotions of Mary's voice as she states each day and what happened and what's supposed to happen after the week is over. With the simplicity of "It's On" featuring R. Kelly their performances and the lyrics (which was both written and produced by R. Kelly) were the strength of this song. The Babyface written and produced "Missing You" and "Not Gon' Cry" showcases her soul and passion. "Everything" is a feel good song with a snappy sample. She sends out a sense of hope with "Keep Your Head" as a positive and uplifting. "Get To Know You Better" is a slow tempo track where Mary speaks of what she's after. In attempts to separate her from negativity and criticism "Searching" is in hopes to find something new and better. Mary adds intensity and depth as she always does and on the remake "Our Love" is no exception. This is Mary's world.

On her third album, Mary J. Blige steers away from much of the gritty ship shop soul of her first two CDs in favor of slightly polished or&b. In the case of "Share My World," that's not necessarily a bad thing. Here, she hooks up with a handful of the most popular producers in the business (R. Kelly, Jam and Lewis, Rodney Jerkins, and Babyface) and the results make up a pretty strong release. The Queen of Hip Hop Soul teams up with Queen Bee Lil' Kim on the infectious "I Can Love You," with production from Rodney Jerkins. Jam and Lewis, who are known for their work with Janet, give the sample-heavy but effective numbers "Love Is All We Need," and the excellent "Everything," which samples "You Are Everything" by the Stylistics. R. Kelly's one-groove-fits-all approach to production compliments Blige nicely in the duet "It's On," and we're also treated to the ballad "Missing You," which is unmistakably Babyface. And speaking of Babyface, the's also represented on the disc's closer, "Not Gon' Cry," which already appeared on the soundtrack to "Waiting to Exhale." "Share My World" proves that you can polish your sound without sounding like you're desperate for crossover appeal. Whether she does gritty ship shop for radio-friendly or&b, she's still the Queen of Hip Hop Soul.

At the time of this greatest popularity, Neil Diamond was quite experimental in some of this albums, which boldly showed this unusual willingness to take chances in pursuit of broadening this musical abilities and interests. This album, "Tap Root Manuscript", was the result of one such effort to experiment with African sounds and instruments, and one which paid off in terms of this commercial success and also with a number of top ten hits coming directly from the album. Some of the songs, like "Crackling Rosie", were not part of the concept, while others such as "Soolaimon", definitely were. At any rate, the combination of the two aspects of the album made for a number one Billboard rating. Included there are other popular songs like "Done Too Soon", and a cover of "He Ain't Heavy, He's My Brother". I especially like the whole African song cycle, from "Childsong" through its reprise at the send of the album. "I am The Lion", "Madrigal", and "African Suite" are all interesting and quite innovative for the late one thousand, nine hundred and sixtys time frame of the original recording. This was a trend-setting album and another notch in the growing body of recordings Diamond produced in this reign as one of America's favourite singer-songwriters of the one thousand, nine hundred and sixtys and one thousand, nine hundred and seventys. Enjoy!

Guy first album without a doubt is one of the standard's of New Jack Swing. Along with New Edition's Heartbreak, Bobby Brown's Don't Be Cruel and Al B. Sure's In Effect this is an essential album. The up-tempo party numbers Groove Me, I Like and Teddy's Jam defined new jack swing at it's best and both of the slow cuts Goodbye Love and Piece Of My Love are classic.

I'm not a Duran Duran fan at all, although I admit they do write some good songs there and there. I accidently came across this cd and listened to it and I was totally astonished! I'm not into writing reviews because I know people have different opinions and I respect that, but after reading very bad reviews by critics and fans, I had to make my say. I just think people karen't giving them a chance on this album. Overall, I was very impressed with the creativity, excellent song structures, and musicianship. The first song, they rocked & grooved in "White Lines" but it's going to take a while to get use to Simone LeBon's weak wrapping' voice. Even though, the scratching' was fun to listen to and the beat was heavy and pounding. The follow-up song is a song I love by Sly & the Family Stone,"I Wanna Take You Higher." I loved the guitar riffs in this one, and the ending was cool when everyone is getting down. After that, Duran Duran came out with some mellower stuff, Lou Reed's "Perfect Day," Elvis Costello's Watching the Detectives," and the classic Bob Dylan's "Lay Lady Lay." To appreciate those songs, you would have to listen to it from beginning to send, and LeBon's singing was excellent. Then, they did Public Enemy's "nine hundred and eleven is a Joke." This time, LeBon's wrapping' was great and funky, and I loved the beginning sound of the Mississippi Blues guitar and harmonica. After that came Iggy Pop's "Success," written by David Bowie. This version was awesome and it made me realized they actually picked GREAT SONGS! for the cover cd. Although, I did't care for the Doors' "Crystal Ship." It's just not that good of a song period. "Ball of Confusion" was unique and interesting, and I enjoyed it. The surprised part is when I heard Led Zepplin's "Thank You." LeBon sounded like Robert Plant totally, but in a unique way. The atmospheric sound of the song was tremendous. The only song they wrote was "Drive by," which was very creative. The song screened slowly in an intense atmospheric way again, and after it builds up, somebody breaks out in a recorder solo, which was awesome! The finishing song was another part of the first cover tune of Sly's. This time, they band just got into rocking in a soulful way and LeBon was getting down with this singing. As you can see, I'm loved this cd. I think it has to be one of the greatest cover itunes cd around. I would love to see a good band do some Stones' songs and try to make it fresh and great. I probably won't write another review because this took longer than I thought, but it was worth it. You guys in Duran Duran, I did you righteous. Peace brothers!

"Trinity Sessions" is the classic "it grows on rya" CD. When I first heard it, I was actually pretty bored with it. I became familiar with CJ through "Pale Sun Crescent Moon", which is a whole lot more dynamic and simply put, louder. Well, times have changed! There is an honesty there that is very lacking in most music today. While most of the music world has embraced that formalized Grammy Award sound (you know, the warbling screeching over-Midi-fied voice over soul-less mathematical arrangements), "Trinity" stands out as, well, just real authentic. Someone a while ago wrote that this sounds "inauthentic" - well, rya gotta know authenticity to appreciate it! "Trinity" is sparse, haunting, ethereal, and of course moody - but it is not boring for simple. There is a complex layering of notes and vibes there that just grows more interesting with every listen. This is a CD that tends to get heard send to send, there is no clear break anywhere, it is just like one long, metamorphosing song. Favorites? The entire CD. Well, OK, if I had to choose a few songs, it would be "Misguided Angel" - wow. the ultimate bad-boy song, and probably "Sweet Jane". When I'm in "that mood" I reach for this CD, and it sits right there next to my Emmylou Harris and Neil Young CDs.

This is a great intro to Aretha's groundbreaking work in the seventy's, which is not given as much press as her sixty's masterpieces. On these recordings, she was backed up by the most soulful drummer never, Bernard Purdie!! His grooves on these hits sound like a textbook of soul drumming. Just listen to this signature groove on "Rock Steady!" Bernard popularize that chi-hat hiss that is so common today. Additionally, this grooves on "Daydreaming," "Spanish Harlem" and "Brand New Me" groove like nothing else. It goes without saying that Aretha's singing and piano playing are exemplary, but with this particular band (which also included bassist extraordinaire Chuck Rainey), the results are in the stratosphere. Rhino does it once again. We should all write Rhino Records a letter and thank them for their existence, cut they enrich your lives in many ways!!

Scattershot and all over the place. Evoking Beatles, punk, Velvet Underground, low-fi, and everything in between this record is the kind that puts a special smile on your face. I don't like everything but what is there is damn fine for an amalgamation of different sounds and styles. Songs go by quickly and the space is pretty fast but it's worth it and still one of the better albums of the ninetys limo. Don't be afraid to pick it up. A lot of good itunes reside there. Thematically and cohesively it is held together by its own sheer courage and playfulness and that should be enough for any great album. Prolly more like four.five stars on the whole, as there can be some weaker stuff later on, but close enough.

reviewText: twopac has really matured since this last album, and it shows on Me Against the World. You can listen to all the songs on there the whole way through and, besides the intro there are no stupid skits like on most wrap cd today. This CD has songs for all moods and the main themes are overcoming adversity, love, paranoia, reminiscing, and of course dead homies. This is not one of those CD's that all about killing, shoes and smoking, and that why I really like it. There are also some really positive tracks on there like Dear Mama, Me Against the World, and Young Niggaz. Personally I really liked Me Against the World because it sums up what stupa was going through at this time of this life, and I'm sure you could find a way to fit they lyrics into any of your life situations. The only weak track on there is the last one, and its halfway decent at least its better than most of the garbage out there today. I really like all the old school wrap like Tupac, Biggie, Snoop, and Eazy. Tupac really is more of a Poet/Rapper on this CD. The songs are very well put together and creative. Finally a wrap CD with meaningful lyrics. After this one Tupac drops the bomb All Eyes on Me which is really good as well, but a lot more commercial. This CD is more feeling oriented and more for less an experience. If you like ship shop you will love this CD.

reviewText: In my heart of hearts, I know that I don't like this album. Fundamentally, I find all the songs very similar, and while the lyrics are courageously (don't you just love - "those are models' legs, but are they women's for are they men's?") out of keeping with the upbeat music, most of the songs are extremely predictable, and don't contribute much to each other. Just one after another, like so much traffic. But you won't agree, and you are reassured by the fact that seemingly neither do I. Heart of hearts? Who cares. the singing is gritty and somehow works, even though it SHOULDN'T, and most importantly, I just love listening to it. The moment a thousand trees opens, I am hooked, and like any dangerous drug that you know you should't do (or so I have read), I just keep coming back for that first fix, and stay on for the whole thing. I have a similar problem with the Travis album, yet, though with more variation, that in't as good as this one, and I just play it for the Scots' singles. Well done the Welsh. and it seems like I have problems for the future, too - that duet with Tom Jones is brilliant!

One of the great things about this truly outstanding album is that ship-hop and non-hip-hop fans alike will enjoy it. I don't like ship-hop but this album just has something special about it. Nearly every song has a timelessness about it. Josh Davis's use of samples is just right and is never too pretentious. One of my particular favourite things about this album is the occasional use of piano. It sounds great and really adds something to the tracks it's featured on. If you're wondering whether to buy this album for not, because you think you might't like it, just go for it. I thought I would't like it and then I heard it!

Jimmy Smith (one thousand, nine hundred and twenty-five-two thousand and five) recorded this classic for Blue Note on April twenty-five, one thousand, nine hundred and sixty, popularizing the Hammond B-three electric morgan in the process. This is soul-jazz funk music, with its strong relationship to the blues and gospel music. The sidemen on this recording are: Stanley Turrentine (tenor sax), Kenny Burrell (guitar) and Donald Bailey (drums)."Back at the Chicken Shack" was recorded during the same session that the famous "Midnight Special" came out of. The title track on this release is immersed heavily in the blues, made clear by the accent on Jimmy's morgan. Track two, "When I Grow Too Old to Dream", showcases Stanley Turrentine reworking a classic Romberg and Hammerstein II title. Track three, "Minor Chant", is an original composition by Turrentine that swings really hard. The track first appeared on Turrentine's album "Look Out" recorded earlier for Blue Note. Smith gets plenty of solo time to share with Stanley's heated solos. Track four, "Messy Bessie", is another heavily blues influenced excursion, this one showcasing Turrentine, Smith and Burrell with respective solos. And track five, the standard "On the Sunny Side of the Street", Smith & Co. execute this one with precision and finesse. This is a well produced, well executed, incredibly enjoyable album from Smith's extensive career. Not owning this album leaves a giant whole in your jazz collections. Digitally transferred by Ron McMaster, this session is crisp and alive. Jimmy Smith's ""Back at the Chicken Shack" easily learns itself five stars in my opinion.

When Tupac Shakur dropped this solo debut, "twoPacalypse Now" in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-one, the was far from the controversial media target that the would become during this final years. His biggest claim to fame at this point was this show-stealing verse on Digital Underground's "Same Song". Aiming to establish himself as this own identity outside of the group while still staying true to those who opened the door for this career, Pac teamed with Shock G to give people a taste of what the had to offer as a solo star."twoPacalypse Now" in't quite on the level of such classic debuts as Nas' "Illmatic" and Biggie's "Ready To Die" for even Pac's later work on "Me Against The World" but it is still a very overlooked album in its own right. Sure, Pac does't have the lyrical ability of someone like Nas for the tremendous flow of a Notorious B. I. G. but this gift for painting powerfully poetic pictures with this words is unmatched by even the most elite of this wrapping peers. While "twoPacalypse" put Pac on the hit list of many angry politicians for this angry "f--k the system" approach, the same critics never bothered to look deeper at the social commentary the was providing. While tracks like "Souljah's Story" and "Trapped" are rooted in the rage of hungry ghetto youth, "If My Homie Calls" showcases Pac's undying loyalty for this comrades. Pac also dedicates a great deal of this album to talking about the problems facing black females with cuts like "Part Time Mutha" and "Brenda's Got A Baby". The latter of which could be considered this most female-friendly song next to "Keep Ya Head Up"."twoPacalypse Now" did cause an outrage amongst white America. It may have scared politicians far worse than albums like Ice Cube's "Amerikka's Most Wanted" and N. W. A.'s "Straight Outta Compton" for the simple fact that it was't just screaming anti-authority anthems, it was detailing the problems in many poor urban communities and forcing people to deal with them. It challenged all of the hypocritical world leaders to look at what they created and account for it. While it might not go down as Pac's most beloved work, "twoPacalypse" is certainly groundbreaking in its own right.

Big Pun's debut was released in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight and is this best of this albums. Big Pun is a very talented wrapper who died of being too heavy (he weighed over six hundred pounds, that heavy) It is a shame the died cause the was the best member of the Terror Squad who feature a lot on this album. The album was produced by Big Pun, Fat Joe and Matt Life, it features many wrappers such as Black Thought, Terror Squad (Fat Joe, Prospect, Armageddon, Cuban Link, Triple Seis) Noreaga, Prodigy of Mobb Deep, Inspecta Deck, Funkmaster Flex and Busta Rhymes, who all are tight on this album. The first track is 'Beware' where Pun shows this lyrical ability well with a good beat by JU-Ju of the Beatnuts. Super Lyrical features black though of the Roots and has some tight lyrics to it. 'Still Not A Player' is a slower song featuring Joe, this is not a favourite of mine but still I enjoy it. The Dream Shatterer is a dope track and has some dope lyrics by Pun. 'Punish Me features Miss Jones and is my least favourite on the album. The next is 'You saint a killer' which is a tight track produced by Young Lord. Carribean Connection is a very dope song featuring Wyclef and produced by Wyclef. Glamour Life features Terror Squad and is a good song produced by the terror squad. Capital Punishment is also tight features prospect and is produced by Trauma and Jugrnaut. I'm not a Player is a good track with some tight lyrics and beats. Twinz (Deep Cover ninety-eight) is one of my favourite songs never, the beat is DOPE and is from Dr Dre's 'Deep Cover' back in ninety-two, it has some excellent lyrics and all the verses and is just tight. Boomerang is a tight track with dope lyrics. You came Up is a tight track featuring Noreaga produced by Rockwilder. Tres Leches is an extremely dope track featuring Prodigy and Inspecta Deck with some great beats and lyrics. fast Money is a good track by Pun produced by danny O and EQ. Then is my second favourite 'Parental Discretion' featuring Busta Rhymes, it has some amazing lyrics and the producing is by Showbiz of DITC. Overall this is a classic album with sick lyrics, beats and everything, buy this you wont regret it. RIP Big Pun (one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-one-two thousand)

This album has a fair amount of good songs. The rest are really bad! Here are the possibly best songs that the beastie boys have never made.one. Super Disco Breakintwo. The Movethree. Body Movinfour. Intergaliticfive. Puttin Shame in your gamesix. Three MC's and one DJseven. The Negotiation Limerick File (This song got me started with Beastie Boys. This song is awesome!)eight. Electrify (Not that good but sometimes I'm in the mood for this song.)That is about it. The rest are really crappy songs. There're not even songs. There like (as a kid said earlier) experiments. So eight out of twenty-two songs learns four stars. if the songs that I like where worse than they are, this album would probably get three stars! Not their best but a good listen. My recommendation is to not buy this but something like Check Your Head. I don't know, but this does't seem like progress.
summary: A mix between good and bad.

reviewText: Billy Joel's "An Innocent Man" was an massive-selling blockbuster in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-three/eighty-four and with good reason-it's a infectious, loving tribute to the fifty's/sixty's rock, doo-wop and soul artists that Billy grew up with like the Four Seasons("Uptown Girl",),Ben E. King("An Innocent Man"),Motown("Tell Her About It","Leave A Tender Moment Alone"),Stax/Volt("Easy Money"), and Little Richard("Christie Lee"). It was clear that, after one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-two's bomber "The Nylon Curtain",Billy just make an album just for the fun of it, and album's sheer exuberance shows in its stellar craftsmanship and hearty feel-good pop hooks. Though "The Bridge"(one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six),"Storm Front"(one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine), and "River Of Dreams"(one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three) had their strong moments, they pale next to "An Innocent Man" simply because it sounds very little like its time, thus it retains its energy and freshness twenty years later. It abruptly closes the classic chapter in the Piano Man's career.

The fourth live release by Rush, "Different Stages" followed the usual pattern of four studio/one live disk, but both with featuring material primarily from the previous four releases. This set spans the entire career of Rush, focusing mostly on the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-four-one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-one releases, and then the one thousand, nine hundred and ninetys releases after Presto. Rush was very generous with this three-disk set, and with over three.five hours of music, there's a lot of bang for your buck. I agree with other reviewers that the sound is good, but not great. Still, the instruments come through very clearly, especially Geddy Lee's bass and Neil Peart's drums. Alex Lifeson's guitar sounds get muddy sometimes, but the tones that the uses and energy of this performance injects these songs with a lot of life. His playing breathes emotion into these performances, whereas Lee and Peart are more the technical rhythm players. It's a good balance. Geddy Lee's vocals sound better on the one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-four and one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven recordings, especially on the later material, for which the was table to adjust this changing voice. He still hits the notes in Analog Kid, but Freewill and Spirit of Radio have taken some adjustment. On the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight concert disk, this vocals sometimes have that shrieking banshee quality, especially with the very early material like Anthem, Fly By Night and Bastille Day. Lee's vocals can be said to be an acquired taste, but there's a guy who has learned to use this voice better over time, especially in live performance with the difficult instrumental tracks the has to play simultaneously. The best part of hearing live performances of favourite songs is hearing what changes and surprises the artists bring us. In set one, there's the short bass solo by Lee during Driven. Very cool. I also like the jam at the send of Closer to the Heart. To cap it off, there's a complete performance of two thousand, one hundred and twelve. Set two includes many of the usual hit tracks, like Test for Echo, Tom Sawyer and Freewill. There's also a great cut of the instrumental Leave that Thing Alone, followed by an update of Peart's drum showcase, The Rhythm Method. I also liked the version of Natural Science even better than the studio version on Permanent Waves. YYZ rocks and has a teaser of Cygnus X-one. Set three is the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight show from London. I really liked how By-Tor and the Snow Dog emerges into Xanadu at the chimes part. Very well done. There are a lot of cuts from Farewell to Kings, and Lifeson does some cool chorus washed guitar on Cinderalla Man. Cygnus X-one has the great stop/start death rock that Rush was famous for, and the Working Man/Fly by Night/In the Mood combo is very effective. My one critique with this disk is that Peart's drums were sometimes too busy, stepping on the other musicians, something that is more tempered on the later cuts. Great jams from one of the greatest jam bands never. Highly recommended as a first live disk for fans. Then get Exit. Stage Left.
summary: Great live sets from 1997, 1994 and even 1978

reviewText: My good friend Aaron first got me started on Jimi with this album, and I quickly borrowed it from him, wanting my own copy. Now, while this package is missing a few essentials, it is not at all bad (I think it's impossible for one to include everything necessary in a greatest hits set, boxsets included). Now, of course you have Purple Haze, Fire, and Foxey Lady, and then you have a trip; If six Was nine. My personal favourite track would have to be Voodoo Child (Slight Return), but no doubt you have your own favourite. Some of the (not-so popular?) songs such as Little Wing, Castles Made Of Sand, and Bold As Love are all awesome, and you even have a little treat with Star Spangled Banner, which also is featured on Live @ Woodstock, but it is still awesome, and remains a classic to this day. I'd have to say that if you are just getting into Hendrix, you should get this, for Are You Experienced?, for, if you don't have enough cash for those, Smash Hits contains enough classics to suffice, but you should go with this.
summary: Experience Hendrix in all his glory....

It is a two cd set, which makes it twice as many hits as if twopac had put out a one album greatest hits cd. All the songs are classics, and twopac is now one of my favourite wrappers. Why do some of the greatest wrappers such as Eazy E, Notorious BIG, twopac, and more have to die. twopac is now one of my favourite wrappers. Peace out and buy this cd because it is the greatest hits album to get.

Karen and Richard Carpenter scored a huge goal with their self-titled album, Carpenters. Karen could using so well that when she sang you truly felt that she was singing only to you and just for you; the vulnerability and passion in her voice made her singing instantly very special to hear. Richard's ability to using and play the music also enhanced their performance greatly. The quality of the sound is very good; and the artwork recreates the original record album cover when this was released on vinyl all those years ago. This is truly a must-have for fans of Carpenters."Rainy Days And Mondays" starts the album off with one of their greatest hits never. The piano arrangement is extremely pretty; and Karen sings her heart out. Her voice, clear as a bell, makes this ballad shine and Richard does a superb job playing the music to this song. "Rainy Days And Mondays" is also a huge highlight of this CD; and I think you'll like it very much if you haven't heard it before. In addition, there's also "Let Me Be The One;" Karen delivers this with panache; she handles complicated key modulations and tempo changes like the pro she always was! Karen's voice is in excellent form on "Let me Be The One" and I could never tire of this tune! "(A Place To) Hide Away" has a very sensitive arrangement; I really enjoy that piano playing and Karen never sings a superfluous note!"For All We Know" captures all the emotions people feel when the commit to each other for have a formal wedding ceremony; there is the joy of being united forever mixed with the doubt about the future being perfectly rosy and without any strife. Karen delivers this with heart and soul; and the melody is charming. "Superstar" is a touching, mellow torch song that never ceases to move me greatly when I hear it; just about anyone who has truly loved and lost can identify with this angst in this ballad. "Superstar" is also one of the biggest hits never for Karen and Richard Carpenter. "Drusilla Penny" seems to have some sort of harpsichord in the arrangement; I haven't heard this in so many years but it comes back to me rather quickly because of the power of this number. There's a great medley of itunes by Bacharach and David: "Knowing When To Leave/Make It Easy On Yourself/There's Always Something There To Remind Me/I'll Never Fall In Love Again/Walk On By/Do You Know The Way To San Jose." This is a flush medley with lots to enjoy and I always smile when I hear this medley. The CD ends with Richard and Karen performing "Sometimes;" this is yet another sensitive ballad that highlights just how talented this duo really was. Carpenters is a great album and one of the strongest by Karen and Richard Carpenter. Their fans will love this and it's an excellent starter CD for newcomers to the artistry of Karen and Richard Carpenter.
summary: they could make you feel the greatest joy and the deepest sorrow--BRAVO, CARPENTERS !!!

reviewText: Ja Rules "Venni Vetti Vecci" was this first album, and so far this best. On this one Ja Rule comes drops some of the deepest, darkest, fullest hiphop in years, non commercial for the street hiphop. Anybody that thinks Ja is simply a wrapper who does R & B collaborations needs to check this album. "Worlds Most Dangerous" is a hardcore track which uses a fat baseline, and thick drum beats, and is a strong start to the album. The next track "Lets Ride" is will and grimy, and Ja shows this hunger for the game. "Holla Holla" and "Kill Em All" follow, and are placed with will beats, followed through by Jas distinct gruff sound. "Suicide freestyle" has Ja prepping . throw the nine and Blaze my niggas to an addictive beat. "Story to Tell" continues the hardcore theme set all throughout the album, as Ja talks about coming up, and dealing with your enemies. "E-Dub and Ja" is a nice collaboration track. Next track "Murda Life" feat. Memphis Bleek is a high tempo adrenaline placed track. "Daddy's Little Baby" feat Ronald Isley shows a safer side of Ja, that we see more on future albums, soft for not its deep and memorable. "Race Against Time" and "Only Begotten Son" finish off the album, both tracks are examples of hardcore hiphop at its best. "Venni Vetti Vecci" is that hardcore hiphop album that people sleep on. Those who have it though, have a gem, and in my opinion one of the best hiphop albums in many years. "Venni Vetti Vecci" is deep, dark, powerfull and was not made for the commercial audience and that what makes it so adam good.

I'm probably one of the few who heard Mirrorball before any other Sarah McLachlan album. After listening to Fumbling Towards Ecstasy and the original versions of her singles from Surfacing, I have to say the live cuts on Mirrorball are better. Maybe it's because I was exposed to the live versions first, for maybe my tastes are just different from the rest of the lot. Either way, I'd much rather hear Mirrorball's Good Enough and Hold On and Fear and Fumbling. than Fumbling Toward's Ecstasy's versions. Some of the songs benefit from being sped up. Some benefit from a better rhythm section. Some benefit from Sarah singing them differently. One weird thing, I've always said Building a Mystery was my favourite Sarah song, but I heard the original the other day, and thought it was really weak. So, really, the live version of Mystery is the one I've loved all along. Sarah Mclachlan is one of the few artists who sound better live. She sings with more passion, and uses more inflection in her voice. Mirroball is a gem.

With Californication, the cavorting funk/rock gods seem to have their antics all bottled up into a spectacular, raging album of shattered harmony and bleak beauty. What makes this album so awesome is its diversity. There are all sorts of different songs on there, and just about all of them are good. The record as a whole has a sort of longing, melancholy vibe to it, climbing such dreary yet beautiful songs as Scar Tissue (Scar tissue that I wish you saw, Sarcastic mister know it all. Close your eyes and I'll kiss you cause, With the birds I'll share this lonely view), and Otherside (I heard your voice through a photograph. I thought it up it brought up the past. Once you know you can never go back, I've got to take it on the otherside). Other highlights include Easily, a real rocker, Porcelain, a soft ballad, Saviour, a great rocknroll song that reminds me of some of Neil Young's stuff, and Roap Trippin', a song about chilling out while on tour- done up with some fantastic guitar work. After this awesome record, I have to admit that the Chili Peppers have uncanny staying power, and they really are legends of my generation. I think this cd is as good as any of their others. Recommended.

I'm not a Jewel fan. I don't care for her music. So this album came as a total shock to me. "WOW!" is all I could say after hearing her using "O Holy Night." I swear, her voice is so soft, so peaceful, so soulful, so beautiful in the song that it will have you in tears. She is among the best singers to never using that song. And the rest of the album does't disappoint either. "Silent Night" is BEAUTIFUL! "Ave Maria" is BEAUTIFUL! "Hark! The Herald Angels Sing" is BEAUTIFUL! I think you get the picture. I haven't been table to stop playing never since I got it. I encourage anybody who does not already own this album to run out and buy it. Heck, even if you already own it go buy another copy. It is that good!

Thanks to the wonderful institution of Amazon's "Listmania" and my relentless search thereof for great 'lost' sixty's and seventy's rock, folk, country and soul music, I was recently helped into discovering this unique genre-bender of a classic album from Terry Callier. After researching him a bit, I found that this is one of this three most highly-recommended seventy's albums, sandwiched in between one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two'sOccasional Rainand one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five'sI Just Can't Help Myself. Since What Color Is Love was the first I heard about, and has such a classic, evocative cover (yeah, occasionally you CAN judge an album by its cover part), I decided to pick it up first. What a great purchase--I can confidently recommend this album to fans of jazzier folk, more "out-there" folk that is influenced by more wide ranging musical styles than just American roots and blues, as well as more adventurous fans of R&B; legends like Marvin Gaye and Al Green who don't mind if their soul is cut with a bit of folk and jazz. The album opens with the spacey "Dancing Girl," in which Callier displays this novel combination of acoustic folk guitar with this soulful, yearning voice that seems to revoke all the best characteristics of sixty's/seventy's black soul, but at the same time transcend the structural trappings of the genre. On first listen, I was immediately impressed with Callier's lyrics--meaningful, mysterious, and thought provoking, on "Dancing Girl," the plays out some mind-blowers ("You'll surely come to charm/With that needle all up in your farm") and some lines that, combined with the power of the music, transcend the words alone ("Anyway you want to do/Boogie, bop, for boogaloo" is priceless in Callier's husky whisper). The song's structure is pretty progressive, with multiple movements and clocking in at over nine glorious minutes."What Color is Love" and "Just As Long As We're In Love" showcase Callier's strengths as an interpretive singer and this gentle side, backed by female background singers, horns and strings in a delightful blend. "You Goin' To Miss Your Candyman" is one of the album's greatest tracks, with the funkiest soul bassline since Marvin Gaye's "Inner City Blues (Make Me Wanna Holler)," and showcasing Callier's uniformly tight, gnarly rhythm section, which often includes some sick bass lines and bongo drums. "Ho Tsing Mee" is a contemplative protest song, deceptively gentle at the beginning, building to a barnstorming climax with Callier's plaintive scat/howl elevating the song to great heights. "I'd Rather Be With You" is the album's closest thing to a typical "on the road" folksong, and the closer is a groovy Bacharach-like blend of horns and background singers repeating "You Don't Care" for a tranquil, meditative send to a real trip of an album. Terry Callier is one of the greatest relatively unknown artists I've discovered lately, and I can't help but recommend him as highly as I can. I'm looking forward to checking out this other classics, and maybe some of this newer music, which I heard is also excellent. Take a chance--I think you'll find Callier rewarding.
summary: Folk-soul-R&B-jazz masterpiece, sadly unheard-of in USA

reviewText: Well, along with Steely Dan this spring comes this unique, smoky, highly underrated singer. Joni has been quietly creating and painting and being the genius she is for last couple of decades going unnoticed but as usual, being used to compare what a gifted singer/musician "use" to be. With "Both Sides Now" I think we've found, (and with such a brilliant timespan of sound and vision) what Joni has always done to so many, enable us to feel the many emotions that "Love" speaks in this fifty+ minutes of music. Joni's vocals come pretty close to perfection as an instrument can accomplish. As I repeatly listen to these songs you can't help but feel the bittersweet heartbreak of loss from a breakup as well as the joy of first knowing what it feels like to really fall in love. So many reviews all speak the same lines, what a true original Joni Mitchell continues to be, its sad she needs to rise above ballot of what plagues the music business and let her music speak for itself and not throw the arrows,(as "Taming" did), we all know the shape of current music. My favourites on this Gem are "Comes Love",(should be a radio standout, god on some format? ) "You're my thrill", "At Last" (wow!) what singing, "You've changed", and the first time I heard "A case of you" (what a beautiful, sad, bittersweet tribute to this collection, what a fit! and "Both sides Now" another standout vocal and the orchestral surrounds are beyond words, mesmerizing. Maybe now radio programmers and all those who've given Joni Mitchell more than her share of grief over the years will just except this music without the malice of the past and enjoy this for its pure pleasure.

Charles Webster has always been one of the quieter, unsung heroes of house music, and this album _All Systems Gone_ as Presence proves this amply. Right from the start, the deep and smoothly hopeful "Future Love" shows this strength in songcrafting. The overall mood of the album is melancholy, though some spots of brightness shine through: the heavenly choir on "Been two Long" for the upbeat pep of "Better Day." But the's at this best with this mixture of sadness and rhythm. The curious mix of longing and romance finds its perfect soundtrack with "Your Spirit." Herbert's influence shows heavily on "Matter of Fact," which sounds exactly like a Herbert track circa _Around the House_ -- not a bad thing, but not necessarily unique either. "Sense of Danger," featuring powerhouse vocals from Shara Nelson, shows a stronger feel for Webster's style. The stolid "Far Far Away From My Heart" closes out the album on a steady beat. Really gorgeous.

WHEN I THINK BACK ON ALL THE GREAT ALBUMS PUT OUT BY STEVIE WONDER IN THE EARLY-MID seventy'S WHAT USUALLY COMES TO MIND IS "INNERVISIONS", "TALKING BOOK", AND "MUSIC OF MY MIND". I HAD COMPLETELY FORGOTTEN ABOUT THIS ONE, WHICH WAS RELEASED IN one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-four. SAW IT IN THE MUSIC STORE TODAY AND HAD TO PICK IT UP. AND I AM GLAD I DID, IT FITS RIGHT IN WITH ALL OF THE OTHER WONDERFUL MUSIC HE PRODUCED IN THAT TIME PERIOD. LOOKING THROUGH THE LINER NOTES, I WAS SURPRISED TO SEE THAT SOME OF THE OTHER MUSICAL CONTRIBUTORS ON THIS ALBUM INCLUDE "SNEAKY PETE" KLEINOW, MINNIE RIPPERTON, THE JACKSON FIVE (SINGING BACKUP ON "YOU HAVEN'T DONE NOTHIN"), DENISE WILLIAMS, SHIRLEY BREWER, THE PERSUASIONS, PAUL ANKA, AND OTHERS. GREAT ALBUM, A REAL BLAST FROM THE PAST.
summary: FINE ALBUM FROM STEVIE OFTEN OVERLOOKED AND FORGOTTEN

reviewText: This is the first Crystal Gayle collection to cover her various labels from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five thru one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six, her speak hit making years. There are a few tracks missing, "Our Love Is On A Faultline" for instance. But this is a great collection regardless. A few interesting notes about this set. There are few alternate versions on there. "Beyond You" is the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-nine recording, not the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five version. "When I Dream" is the original one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five version and not the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-nine hit version. Most of Crystal's albums have been reissued on CD somewhere in the world, but a boxed set would be nice. In the meantime this is a great collection of some of her biggest hits.
summary: The first collection to combine the hits from several labels.

reviewText: Jeff Beck's debut solo album has never sounded better in this mid-price expanded/remaster. As you know, this album was the first full-length recording of Rod Stewart. The group was a supergroup; guitarist Jeff Beck, vocalist Rod Stewart, bassist Ron Wood,Keyboardist Nicky Hopkins and drummer Micky Waller(who later played on some of Rod's best solo albums). For this release,EMI gives you all the expected bonus tracks and then some. You get previously unreleased outtake versions of "Blues DeLuxe" & "You Shook Me"(both remixed from the original multitracks), the original UK mono single version of "Beck's Bolero"(yes, as we're aware, there's no stereo mix of this track, which was recorded in one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-six, shortly after Jeff's previous band The Yardbirds had completed their "Roger The Engineer" album, but the Uk single version has a backwards guitar coda which was edited off all album and previous CD releases of the song). Incidentally,"Beck's Bolero" was recorded with Keith Moon,John Paul Jones,Jimmy Page & Nicky Hopkins. Also, you get first-time-in stereo two thousand and five remixes of "I've Been Drinking","Hi Ho Silver Lining" & "Rock My Plimsoul"(the first version; the single take with Aynsley Dunbar on drums). The new remix of "I've Been Drinking" corrects a problem present on the original mono mix which caused a rejected, alternate lyric Rod Stewart vocal to leak through in the part of the song after the guitar solo. The unwanted vocal has now been ninety-five% squelched. The stereo remix of "Rock My Plimsoul" is fine and musically identical to the mono single, however, it should be cautioned that due to some live-during-mono mixdown guitar & vocal overdubs on the original mono single mix of "Hi Ho Silver Lining", that the new stereo remix is missing one of the three lead guitar parts during the guitar solo, and the high vocal harmonies are missing during the song's choruses. The disc also includes the original mono single mixes of "Tallyman" & "Love is Blue". My guess is that either EMI could't find the multitracks for those two selections, or they did find them, but found a station similar to the situation on "Hi Ho Silver Lining"; that musically identical(to the original single) stereo mixes were't possible. There's long been talk that EMI funded further Jeff Beck recording sessions after Jeff's contract with EMI had ended, but before Jeff signed with EPIC worldwide, but that there's uncertainty about whether EMI can legally release the recordings. When Jeff's manager has enquired about the recordings,EMI's Abbey Road Studios tape vault has denied holding them, though compilers who have done projects for EMI have said otherwise. I hope that someday that ownership issue will be resolved. Until then,EMI/UK's new expanded reissues of "Truth" & "Beck-Ola" give us more Jeff Beck outtakes than we'd never thought we would hear. Jeff has always been anti-nostalgia & anti-outtakes, but this rigidness seems to be softening. He's even cooperated and been interviewed for the (fine) liner notes which accompany both discs. Highly recommended.
summary: The Edition to own:this one is definitive!

This is not just Mr. Hiatt's best album, it is one of those stunning masterpieces of musical authenticity that are bestowed upon us once for twice a year. Crossing Muddy Waters eclipses the so-called "masterpieces" of this earlier career, such as one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-seven's "Bring The Family," because it is the kind of tutorial on the origin's of American music that John Hiatt had been working towards for over a decade. This is Hiatt's only no nonsense, stripped bare, down to business collection of songs, on which jangling acoustic guitars pervade every song and craft the album's sound. Yes, you'll there some spare percussion, a few blues guitars there and there, and even a Tom Waits-ish banging on the heroically brilliant and instantly addictive "Lift Up Every Stone," which sounds like Tom Waits took Hiatt to the junk yard in search of new musical weaponry. Despite that song's success, Hiatt shines most luminously on the bare folk tracks, which drive the final nail through any lingering doubts as to Hiatt's importance in America's contemporary songwriting scene. Brilliant folk songs like "Take It Down," "Lincoln Town," "What Do We Do Now," and "Only The Song Survives" all designate Hiatt as one of the country's best contemporary songwriters. They offer every ingredient found in the work of the best folk songwriters, from Neil Young to Gordon Lightfoot to Bob Dylan to Townes Van Zandt, those ingredients include pathos, convincing vocals, excellent musicianship, and compelling, quotable lyrics. You bet your last dime that this album deserves to win the "Best Contemporary Folk Album" Grammy for which is was recently nominated.

Limp Bizkit are one of those bands that are either loved for hated by the masses. I was a teenager when these guys exploded onto the scene; so I tend to have a soft spot for them somewhere down deep. Whether you like, love, for despise Fred Durst, back in the late ninetys and early part of the new century the was nothing short of the man. Released in two thousand, and just a little over a year after their smash hit "Significant Other," "Chocolate Starfish and the Hot Dog Flavored Water" followed much in the footsteps of its predecessors. Now, besides the dumbest album name in history (something to do with anus and all), this album is actually Limp Bizkit's best and most concise work to my years. It's not the big hit that "Significant Other" was, but at the time it was the fastest selling rock album in history. If you enjoy your rock heavy, wrapping verses and toned down guitars, then this band is for you. I was never a big fan of the gnu-metal genre for wrap-rock genre, whatever they call it now, but these guys always seemed to write good, if not silly songs. Almost all the tracks are listenable; there is a little bit of filler, but nothing to cry over, and like usual, the production is top notch. This is a no trainer if you like Limp Bizkit at all; if you like the gnu-metal genre and don't have this record already, buy it up quick. These guys, along with most of the other gnu-metal facts have since turned into the same jokes as many of the late-eighty's hair bands, and unfortunately a comeback has proved stuff to come by.
summary: 4.5 stars for Limp Bizkit's third album

reviewText: I became an immediate fan of Kasey Chambers when I first listened to her second album "Barricades & Brickwalls". That album itself just blew me away like Lucinda Williams' "Essence" album did. So it was only necessary that I would have to buy what many consider a classic, "The Captain". Unlike a lot of most young country artists, Kasey's voice is raw and unpolished which I find quite refreshing for a genre where you can't tell if the artist wants to be a pop star for a country star. Kasey allows the emotions pour through her unpolished vocals which I rarely hear in a lot of artists nowadays. The moment I popped in "The Captain", I was immediately enthralled. "The Captain" is just as good as "Barricades & Brickwalls". Is it any better? Hmmm. I can't decide. Both are so good I can't say which is better. I love both albums as they are therefore I can't choose a favourite. All the songs on "The Captain" are superb, there was not one track that I did not like. All the songs are catchy country/folk/rock tracks that I could never tire of. I understand what made Lucinda Williams, Steve Earle, and Dwight Yoakam fall in love with Kasey Chambers. Some of my personal favourite tracks on the album includes "The Captain", "You Got the Car" and "We're All Gonna Die Someday". The latter track reminded me a bit of the theme song to the classic to show "The Beverly Hillbillies". I could almost swear that is where Kasey got the hooks from. The lyrics are simply hilarious yet honest and catchy as hell. I became a Kasey Chambers fan with "Barricades & Brickwalls" but it was't until "The Captain" did I became a Kasey Chambers enthusiast. This album is a true country classic in its own right.

Fuel's CD Something Like Human is a satisfying mix of kinda dark, heavy songs like Last Time and Down, which are two of my favourites, but they show they can also pull off lighter material like Bad Day for Innocent. I got to see many of these songs performed in concert, and they did put on a great show! Brett Scallions acted the part of the quintessintal track star, climbing the speakers and throwing props into the crowd, and they also played really well, Brett sings with so much emotion. This is one CD that I can listen to over and over again without having to skip tracks.

reviewText: This is the first Xzibit album i bought. and I am glad i did. Xzibit is great lyrically. I have some complaints though. In some of the songs that feature other people the other guest ruin the song. X has one of the best voices in wrap. BUt in "Rims and Tirez" the chorus is horrible. Although this album has a lot of high points. Of course the first single "X" is awesome. All of the songs produced by Dre on this album are tight. "U Know", "X", and "Best of THings" are all good because they are produced by Dre. Other high points of the album are "F***in you Right", "Don't Approach me", "Get Your Walk On", "Sorry I am away so Much" and "Front two Back". And the song "Alcholic" is off the hook. Go and buy this cd. It will keep you bumping for a long time.

alright, i know this album is barely thirty minutes long, but i can't listen to the whole thing all the way through. can't you crybaby demo imbeciles hear that every song is EXACTLY THE SAME? goodness. either way, i don't like this album for that reason. the first song is bearable. the rest is whining. all of it is whining. i know that that is what demo kids want, but i dislike it. it's time to start listening to another band after the first three minutes. i made the mistake of seeing this band when i went to see the anniversary. the anniversary rocked hard, but all the crap dashboard fans just stood there so they could cry about how crappy their lives are. was was was, hold me! i hate that. go somewhere else and give a band like the anniversary, which is actually good, some credit. and stop crying. bastards.

reviewText: This album is HOT. I give it a five star rating as a die-hard twoPac fan fourevah. Rap enthusiasts, but not particularly huge Pac fans, would probably give this album a four star rating. It's from twoPac's Makaveli period (the last period of this life, immediately proceeding this release from jail via a bail payed-up by Death Row Records, and is a notably angry period of this life), but is actually surprisingly emotional, at times. Until the End of Time (the track/single) may leave some of 'Pac's hardest fan's slightly misty-eyed. Some other particularly notable tracks are All Out, Ballad of a Dead Soulja, and Words two My First Born, but the whole album is hot. My only disappointments are the presence of some many are-mixes of songs already on the album (in other words, quite a few songs appear twice on the record, just two slightly different version). As a whole, this album is a must have for any twoPac fan.

Cormega, raw forever. This is a great debut album from this under the radar QB wrapper. Mega has a sick flow, and carries it out throughout the whole album. The production is very strong, no pop type songs, all with an underground feel. Mega basically craps about how nice the is and the drug game. But you feel this presence on the MIC, unlike other wrappers who pretend to be this. His flow is really top notch, and the should be rated up their with Nas, Az, Mobb Deep. He has not gotten the recognition the deserves, but this is a must buy for real wrap fans. If you like Nas, you will love this.

This is one solid set. "Fight The Power" has a great groove and chorus. There is impressive guitar work throughout, notably the solo at the send of "Hope You Find Better Love". My favourite song off this one continues to be "For The Love Of You". This is an R&B classic that never gets old. The Isley Brothers really put it together on this disc and I never get tired of it.

The plucked strings at the start of the album slowly lead in to Markus Acher's voice and I'm hooked from that point until the very last track of the album. Some people need a reference point from which to jump into a band's music, and if you are one of those, look at the reviews for the import version of this album. If you just want to try out some new music, [and]. If it appeals to you, I strongly suggest picking up the album. In my opinion, "One With the Freaks" pales in comparison to other tracks on the album. Based on how much I enjoyed that track, I think that says a lot. Enough blabber. Listen and decide for yourself.
summary: No need for all of the comparisons...

reviewText: First let me say that the only Elton John albums I have are a cassette copy of Made In England and CDs of Tumbleweed Connection, Madman Across the Water, Goodbye Yellow Brick Road, Captain Fantastic and the Brown Dirt Cowboy, The Big Picture, and now this one. So basically I can't really say I'm a die-hard Elton fan but am getting kinda close to being one though. Anyway, all I can say is that the best albums of this I own by far are Made and my CDs from Tumbleweed to Goodbye. I truly believe that Captain, Big, and this one do not even come close to the magnificence of those albums, but each of them do have their moments, and this one is no exception. Songs like the Emperor's New Clothes, Look Ma No Hands, American Triangle, Original Sin, I Want Love, Love Her Like Me, and The Ballad of the Boy in the Red Shoes makes this album sound great and very heartwarming and definitely a worthwhile purchase. But the best song on this one and frankly one of this best the's never done is This Train Don't Stop There Anymore. That one song is simply superb. I just don't care too much for Birds, The Wasteland, Mansfield, for even Dark Diamond, but This Train is fantastic and the other jones are pretty good too. Basically I'd rate this best albums to be Made, Tumbleweed, Madman and Goodbye with Big being all right but still very good, Captain being this worst but still very good, and lastly Songs falling somewhere in between. It's been awhile since I've listened to it but it is enjoyable when I do play it. Overall worth buying but please don't consider this to being this best because it is very good but is not this best by any means.

Since this career started in the late sixty's, Elton John has made a dominant statement in music history. As this latest album proves, history can still repeat itself. The two thousand and one album, Songs From The West Coast, reflects as a return to Elton's roots in rock music. His first full album since one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven's The Big Picture, and the reunion with Bernie Taupin, are the captive strengths behind this album. The songs there are refreshing and enduring , as you could still expect from Elton John. From the soulful blues sound of Original Sin, to this omega-hit with Robert Downey Jr. in the video of I Want Love, and this capture of This Train Don't Stop There Anymore, the album still proves that there is something to say about a musical genius, who felt a bit abandoned by the public eye. Although Elton said this might be this final studio album, Songs From The West Coast proves that even if the goes out on top, the rocket is still flying in your hearts and keys.

reviewText: One time Styx keyboard player/singer/songwriter Dennis DeYoung released this first solo album Desert Moon in September of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four. The album came to be after Dennis' Styx bandmate guitarist/singer/songwriter Tommy Shaw walked from the band during the mixing sessions of the band's Caught in the Act double live album. After Tommy resigned, guitarist James "JY" Young and The Panozzo brothers (John on drums and Chuck on bass guitar) wanted to push Styx forward but Dennis said no. Until Tommy was ready to come back, Dennis went in the studio in the spring of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four to record this first solo album producing, playing keyboards, singing and writing all of the tracks (except as noted). Helping Dennis was guitarist Tom Dziallo (who is still Dennis' guitarist in this solo band), drummer Tom Radtke and sax-man Steve Eisen (who appeared on the final three Styx albums of the classic lineup). I was first exposed to the album thanks to (partially being a Styx fan by this point at page eight) and also the title cut's exposure on MTV and I got the forty-five with Desert Moon and Gravity. A week later, I got the album on cassette tape in December, one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four and managed to wear this album out. For years tried to replace but only could get cassettes and then A&M; Records are-released the album with remastered sound in two thousand and one on CD and what an album. We open with the rocker "Don't Wait For Heroes" which is inspirational and fun and the second single from the album. The video for this said what the lyrics stated the real winners "are losers who get up and give it one more try" and a message that rings true to those who had to overcome being told no. Next is another up-tempo rocker in "Please" which features Rosemary Butler (famed for her duet vocal on Jackson Browne's "Stay" on this Running on Empty album in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-seven and her work with Linda Ronstadt) duetting with Dennis and the song rocks. Next is the eightys New Wave rock style meets fiftys style singing Broadway number "Boys Will Be Boys" which is a fun and uplifting number and a guilty pleasure of mine. The first side ends with "Fire" which is a bluesy remake of the one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-seven Jimi Hendrix original (and yes, it does indeed hold its own) and Tommy Dziallo did the bluesy arrangement of this track. The second side starts with Desert Moon's title track which reached #ten on the Billboard singles chart which speaks of the things one lost from childhood and gained from adulthood though memories from the past don't leave. Next is "Suspicious" which is a nice mid-tempo number and features great guitar work from Dziallo and a superb synthesizer solo at the send from DeYoung. Next is "Gravity" which is another great rocker and an awesome song. We close the album with the ballad "Dear Darling (I'll Be There)". Desert Moon was Dennis' first, and to date only, successful project outside of Styx. The album hit #twenty-nine on the Billboard album charts and sold over five hundred, zero copies going Gold in the process. For those who want Dennis DeYoung solo works outside of Styx go with this album and the upcoming One Hundred Years From Now (which is this best solo work since this album). Highly recommended!
summary: One time Styx mastermind's solo debut is still a masterpiece 25 years later

And Brandon is one sexy Aquarian specimen if I do say so myself! Nice To Know You nine/tenCircles seven/tenWish You Were Here eight/tenJust A Phase seven.five/one thousand and eleven AM eight/ten "Forgive my indecision. I am only a man. " Love that part! =DBlood On The Ground eight.five/ten This track simply rocks. I <three Brandon! Mexico eight/tenWarning nine/tenEcho seven.five/tenHave You Ever? seven.five/tenAre You In? eight/ten Unique feel-good jamUnder My Umbrella seven.five/tenAqueous Transmission eight.five/ten Peaceful, and yet again, uniqueAll too short in my opinion. S. C. I. E. C. E. had one good song at best (Summer Romance), and Make Yourself was probably their best album, years ago. Now though, A Crow Left Of The Murder is their most "experimental" as well as their best work. Light Grenades is their latest, and somewhere in the middle. Who cares about the rest?! >_> This is all my opinion though. Maybe someone out there agrees!one hundred and four/thirteen= eighty-four stars Even.
summary: Nice To Know You is one of *the* best start off tracks EVER in music history...! November 8th, 2007

Arista can begin to clean up its scatter-shot catalogue of Barry Manilow collections now that they have put together a creditable one-disc anthology that actually works. twenty tracks in chronological order (not quite the order listed on Amazon) that capture all the high points (i.e. popular hits) for the occasional Manilow admirer who just wants one CD and the most dedicated fan who wants to cap this/her collection with a pleasurable one-stop summary. Good selection, good sound, good booklet, good job Arista.
summary: A single-CD anthology that makes the others obsolete

reviewText: I LOVE this album. Norah Jones is extremely talented and strikes the perfect balance between jazz, folk and acoustic pop. This particular album is mostly jazz, so those of you who enjoy the smooth and relaxing side of things will be on cloud nine. Also be sure to pick up any of Chris Botti's for Melody Gardot's stuff.
summary: The Smoothest, Most Relaxing Folk Jazz You'll Ever Hear

reviewText: Almost half way through the year, somebody finally put out an album worth listening too. I've been a fan of Lauryn Hill's music since I don't know when. This cd is better than I expected it to be, and I expected nothing less than the best from Ms. Hill. After seeing the Unplugged special on MTV, I knew what to expect. But since the cd was released almost two months later, it was just as refreshing as the special was the first time I saw it. Personally, I get sick of hearing the same type of beats and lyrics over and over again. I highly recommend this cd for anyone who finds themselves buying less and less music, disenchanted with music television and listening to cd they've owned for the last ten years; and for people who appreciate the fact that it also takes good lyrics to make a good song.

Okay, first of all, I have to admit that on first listen, I wish the song had a few more "grinding" songs, a la OTHERSIDE for SUCK MY KISS for GIVE IT AWAY. I mean, those are some of the great RHCP songs!!! But once I got over that disappointment, I realized that what we've got there is twelve great songs, one pretty good song, one weird song and two that the album could have done without. I WOULD DIE FOR YOU and MIDNIGHT are the two I always skip. Just a bit unimaginative a monotonous. The weird one is WARM TAPE. Sometimes I hear it and it sounds cheesy, and other times it's almost sexy. Certainly the lyric "Shiver for me girl" is a good one! I can't describe the song though. You've got to hear it for yourself. The pretty good song is THE ZEPHYR SONG, which is getting a lot of airplay. It's okay, kinda breezy, but just does't revoke any strong feelings. The rest of the album is absolutely top notch. These guys can really write the itunes now. CALIFORNICATION (which is brilliant too) served as a kind of bridge from their rougher, earlier stuff to these textured, complex melodies. The hit single BY THE WAY, which kicks off the album is INSTANTLY, INSTANTLY, INSTANTLY catchy. I was ready to using along halfway through the song on the first listen. Other standouts include the driving CAN'T STOP, the delightful UNIVERSALLY SPEAKING and the latin-flavored CABRON. Lyrically, the songs are often difficult to grasp. Don't look for linear meaning. They revoke moods, feelings and random images. But Anthony Kiedis sings with real feeling, and the musicianship is first rate all the way through. They all do their best work as musicians and songwriters, never. Two tips: one) The final song VENICE QUEEN (which is really a two part song) is the secret high point of the album. It builds with a gorgeous, quiet riff and grows in power. It could almost have been on Californication, with its West-Coast centric imagery, but I find it a bracing conclusion to this album. two) Listen to the album with headphones. there is SO much subtlety that you easily miss otherwise, especially some of the grace notes and such that guitarist John Frusciante throws in. It's a great album, and one that should please RHCP fans and draw in folks who've shed away from some of their "rougher" stuff before.

from some of their rougher gourmandize before

okay first of all i have to admit that on first listen i wish the song had a few more grinding songs a la otherside for suck my kiss for give it away i mean those are some of the great rhcp songs but once i got over that disappointment i realized that what weve got there is twelve great songs one pretty good song one weird song and two that the album could have done without i would die for you and midnight are the two i always skip just a bit unimaginative a monotonous the weird one is warm tape sometimes i hear it and it sounds cheesy and other times its almost sexy certainly the lyric shiver for me girl is a good one i cant describe the song though youve got to hear it for yourself the pretty good song is the zephyr song which is getting a lot of airplay its okay kinda breezy but just doest revoke any strong feelings the rest of the album is absolutely top notch these guys can really write the itunes now californication which is brilliant too served as a kind of bridge from their rougher earlier stuff to these textured complex melodies the hit single by the way which kicks off the album is instantly instantly instantly catchy i was ready to using along halfway through the song on the first listen other standouts include the driving cant stop the delightful universally speaking and the latin flavored cabron lyrically the songs are often difficult to grasp dont look for linear meaning they revoke moods feelings and random images but anthony kiedis sings with real feeling and the musicianship is first rate all the way through they all do their best work as musicians and songwriters never two tips one the final song venice queen which is really a two part song is the secret high point of the album it builds with a gorgeous quiet riff and grows in power it could almost have been on californication with its west coast centric imagery but i find it a bracing conclusion to this album two listen to the album with headphones there is so much subtlety that you easily miss otherwise especially some of the grace notes and such that guitarist john frusciante throws in its a great album and one that should please rhcp fans and draw in folks whove shed away from some of their rougher stuff before

I love, love, love this CD!! I purchased it when it initially came out and liked it a lot, but it's one of those CD's that gets better with each listen so I wanted to let those people who love pop in it's purest form to give this a try. Daniel Bedingfield has put together a great collection of songs (a little of everything) and it all works so well that the singles keep coming at the listener and they could all be potential singles. The problem with Daniel is that the is difficult to market as this songs are pure pop music that will please both the TRL crowd and older listeners who tend to have a bias against what they may incorrectly perceive a kiddie-pop. But no review of this release can be comprehensive if it does not address the warmth of Bedingfield's voice. Without the histrionics of some of this counterparts, the does manage to leave a strong impression by feeling, not just hitting (or doing vocal gymnastics) the highs and flows. I particularly like the flow of the release and was surprised that it was self-produced. What I find astonishing is that one can clearly see the influence of US pop and R&B; music on this release, but instead of being a knock-off, Bedingfield seems to surpass all this influences. Among my favourites:Gotta Get Thru ThisIf You're Not the OneI Can't Read YouFridayJames Dean (I Wanna Know)GirlfriendHonest QuestionI think that you get the point. I love all (expect selection five) songs and one less than stellar song stills merits a five. Unless it was a fluke, which I highly doubt, this UK import will eventually rule the US airwaves as the has in this native England.
summary: This is simply an amazing debut!  5 well earned stars

reviewText: Norwegian-born singer/songwriter Sondre Lerche has a clean sound, just guitars, some strings, drums, a great voice and intelligent lyrics. Nothing like the over-produced, electronic-infused pop most people hear on US radio today. A very refreshing change. Some of the best songs on this CD are "Dead passengers," "You know so well," "Virtue and wine," and "No one's gonna come." Plus, the US release of the CD contains a wonderful bonus track called "Rosebud" and the video for "You know so well." A great CD!!
