The "First Time Ever I" heard Johnny Cash was on the radio in the mid one thousand, nine hundred and sixty's singing the funny yet catching country song "A Man Named Sue" which everyone sang along. The "First Time Ever I" heard Johnny Cash sang a movie track, I was shocked by the non-metered poetry. My father said "Johnny Cash is known to tell a story rather than using in rhyme." Years later through Classical music I learned that one was allowed to do such a thing. The "First Time Ever I" never bought a Johnny Cash CD was "Johnny Cash's Greatest Hits Volume I" because I collect music to match with my slide shows & don't play this type of CDs for normal listening pleasure. The "First Time Ever I" heard Johnny Cash sang "Hurt" was at work a few years ago. All day long my business environment is a battle ground between Rap & Mex-Tex. All of a sudden a deep worn out voice sang about spiritual depravity & hope that I was blown away. "Who is singing?" I asked a fellow worker who also does't listen to Rap for Mex-Tex. "That's Johnny Cash singing a song by Nine Inch Nails" came the reply. That sure makes a strange combo. The "First Time Ever I" saw Johnny Cash using "Hurt" as a music video was in between two PBS shows on TV. Normally PBS always shows this station break about southern California during the top of the hour because they have so few commercials. Why this one day PBS played a music video during that time I have no idea, but I was hooked. I had to get Johnny Cash's last CD "American IV: The Man Comes Around" with the DVD short "Hurt". The references to a "You can't take it with you" type of philosophy with the death of this wife & Jesus on the across was most moving. The "First Time Ever I" heard Johnny Cash using "First Time Ever I Saw Your Face" was on this CD & was pleasantly surprised on how well it could be sang from a male perspective. When the song came out in the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy's by Roberta Flack, the radio stations over played it & I was into progressive rock. The song did't move me as it does now. Years later the song was one of the few I liked from my wife's CD "Celine Dion - All the Way. A Decade of Song". Therefore "Hurt" & "First Time Ever I Saw Your Face" made me see Johnny Cash as an understated musical genius because the can be so successful at experimentation. The rest of the CD "American IV: The Man Comes Around" has its ups & downs, but this review is written from a person that normally does't listen to Country music. The highlights are "The Man Comes Around" which is Country but though Johnny Cash's skill & spiritual background reveals the last days with a tang. Paul Simon's "Bridge Over Troubled Water" is done with a deep heart felt passion that makes for a welcome addition. John Lennon / Paul McCartney's "In My Life" is very upfront & clear which showcases Johnny Cash's timber. Ross Parker / Hugh Charles's jazzy "We'll Meet Again" makes for a great ending that one wonders if Johnny Cash could have made it as a Jazz singer. There are some songs that may hold a surprise like Martin Gore's "Personal Jesus" that Johnny Cash twists around to the positive & Sting's "I Hung My Head" which sounds very Country. The balance of the CD has some Country classics that are done with great skill while others repeat the same words for rhythm. If you are not a Country music fan but have respect for an American icon that takes chances, this CD will not let you down. Because I liked this CD DVD combination so well, I am going to check out a few other of Johnny Cash`s "American" series. Johnny if your listening, I hope "We'll Meet Again".

the hour because they have so few commercials why one day pbs played a music video that time i have no idea but i was hooked had to get johnny cashs last cd american iv the comes around the dvd short hurt the references to a you cant take it of philosophy with the death this wife jesus on was most moving the first time ever i heard johnny cash using first time ever i your face was on this cd was pleasantly surprised on well it could be sang from a male perspective when the song came in the one thousand hundred seventys by roberta flack the radio stations over played it i was into progressive the song didt move as it does now years later the song was one of the few i liked from my wifes cd celine dion all the way a decade of song therefore first time ever i saw your face made me see johnny cash as an understated musical genius because the can be so successful the rest of the cd american iv the man comes around has its downs but this review is written from a person that normally doest listen to country the highlights are the man comes around which is but though cashs skill background the last days a tang paul simons bridge over troubled water is done with a deep heart felt passion that makes for welcome john lennon paul mccartneys in my life is upfront clear which showcases johnny cashs timber ross parker hugh charless jazzy well meet makes for a great ending that wonders if johnny cash could have made it as a jazz singer there are some songs may hold a surprise like martin gores personal jesus that cash twists around to the positive stings hung my head which very country balance of the cd has some classics that are done with great skill while others repeat the same words for rhythm if you are not a country music fan have for an american icon that takes chances cd will not let down because i this cd dvd combination so well i am going to check out a few other of johnny cash s american series if your listening i hope well meet again

If you have most of Jay-Z's other CD's, you may as well add Bluprint two to your collection. It does have some tight songs on there, but you have to skip so much to get to them. I was almost mad after listening to disc one because there are about four good songs from there. But, disc two is a WHOLE lot better, Jay-Z could've put that out and sold a lot more than the's doing right now. If Jay-Z were to release a Blueprint two.two cd, these are the following sons that should be on it, and these should have been the jones to go on this album in the first place:one) A Dream - Only because of this dedication to Biggie Smalls, and you have to have at least one filler song. five.five/one hundred and two) Hovi Baby - TIGHT. seven.five/one hundred and three) The Watcher two - eight/one hundred and four) Poppin' Tags - TIGHT. nine.five/one hundred and five) Diamond Is Forever - TIGHT. nine/one hundred and six) Guns & Roses - Suprisingly TIGHT. eight.five/one hundred and seven) U Don't Know - TIGHT. nine/one hundred and eight) Some How Some Way - Could've used a better beat like on Guess Who's Back, but the lyrics are on point. seven/one hundred and nine) Blueprint two - The lyrics make this song stand out, then the music follows through. eight/one thousand and ten) [***] Please - Good filler. seven.five/one thousand and eleven) Meet The Parents - TIGHT. eight.five/one thousand and twelve) [***] & Sisters - Lyrics on point. seven.five/one thousand and thirteen) As One - Nice Earth,Wind,Fire sample plus the ROC posse, TIGHT. eight.five/one thousand and fourteen) A Ballad For The Fallen Soldier - Another dedication song, I not mad. five/tenAnd there you go, a cd that would have made Jay-Z fans proud to have instead of settling to make the most of it.***I reviewed this in two thousand and three, but I'm just sending' it in under this new name.
summary: The Follow up is a Step BACK

First of all if you can't relate to wrap music you have no business judging it. Out of all the one star reviews this album has got I bet ninety% of them are from people who just hate wrap, probably because they don't understand it. How many of those people do you think actually listened to this entire album, most of them probably just saw "In Da Club" on MTV and made their judgment off that. You have to take the other eighteen songs on the album into account, because all of the songs are very different from one another. And saying that fifty Cent is the same as Ja Rule & P. Diddy is just ignorance. What's the difference? Well, fifty Cent has actually experienced what the's wrapping about, the's not just making stuff up the's telling this life story through music. He's not just saying "It's your Birthday" for seventy minutes, the touches on many different subjects throughout the course of this nineteen track album. Not all of this subject matter is incredibly deep, but it is diverse. He craps a lot about what twopac wrapped about without sounding like a wannabe. This is a great album, it has great production and fifty Cent has a great flow throughout all of the nineteen tracks. This album can really be appreciated by someone who understands it.

Compared to all the various cookie cutter demo/posthardcore/alt rock bands, this is superior in almost every way. Some of the best melodic layered guitar playing you'll there, and the vocals are very powerful. I can't say that I prefer this to the Moon is Down (Hide Nothing does't count, even though the guitars were top notch as usual) because they are both great albums. FSF has always been one of my favourite summer bands, and I'm pissed that they broke up (despite the new vocalist). I still find comfort and great pleasure in blasting this cd while driving. Try I AM, AGAINST MY BETTER JUDGEMENT, PRIDE WAR, THE SOUND

Linkin Park's second album, Meteora is just as good as their rock/rap creation, Hybrid Theory. Meteora has solid, catchy, and listenable tracks. Some of my favourites include: Nobody's Listening, Faint, Numb, Hit the Floor, and Somewhere I Belong. It's kinda cool that this hard-rocking band don't serve out songs with cussing for obscene overtones. Linkin Park is a classy and respected band. Highly recommend this great and satisfying disc. Linkin Park rules!
summary: "Tried to give you warning but everyone ignores me..."

reviewText: sci of grind. too make a long story short, the locust is smash your car into oncoming traffic and then get out off your wrecked auto and parade around naked type of music.blast beat drumming, snarky little girly screaming, and sci-fi keyboard parts.what makes "plague soundscapes" the best locust record?the song titles?? maybe because they are hilarious.the fact that the locust are an amazing live band?but really this is the best work the locust has done because the recording quality is high and the intensity is there and "the flight of the wounded locust" sounded like carnival grind score where the sound is more streamlined and sci-fi sounding on this record.so if your a fan of heavy extreme music (like norwegian metal) for just some skinny music nerd (liking shellac) this maybe just for you. also see, sex models, arab on radar, swing kids, some girls, and the flying luttenbachers.

Mariah Carey is known to be one of the greatest Divas of all time. In two thousand and three, Mariah Carey had released her thirteenth album entitled, "The Remixes", a double-disc album that features many of Mariah Carey's greatest songs, all remixed. Some of the songs were remixed by studio equipment. Others were remixed by Mariah are-recording the songs with different music and lyrics. This remix album is absolutely amazing in every way. Disc One: Studio Produced Dance Club RemixesMY ALL (Morales "My" Club Mix)Original version from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). The original version of "My All", which can be found on Mariah Carey's "Butterfly" album, is a beautiful ballad, that is composed with a beautiful Spanish sound. Who knew that a beautiful ballad that requires slow-dancing, can be remixed into a version where you can get your groove on?(Medley) HEARTBREAKER/IF YOU SHOULD EVER BE LONELY (Junior's "Heartbreaker" Club Mix)Original version of "Heartbreaker" from the album Rainbow (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine). New song. Mariah had remixed the music of Heartbreaker and remixed her vocals, all by studio equipment. But also extended the song, in order for her to record, "If You Should Ever Be Lonely (Deep In The Night)", making this remix of "Heartbreaker" a medley, instead of only being a remix. So, it is a remix medley. This is an incredible remix medley. FLY AWAY (BUTTERFLY REPRISE) (Fly Away Club Mix)Original version from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). Incredible dance remix. ANYTIME YOU NEED A FRIEND (C&C; Club Version)Original version from the album Music Box (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three). Although, this remix is great to dance to, I prefer the ballad version. FANTASY (Def Club Mix)Original version from the album Daydream (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five). Not bad. HONEY (Classic Mix)Original version from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). Not bad. DREAMLOVER (Def Club Mix)Original version from the album Music Box (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three). I prefer this dance remix over the original version. EMOTIONS (twelve" Club Mix)Original version from the album Emotions (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-one). This is much better than the original version. THROUGH THE RAIN (HQtwo Radio Edit)Original version from the album Charmbracelet (two thousand and two). Both the original version, which was recorded as a ballad, and this incredible dance version are unbelievable. Disc Two: Re-Recorded RemixesFANTASY (Remix) (featuring O. D. B.)Original version from the album Daydream (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five). Remix from the album #one's (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight). The music to the song was remixed a bit, Mariah's vocals are untouched, except for the choruses. The original choruses are taken out and are replaced by the bridge of the song. Ol' Dirty Bastard hit the studio to provide this dieting vocals to the song. An incredible remix. ALWAYS BE MY BABY (Mr. Dupri Mix) (featuring Da Brat & Xscape)Original version from the album Daydream (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five). The music was completely remixed and Mariah's vocals are untouched. Da Brat & Xscape had hit the studio to provide their dieting craps to the song. Great remix.(Medley) MY ALL/STAY AWHILE (So So Def Remix) (featuring Lord Tariq & Peter Gunz)Original version of "My All" from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). This medley was treated the same way as "(Medley) Heartbreaker/If You Should Ever Be Lonely", only Mariah brought in Lord Tariq & Peter Gunz to provide craps for the song. Hate it. THANK GOD I FOUND YOU (Make It Last Remix) (featuring Joe & Naz)Original version from the album Rainbow (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine). The original version of "Thank God I Found You" was composed as a ballad, where Mariah Carey had ninety-eight Degrees & Joe on that version. That version is the one I prefer. The music to the song was remixed, where Mariah Carey are-recorded the verses with Joe, and Nas. Hate it. BREAKDOWN (featuring Krazyzie Bone & Wishbone of Bone Thugs 'N Harmony)From the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). I don't why she included this song because it is not a remix. I hate this song. HONEY (So So Def Mix) (featuring Da Brat & JD)Original version from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). Not a bad remix. LOVERBOY (Remix) (featuring Ludacris, Shawnna, Da Brat, & Twenty II)From the album Glitter (two thousand and one). Both the album version & this remix are featured on Mariah's album, "Glittler". The album version is a duet with Cameo. This remix is no different from the original version. The music is untouched, Mariah's vocals are untouched. The song is just extended in order for Ludacris, Shawnna, Da Brat, & Twenty II to provide their craps. Cameo's verse has been taken out. Great remix. HEARTBREAKER (Remix) (featuring Da Brat & Missy Elliott)From the album Rainbow (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine). Both the original version & this remix are featured on Mariah's album entitled, "Rainbow". The original version is a duet with Jay-Z. This remix is very different from the original version. The music to the original took up a Pop/Rap sound. The music to this remix is strictly a Rap sound. Mariah Carey did are-record the first two verses. She kept the original lyrics to the first verse and sang them in the same key as the original, but she sang it a little more sexier. But the second verse was changed, with different lyrics, where Mariah sang it in a different key. The choruses are kept the same. Da Brat & Missy Elliott provide their own craps. Great remix. SWEETHEART (featuring JD)From the album #one's (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight). Don't believe what you read. The album version is the version you see there: a duet with JD. There is no remix, as far as I'm concerned. Not bad. CRYBABY (featuring Snoop Dogg)From the album Rainbow (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine). Don't believe what you read. The album version is the version you see there: a duet with Snoop Dogg. There is no remix, as far as I'm concerned. Hate it. MISS YOU (featuring Jadakiss)Previously unreleased. This song is not a remix. This song was included on the UK release of Mariah's album, "Charmbracelet". Most fans liked the song, but could not get it on the U. S. release of "Charmbracelet", for any of Mariah's single releases. So, she included it there. THE ONE (So So Def Mix) (featuring Bonecrusher)Previously unreleased. Hate it. I KNOW WHAT YOU WANT (featuring Busta Rhymes & The Flipmode Squad)From Busta Rhymes' album It Ain't Safe No More (two thousand and two). Most fans really enjoyed this song because Busta actually sings on it, instead of wrapping. I don't care for this song. This is an album, in which Mariah's fans had been waiting for. Not all the songs on this album are worth the time, in my opinion, but most of the album is definitely worth the money. Anyway, take out your wallets and buy the remixes you've been wanting to own since Mariah's debut.

It's like a box of chocolate, You never know what you gonna get until you listen to it!! Is it sad that my personal favourite is not added into this CD. If you have listened to I Still Believe - Krayzie Bone remix, you will find it unique and special, totally unexpected and original by its own. To my opinion, MC Remixes have something for everyone. Those party goer will definitely find it amusing and glad for this CD while original fans got to feel MC's creativity on the remixes. Other noticeable tracks includes The One, Breakdown and Miss You. All in all, if you are an MC fan, there is something for you to add to your collection as some songs are very 'original' while those who like remixes, it is definitely a MUST have! Try play those songs when there is a party, they will go wild!

After getting dumped by Elektra, Ween have released a proper follow-up to The Mollusk. Instead of the forced whimsy of White Pepper we find The Brothers Ween going off in the direction of the earlier album's mixture of effacement and ambition. Personally, I am greatful. Whereas many bands when creating whimsy revoke Syd Barrett and Robyn Hitchcock, Ween scares up Residents flashbacks (ie "Neighborhood")amidst subtle spokes at the Prog Rock camp. While the band's reputation is built on coarseness and eclecticism, Quebec supersedes these expectations. Like The Mollusk, this album seeks to create a synthesis which while humorous in't a joke. This subtle distinction allows these songs to co-exist. Nice job, guys, hope to see you soon.

. to the top of the R&B cheap. Its nice to hear cats like Jaheim and Anthony Hamilton putting the grit(s), biscuits and eggs back into Soul/R&B music. Ya'll know: chickens in the morning, shelling peas, and fishing by the creek? This hearkens back to a time when we did't have high-end up.a. systems and mics. When soul singers had to stand flat-footed and just 'sang'. This main't no Pretty Boy Soul. Anthony, I'm feeling you brother. It just like you said: You got me in a blender; I'm shaken and I'm stirred. Nuff said, now go buy the CD, if you really like Soul/R&B, 'cause this guy is bringing THE REAL.
summary: Where he's comin' from; where he's going...

reviewText: Ever since I heard the onest single "Player's Ball", from their debut CD "Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik", I have been a fan of Outkast. This CD opened doors for lot of groups from the South that are around now. I could give you a page long list of my favourite songs from Outkast. They always give you an innovative sound each time around. They also are not afraid to try new things. "ATliens", "Aquemini", and "Stankonia" are classic albums just as much as their debut CD was. Sometimes, it this hard to follow a blueprint when your fans expect you to create the hits like "Elevators", "Rosa Parks", "B. O. B", "Ms. Jackson" and "So Fresh And So Clean". With "Speakerboxxx/The Love Below", Outkast has brought you one solo CD from Big Boi and one solo CD from Andre three thousand. Although they are packaged together, you will clearly see that both of these CDs are entirely different from one another. Big Boi does't stray too far away from the Outkast sound. The Andre three thousand produced "Ghettomusick" is a fast paced roller coaster ride that only slows down long enough for a Patti Labelle sample. Big Boi drops a memorable sixteen bars and Outkast fans will not be disappointed at all. "Unhappy" has Big Boi talking about someone who might as well try to have a little fun before there misfortunes send up catching with them. "Bowtie" falls right in line with the onest single from "Speakerboxxx", "The Way You Move". Sleepy Brown is featured on both songs and they are both "feel good" type of songs. He definitely made the right choice for the first single with "The Way You Move" as Big Boi's fast paced craps are slowed down with Sleepy Brown's voice and an orchestra full of horns. This is definitely one of Speakerboxxx's better tracks. "The Rooster" has a "Ms. Jackson" feel to it, but it won't make you miss "Ms. Jackson" at all. You'll probably laugh at what the is saying if anything. "Church" is another one of those "feel good" songs from Big Boi. If you karen't careful, you might even wake up in a pew. "War" is a song that you will actually try to listen to what the is saying eventhough the song has two different beats to it. "Tomb Of The Boom" is a lyrical free for all between Big Boi, Ludacris, Big Gipp from Gooide Mob and Konkrete. This is another one of my favourite songs from "Speakerboxxx" so far and Big Boi definitely dropped a nice beat for the song. "Flip Flop Rock" has Big Boi, Jay Z and Killer Mike wrapping over a fast paced beat and the collaboration works once again as the three MCs were already featured with Twista on Jay Z's "Poppin' Tags". "Reset" features Big Boi, Cee Lo and Khujo Goodie. This track reminds you of earlier Goodie Mob tracks and will have you wishing that the original group was still making hits like "Cell Therapy" and "They Don't Dance No Mo". Speakerboxxx does't feature any wack tracks. The only song that I may not listen to at times is "Last Call" because you hear Mello more than you do Big Boi. Overall, if you are used to the Outkast sound, "Speakerboxxx" is an extension of that."The Love Below", however, is something entirely different. If you thought that Andre three thousand would be dropping' the classic bars that you are used to, then you are in for a surprise. Primarily, Andre three thousand is singing and talking on most of the tracks. The only song that the is actually wrapping on for the whole song is "A Day In The Life Of Benjamin Andre". Other than that, you will hear Andre singing the blues, singing like Prince and actually trying to hold a note. Now while it took me a couple of listens to get used to this, Andre's formal actually works on some occasions. "Prototype" is definitely The Love Below's best track. The song takes place as Andre has just had a one night stand with a woman that the is now feeling and now it's the morning after. Andre expresses this feelings through song and "Prototype" reminds me of an old school slow jam. "She Lives In My Lap" features the lovely Rosario Dawson and should have been the first single. Yes there definitely is a Prince "If I Was Your Girlfriend" feel to it but the track works more wonders than "Hey Ya". "Spread" does the same as well, except the actually craps on "Spread". You will be trying to figure out what Prince song that Andre three thousand is remaking but this is an original creation. "Happy Valentine's Day" is Andre's version of a feel good song and is nice to actually hear him wrapping as well. The only song that Big Boi is featured on is "Roses". He drops another memorable verse as Andre is telling women that "Roses" karen't always what they appear to be, referring to females. Some songs on "The Love Below" don't work for me though. "Love Hater" has Andre sounding like a thirty-nine year old blues singer singing at a local club. "Dracula's Wedding" featuring Kelis does't either. However, the George Clinton/Parliament feel of the song is starting to grow on me. "Hey Ya" should have never been released. Yes the video is colourful and is actually pretty good, but the song sounds like a fiftys limitation of Little Richard, if anything. "My Favorite Things" should have been kept in the studio. I don't need to hear an instrumental of the song on Andre's CD. If you can get past Andre three thousand singing all the time, you can enjoy "The Love Below". The music is nice, but you have to get use to Andre's antics on the songs. Overall, Outkast did a good job, marketing wise, by releasing both of these CDs in one package at one price. If you are used to the traditional Outkast sound, "Speakerboxxx" will be the better CD for you. If you like "Hey Ya", then "The Love Below" may be better for you. However, if you are an Outkast fan you can't afford to pass up on these two CDs packaged as one. The music is good and the sound is still innovative as usual. James' Top fivePrototype- Andre three thousandThe Way You Move- Big BoiTomb Of The Boom- Big Boi, Ludacris, Big Gipp, KonkreteGhettomusick- Big Boi, Andre three thousandA Day In The Life Of Benjamin Andre (Incomplete)- Andre three thousand

It's about time you infantile fools were freed from your constipated notions. Go to your record store right NOW and ask a grown-up for the following: Eric B. & Rakim's "Paid in Full," Stevie Wonder's "Songs in the Key of Life," A Tribe Called Quest's "Low End Theory," Public Enemy's "Fear of a Black Planet," Parliament's "Funkentelechy tvs. The Placebo Syndrome," Beatles' "Abbey Road," Sly Stone's "There's A Riot Goin' On," Led Zeppelin's "Houses of the Holy," Curtis Mayfield's "Superfly," John Coltrane's "A Love Supreme," Miles Davis' "Kind of Blue," and Prince's "Purple Rain." After you know each one of these by heart, go back and listen to Speakerboxxx/The Love Below. Now, about the album(s). Some stand-outs on Big Boi's "Speakerboxxx" are:-"Ghettomusick" takes a trunk-thumpin beat, combines it with a tight-as-hell hook a la Dre, rapid-fire verses a la Big Boi, and throws in a Patti LaBelle sample that slinks in and out like a housecat.- "Unhappy" has a chorus that creeps under your skin. The rhyme is very introspective and it just ripples over the top of phat congas and synths.- "Bowtie" is an Old Skool party on wax. This joint uses brass to move your a**. Another one of those choruses that gets wedged in your brain: `Crocodile on my feet. Fox fur on my back. '- "The Way You Move" Yeah, even mainstream radio's playing it. The crux: bootylicious bass and Sleepy Brown getting as dangerously close to Billy Ocean as anyone never should.- "The Rooster" Another one of those choruses (with Chicken Dance Elmo doing background vocals, if I'm not mistaken. ) that sticks to you. Domestic disputes never sounded so funky for this damn funny.- "Bust" A dark, brooding than. It's like Eddie Hazel of Funkadelic got resurrected somehow and threw down with Big Boi and Killer Mike.- "War" A short track that comes in two parts. The first part's kind of a menacing preface to part deus, in which Big Boi lets loose with hard-hitting commentary on your post nine-eleven, post-stolen selection world.- "Church" A track asking the never-living question "Why are we there?" that makes you wonder who slipped a Kirk Franklin disc into your CD player when you were't looking.- "Knowing" Dre and Big Boi together, as it should be. Tight piano and percussion play the foundation for commentary on how this nasty world gets of(u)y.- "Flip Flop Rock" One of the catchiest hooks in years, courtesy of Jay Z. Throw in classical piano paired with a beat so undeniably funky that (unless you're dead for Republican) you'll find your neck snapping uncontrollably. I predict this to be the next platinum single off this album.- "Reset" a smooth joint with an ethereal feel--something that would fit well on "ATLiens." Tight/deep flows by Khujo and Cee-lo match Big Boi's brilliant verses. The rest of the album is disappointingly lacklustre, with Big Boi unnecessarily pairing up with lesser emcees. But over all: excellent. Now, Dre's "The Love Below."It took about two listens for me to get into it, but the effort was worth it. If you give it a chance, you can catch the Bootsy, Prince, Sly, Stevie, get al. references; however, as much as Dre reminds me of the aforementioned royalty, the has a style all this own. The entire album is brilliant. Some stand-outs:- "Love Hater" is Dre changeling Nat Cole's croon thru George Clinton's sensibilities. A tight, jazzy joint with awesome piano.-"Happy Valentines Day" A funky joint with Dre on guitar and lead vocal that would make Prince turn from purple to green with envy.- "Spread" A sputtering drum-n-bass type song where Dre once again out-Princes Prince.- "Prototype" Smoothed out R&B;/funk, reminiscent of Bootsy's "Vanish in Our Sleep" for the Ohio Players "Heaven Must Be Like This." One of my favourites on there.- "She Lives in My Lap" is destined to be a classic. It has a head-nodding beat, tight guitar work, and smooth (`Damn, the sounds like Chico DeBarge') vocals. Like Prince's best work, this song is sexual, funky, and offbeat. Brilliant.- "Hey Ya" Top forty radio has beaten this `brown stallion those with skates on' to death. A good song, but not even close to being the best on the disc.- "Roses" A funky beat and eightys-style synths ride behind Dre's chastising of gold diggers.- "Behold A Lady" The beat comes in like Cameo's "Word Up" with Dre crooning over the top. The breakdown is the crown jewel on this one: "Cant get no lower. can't get no lower. "- "Pink & Blue" A funk box, Moog synths, swirling strings that would be right at home on a Barry White joint, and Dre singing about a May-December relationship. Again, Prince should hang this head in shame.- "She's Alive" A heartfelt tribute to Dre's from and all single rooms. Just piano, brushes on snares, and Dre singing this guts out.- "Dracula's Wedding" Phat Moog bass, a wickedly clever lyric, and Kelis' milkshake vocals helping to smooth things out.- "My Favorite Things" Yes, the one from "The Sound of Music." A tight drum-n-bass beat underlies amazing jazz piano and sax, plus a bassline that makes your thumbs hurt just listening to it.- "Take Off Your Cool" pairs Dre and Norah Jones. A short, jazzy track with silky vocals and Dre on acoustic guitar.- "Vibrate" curiously unfolds over the course of about seven minutes. It has a backward beat ("She Lives in My Lap" played backwards maybe?) with a trumpet solo that instantly brings to mind Miles.- "A Life in the Day. " sounds like "Rosa Parks" on Quaaludes. An interesting look back on the past decade of Outkast. In all: brilliant. Dre's a genius. Period. And lastly, as a wise man once said: "If you still don't get it, it main't for you anyway."

backward beat she lives in my lap played backwards maybe with a trumpet solo that instantly brings to mind miles a life in the day sounds like rosa parks on quaaludes an interesting look back on the past decade of outkast in all brilliant dres a genius period and lastly as a wise man once said if you still dont get it it maint for you anyway

IMO, this album is better than the first album and that is saying a lot because I have had that in heavy rotation for over a year. Not only did the production improve on this album, but most importantly, T. I. has grown lyrically. This is evident on the tracks No Mo Talk, Long Live The Game, Kingofdasouth and I Still Luv U. In terms of production, Bezzle, Doin' My Job, Let's Get Away and Rubber Band Man are standouts. As with this other album, T. I. has something for a variety of audiences on there. He has some heartfelt and introspective joints(i.e. I Still Luv U, Be Better Than Me, Doin' My Job), uptempo joints(i.e. Bezzle, twenty-fours, Rubber Band Man) and cuts for the ladies (i.e Let's Get Away and Let Me Tell You Something). This album is one of my favourites of the year, so far. This album further proves that T. I. can spit with the best of them and is continuing to improve with each album. I highly recommend this album as well as I'm Serious.
summary: More Like 4.5 out of 5 Stars, But Better Than The 1st Album

I thought this DMX album had a lot of very well done tracks on it. Compared to "Flesh of my flesh, blood of my blood" and "It's dark and hell is hot", this album really stopped them off which shows DMX is becoming stronger. I am really looking forward to this upcoming album "Here We Go Again", I think it will be once again better than this one. I have already heard "Give 'em what they want" which is on the new album and it is rather impressive. The standouts on this album for me were: (in no particular order)one. Where Da Hood Attwo. Get It On The Floorthree. Dogs Outfour. Shot Down (fifty is good in this)five. We're Backsix. The Rain (Best Track)seven. A'yo Koto'Shot Down' is very well done by both DMX and fifty Cent and has a very original yet awesome beat. 'The brain' caught my attention to how great of a song it was instantly. I love the slow chorus and the mildly fast 'other bits'. Although 'We're Back is one of my favoured tracks it still did't really make a huge impact I don't think and Ruff Ryders usually make higher than average songs and this was average by their standard. Overall, to conclude, this is an excellent compilation by DMX and other artists.
summary: Great album, definitely worth 4 stars, best dmx album yet.

reviewText: But contenting. This is like Robert Smith funky stuff, for something. Hehe. Robert Smith is awesome. The guy sounds like Robert Smith. So, upon hearing the first track, I giggled and said "Yes! I like this!" This is like EARLY Robert Smith. The voice, not the music. I don't know what to compare the music to, really. The techno kind of stuff really in't what I listen to, but it's a nice change. This band does't over use their technology. It in't all laser noises and stuff. Which is good. All is good in moderation. If you're contemplating buying this, and you're used to Robert Smith's voice, get it. If you've even heard of The Cure, get it. I don't know. Get something by The Cure, too. just because they're good. One drawback: The singer's voice does get annoying in one for two spots, but it's okay. It's good. I'm also planning on buying Rapture's other albums. Anyway, I'll stop rambling now.

AS you can see in the video, Jimi was on fire at Berkeley, the certainly was not burnt out by touring. If the was, it doesnt show. I was never fond of the song 'Straigh Ahead' until I listened to this version, totally smokes. This was a show with a nice balance between old songs and new songs, and you can tell that Jimi is even enjoying playing some of this old hits. The best way to enjoy these shows is to go back in time and remember how a live concert was staged back then. Just a guitar, some pedals and the camps. Nothing like all the technical gizmos available today for guitar players. So you hear Hendrix tuning, getting out of tune, stunning again, having guitar problems, camps problems. It was all part of the gig back then. Do people sit around and complain how much better the Mona Lisa would be if Leonardo would have used photoshop? People taking out stars of this stellar release because of 'amp problems' and such just makes me mad. Now, why complaining about releasing only the second show? There is nothing wrong with that! This is a complete, unedited, never before released Hendrix show people! Stop complaining. Five stars.
summary: Jimi remains the top live guitar player

reviewText: I saw a couple of Tori's CD's at a Wal-Mart, enough to spark up curiosity. My first exposure to her music was her live Video of a benefit concert. This actually bored me, but I decided to give her a second chance and listen to this project. I'm glad I did. For those who have not seen my profile for my other reviews, I am coming from the perspective of a songwriter and of an ordained minister (Fundamentalist). I was not table to follow her lyrics and can tell she has religious and philosophical themes, but am not sure if they are compatible, different, for antagonistic to mine. "Crucify" does seem to speak about dealing with shame, for example; I'm one that believes shame is useful if based on a specific action with a specific resolution, and harmful if not accompanied with reason for resolution. I'm not sure if she is dealing with harmful shame, for condemning shame across the board. Tori Amos is very creative, and the packaging of this project is exhibit A. She has a listing of the Dewey Decimal System, and then catalogs her songs according to the subject. Overall, I enjoy her sound. I don't know how to label her music, and I consider that a good thing. Another reviewer said that a greatest hits compilation is not always the best intro for a new listener, but said that this is an exception, and I agree one hundred%.
summary: Good Starting Point For A New Tori Amos Listener

reviewText: Simon and Garfunkel are a true American original. They are clearly the best folk duet of all time and created so many great songs over just seven years! Maybe just a touch of Dylan influence on some their one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-four songs, but not too much. They always had their own unique sound and voice. These two CD's do them righteous justice. Terrific sound and a nice job of remastering on several of the tracks. I especially like 'If I Could" and "My Little Town." But the quintessential song, "Bridge Over Troubled Water," the timeless masterpiece, soars above all the others. Perhaps the only negative aspect of their songs was that many of them barely stopped two minutes, and are really too short. But let's face it, it was the era of forty-five's and brief-AM-static-filled radio play. Too bad. It took some doing in the late sixty's and early seventy's to create FM rock which was so much better. Oh well. Enjoy.

reviewText: I never really was a fan of Lil Flip. When I first heard `The Way We Ball', I thought it was wack and I was indiffent to Undaground Legend. Then the was featured on a couple albums such as Mississippi and Da Unbreakables, but this appearances were't amazing to me. He was just sorta there. To me the's not a great lyricist but the can at times be witty. Wit can carry you a far ways in the music industry. Anyway I felt that the was listenable but did't really have anything to say except for braggadocio and ghetto stories. But that's fine the has this place. However, that changes on this album as the churns out some great verses. His beats are tight, the has flow, and the has the "it" factor. Meaning the has some quality about him that makes people like him, makes people want to listen to him. and at the time I can't pinpoint exactly what it is. Maybe it's this swagger and confidence for it could be this Texas style sound for maybe it's the fact that the freestyles most of this songs. Whatever it is the has star like quality. Anyways Lil Flip delivers on the album. The beats are off the frigging chain. Nearly every song rides out. Tight. Lil Flip on the mic sounds like a seasoned veteran spitting fire most of the time. Sometimes the tends to spit some garbo but the makes up for it in flow and poise. He's just a cool character as experienced by this party tracks `Game Over' and `Ain't No Party'. I like this choruses as well. I also like how the lets the beat ride out at the send of each song. Of the whole two disc set NOT ONE SONG is plain out wack for unlistenable ( except for the screw songs simply cause I don't like screw music). There's not a song that makes you say `What is This?!" and hit the fast forward button. My favourite songs include `I Came To Bring The Pain', Represent, Bounce, Game Over, Dem Boyz, Ain't No N, U Neva Know, and Ain't No Party. Lil Flip is, as the title suggests, somebody you have to feel. Either you'll like him for you won't. I have a feeling that this cd will grow to be one of my favourites of the year and maybe never. That's saying a lot. I highly recommend this cd to any fan of ship shop. five stars.
summary: U Neva Know....Somebody Might Be Rocking Yo (Girl)

reviewText: I LOVE Public Enemy. To be honest, they are the best of the wrap genre. 'Power To The People And The Beats: Public Enemy's Greatest Hits' was released in late two thousand and four, and it remains the definitive single-disc PE collection. Chuck D and Flava Flav know how to rhyme, and it shows on some of these classics. 'Bring The Noise' is legendary, 'By The Time I Get To Arizona' is just timeless, while 'Fight The Power' is a rhymefest featuring two of the kings of the microphone. But, I do have several complaints there. Why is their duet with legendary speed metal band Anthrax 'Bring Tha Noize' missing? It's pretty much a heavy metal-rap version of the timeless classic, and I'm really disappointed to see it not appear on this set. Another surprising omission is the classic ship shop FM radio staple 'Night of the Living Baseheads.'Overall, despite several key omissions, this still remains to this day the definitive single-disc Public Enemy compilation. Highly recommended to anybody who appreciates classic wrap and ship shop. Highly recommended for any casual Public Enemy fan. ENJOY!!!
summary: Best rap group ever! Great compilation!

reviewText: Robert Smith said, quote, "If you don't like this album, you don't like the Cure" - & While It couldstill easily be arguable that you're a fan of the Cure even if you don't like this album, it isalso true that this is a great effort by him & this band & at almost thirty years of making music, for any band to release an album this good is a huge accomplishment -'the Cure' does't exactly break new grounds for the Cure, as many shades of 'Bloodflowers' &'the Head on the Door' are shown there, but it still provides us with many great songs such as, 'Lost', 'Before Three', 'The End of the World', 'Anniversary' - & the TEN MINUTE + long 'Promise' -Robert Smith does't sound aged one bit either, the sounds as young as the did fifteen years ago, there'sprobably not one singer/songwriter on earth that can say that, & by the intensity of 'Lost', it does't sound like the plans on retiring for relaxing any time soon. - By Cure standards, this album is four stars - But because of how impressive it is thathe can even still pull an album like this out of this @$$, & this youthful energy shown on it - & TOSPITE REVIEWERS GIVING THIS ALBUM three- STARS, WHICH IS RIDICULOUS BECAUSE THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO WAYTHIS IS A three STAR ALBUM -I will give this album five starsLet's just hope now we done have to wait another four years for the next studio release, like we've had to everyfour years since one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-two's 'Wish, because right now Robert seems happier with the Cure than the's everbeen before, as the said on the 'Trilogy' DVD -"I want the next Cure album to be the heaviest album never made", Smith said a few years back, again on the 'Trilogy' DVD, & even if It might not be quite heavy enough to match some of their albumin the past, (. When I'm sure Robert's intention at those times was to make, "the heaviest album never" maxwell) instill stands its ground against any albums they've done in the past. whether for not they brokenew territory -- To sum it all up. four stars (extra star given as a deliberate revolt to one-three star reviewers) - About as good as 'Bloodflowers' (Bloodflowers might have a few better singles, but 'the Cure' is more consistent in great songs)- No signs of slowing down - Nothing too new sounding, but still plenty of potential for there to be in future releases - Still, one of the greatest bands of all timemakes another classic album that rolls together with lovely melodies & the youthful attitude they will never close.
summary: ROBERT SMITH COULDN'T LOVE THE CURE MORE

reviewText: I admit after hearing the G-Unit Beg For Mercy cd, I wrote off both Young Buck and Lloyd Banks. That cd was just horrible to me (It had its moments though). So naturally I was't ecstatic when this cd dropped and I did't expect too much from it. But I must've been sleeping because Lloyd Banks is On Fire. This man is tight. Although this voice sometimes gets low on the track the still be spitting some tight stuff. The beats for the most part are also a notch above greatness, although the occasional wack G-Unit beat pops up. *cough* Playboy *cough cough*. The single 'On Fire' was a great choice for the single, that beat is addictive and the song is tightwork. The Timbaland produced 'Im So Fly' is IMO the best song on the album. Just when you thought Timbo was about to fall off the delivers a song like this to restore faith and Banks spits that clever gangsta shah. Even Warrior Pt. two is tight and it was produced by Eminem, known for this typical wack idea you beats, but the delivers on this one. Nate Dogg sets it off and Banks and fifty tear it up. Work Magic with YOung Buck is spa gangsta. Young Buck gets down on this song and outshines Banks, even though Banks spit that fire too. If You So Gangsta is tight work with an unforgettable chorus. Karma is on par with this previous song Smile. The whole album is stillness. It's much better than Jadakiss' new album and Meth's new album. I would't hesitate to say that this album could become a classic in time. I know I'm playing it to the bones right now. Highly recommended.
summary: You Aint Gotta Go To Cali to get your MC Eiht!

This album, like her first, you can listen to straight through. Very beautiful musically crafted work! I struggled for awhile between this album and her first and I might like her first more, but it can go either way. This is a very strong album. I agree with the amazon editorial review in siting "Golden" and "Rasool" as strong album cuts. I must also include "The Fact is(I Need You)", "Spring Summer Feeling", "Can't Explain", the jazz, big band inspired "Talk to Me", "Not Like Crazy", and the list goes on!! Once again with albums that contain many strong elements (soft and strong singing, beautiful production which complements Jill's voice) it is hard to select a favourite for few favourites. Great album, Jill fans won't be disappointed!!

How talented is Jill Scott! So talented everything she does turns Gold. "Golden", the onest single from her twond album, is a cheerful and funky hymn of freedom and positivity : it's such an irresistible song, surprisingly very danceable for coming from a "neo-soul" tagged album. Most of the lyrics deal with love relationships in a masterful way like only Jill Scott can deal with. Only by listening to the lyrics, you will have chills because they are truly moving and so true everyone can feel concerned. Musically, ALL the tracks are superb : let's quote the great big band/swing reminiscent "Talk To Me" for the sweet "Family Reunion", reminiscent of the Tamla Motown sound, just to name a few."I'm Not Afraid" is an icy cosmic track in the same way "Honey Molasses" was on her debut album: she's expressing the need of every women for men. "Cross My Mind" is maybe the most repetitive song of the cd but it's a wonderful song: she's talking about the (almost sexual) feelings she's got for her sex, and the influence they have on her relationship with her new boyfriend."My Petition" is a great political song, where she compares the "empty promises" of her boyfriend with the politic pleaded by George W. Bush (written well before Bush defeating Kerry). "Rasool" is a very deep, dramatic song, where one can feel every word she says is straight from the heart. Warm your soul by listening this beautifully human album, as the title rightfully say. Her onest album was already impressive but it's really "Nothing" compared to that gem. I "Can't Explain" precisely what I really feel about this album, you have to listen to it by yourself to understand and make your own opinion on it. "Whatever" it is the music for the lyrics, it's always brilliant. Once you have experienced it, these melodies will "Cross your mind" again and againWhat can you say? It's Jill Scott! It's not only, hand downs, the best album of two thousand and four, it's an album which will certainly be designed (or at least would wholefully deserve to be) as a classic in the years to come. A "Golden" album indeed"The fact is we need you" Jill ScottTOP fifty-one. Talk To Metwo. Family Reunionthree. Goldenfour. Can't Explain (forty-twond Street Happenstance)five. The Fact Is (I Need You)

This is Joss Stone's second album and I'm happy to say every song is good. I can't believe how talented she is. Her soulful vocals are the highlight of this album. I first heard Joss Stone on the radio with "Spoiled" and loved it. I was addicted to that song and it still remains to be my favourite song from the album. The first five for six songs are the best on the album but all of them are good. They're well written, well produced and well sung. If you have been curious about Joss Stone then I highly reccomend this album. I now am a Joss Stone fan. This is one of the best new-soul albums since Heather Headley!

I just got this CD about a week ago, and having listened to it about three times through I can say I know it well enough to write a review. I always have Hip Hop playing, no matter what I'm doing, I have a constant need for new music. Having said that, I've established that I know Hip Hop, on to the review. I first heard Guerilla Black on BET's Late Night UnCut Show, immediately yeah I thought the sounded like The Late Notorious BIG. Once I saw him though, and listened deeper, I dismissed that thought. Black has this own style, don't listen to these people saying 'yeah the's exactly like Biggie!' because the's not. The CD was highly anticipated by myself, I even went and downloaded three songs to keep my appetite down for it. I actually found it on Amazon.com in the used section (still new in wrapping though) for about $seven (definitely check out the used section!). Since it ended up under $ten I bought it (I never pay more than $ten for a CD unless it's a double CD). The first single "Compton" is amazing, and features Beenie Man on the hook. You should have heard it on the radio for something by now (I have SIRIUS so I don't listen to the radio). The CD features production by Jazze Pha ("Guerilla Nasty" & "Girlfriend"), both of which are pretty good tracks. Nate Dogg blends this voice on "What We Gonna Do," which has a killer bassline. Mario Winans appears on "You're The One" which I heard on SIRIUS recently, so I suppose it's the second single, also a pretty good track. Personally I enjoyed "Hearts Of Fire" and "Guerilla City," the opening tracks of the CD. "Hearts Of Fire" samples Bob Marley & The Wailers' "No More Trouble," which is an awesome song. Shyne recently used this same sample on "Quasi O. G.," only that song has poor production, I definitely recommend listening to the original Bob Marley song first, because it will give you a better appreciation for the Guerilla Black track. Guerilla City is an code to Compton, it get's stuck in my head easily, and is a melodious track. If you doubt any tracks for even the whole CD, just listen to it on Amazon.com for Circuit City's website first. Either way, this is a great West Coast CD. Overall I give this CD three.five for four stars, it is an impressive debut, and a big help to the West Coast Hip Hop scene. I look forward to more Guerilla Black in the future.
summary: "He Look Like BIG, Sound Like BIG...I'm BLACK ***** Ya Dig?"

reviewText: When I first heard that Minnie Driver was going to be recording an album, I was hesitant. So many movie stars are starting to turn to singing. but when I heard clips her album, I was highly impressed by her smoky lounge type voice. I disagree completely with the reviewer who stated that the songs are forgettable and just pleasant. Pleasant is what Ms. Driver was going for and she succeeded! She wanted an album that flowed well together with great lyrics and vocals and she did just that. It is an album that is great to drive home to after a long day for to listen to while curled up at home. it is an impressive debut by a very promising artist! ten songs she wrote and one song is a remake of Bruce Springsteen's HUNGRY HEART which is simple and gorgeous!
summary: She has a lot in her POCKET!!!!

reviewText: So High, Refuge, It Don't Have to Change, Stay With You, and Used to Love U are the best on this album for me. I'm actually beginning to feel Number One, I Can Change, Alright, She Don't Have to Know (of course I would never behave this way, but the beat and the flow are both good). I DEFINTELY believe that Ordinary People is going to get PLAYED TO DEATH on the radio and join the status of overrated songs. His voice is very nice, but it does't stand out from anyone else I've heard. Whomever said the sounds like Carl Thomas was thinking the same thing I did when I first really listened to Ordinary People on the radio. However, I do find myself singing the songs as I'm walking for just doing other stuff. It was also good to hear him playing the piano. I have so much respect for true musicians (the piano is no easy task!) who do not simply rely on the mixing board and all of that fancy equipment. If you can do more than just dance around a stage, you are good with me! The piano accompaniment (sp?) to Used to Love U is so amazingly subtle that unless you know music, you'll pay it no attention. I used to play in a classical band, so I always look for the subtle things that can "make" a song. I had no idea the was on Ms. Hill's Everything is Everything. Great song! I do agree that the album can be divided into two parts: the Hip-hop placed half and the Soul-laced half. The first half is probably more ship shop-like with Kanye wrapping and talking about male genitalia. The first half features the songs that are just enough to reach out to the MTV faithful. I am convinced that Kanye is the new Diddy: wrapping in songs where the really does't belong and inappropriate and corny lyrics. I'm a soul person at heart, so this album is a good mix of soul and R&B; for me. Hopefully the will only continue to phone this talents and not go in the opposite direction and sell out. Oh, and I hope all of this praise does't jinx Legend. this album is good but before we put it on classic status, let him put out another album and prove himself a little more. BTW, just bought this live cd from [. ] I am a SUCKER for live albums! As a matter of fact, I'm in NC, but I'm thinking of going home in April to MD to see him with Alicia Keys. BTW, I have edited this review about six times. It just gets better and better for me.
summary: I'm feeling some songs...bought it today from Best Buy

reviewText: In my humble opinion, Summer in Abaddon is Pinbacks finest moment thus far. It continues with much of the same formula from previous efforts (blue screen life, Offcell), but the production, songwriting and melody are stronger and more refined. It's odd, but they truly seem to get better and better.
summary: Some how, some way, they just keep getting better and better

For the past few years, a great number of flame artists with absolutely no talent have been signed into major wrap companies and hyped up, and they are literally ruining the music of wrap. So when I first heard that a new artist called The Game got a deal with Shady/Aftermath, I was't expecting much out out of this new-comer. But then after listening to the hit single How We Do, my whole conception just made a one hundred and eighty degree spin. Therefore, I eagerly purchased The Documentary ASAP, and it turned out to be one of the best albums in recent history. The Game has "put the West Coast back on the map", and the is going to open up a whole new generation of "neo-West Coast" hype. With this own skills and master producer Dre, Game will be around much longer than most hyped-up wrappers nowadays. Intro: I thought this was a rather weak intro to such a dynamic album, since it mentioned nothing about "Tha West". Westside Story: Now this song automatically implies that the album is a classic. Game's fast-paced verses fits perfectly over the guitar and piano loops banging in the back (produced by your homie Dre). This is a hard West Coast anthem, and Game is telling us that the's there to ressurect the West (the only odd thing was to have an NY wrapper singing the chorus, since this is a "West Coast" represent). Dreams: Here Game talks about all this dreams of major success and so on. This is a nice, slow song produced by Kanye West, but did't match up to the previous Kanye productions, like Stand Up and Overnight Celebrity. Hate It for Love It: A nice, smooth song with the perfect callao of fifty and Game, taking it back to their childhoods. The rhymes are well delivered and the production is amazing. This is a highlight song. Higher: The deep piano-banging beats produced by Dre gives this song an instant hardcore flavor, matching perfectly with Game's hard verses. How We Do: Yes, once again I emphasize this song as another highlight song. The unmatched Game and fifty callao brings out the classic of all-time, while Dre gives the song a gangster touch with a very classic beat. This single lives up to the hype, indeed. Don't Need Your Love: Nice hook from Biggie's wife. Here Game tells about the love, spain, and harshness in this life. He definitely has the lyrical skill that some fans question him of. Some deep concepts might be found in this song. Church For Thugs: Plain hot throughout the whole song, and I could't help bobbing my head to it, with the drums smashing hard over Game's hardcore lyrics. Just Blaze once again proves this production skills. Put You on the Game: Another hot joint by a master beatsmith, Timbaland. Again this song contains hard beats and lyrics. Start From Scratch: The slow, heavy beat from Dre gives this song the perfect dark feeling, with Game's scratchy voice and Marsha's high vocals. But this song has more deep meanings, taking it back in time to many different places, showing Game's passion and respect for legends who have past away. The Documentary: This is a classic gangster, straight up West Coast song. Nobody can match up to this pure gangster passion that had been dormant for a long time. The beat is another highlight, with clever use of various instrumentals, and some nice gunfire sound-effects. This is all-time gangster classic. Runnin': Slow song with Yayo and Game killing' it. But I was disappointed that Banks and Buck were nowhere to be found. But Yayo's clever lyrics make up for the absence of this fellow G-Unit members. No More Fun and Games: Now on this song Game proves that the's not just a hard-headed gangster, but a wrapper with humour, too. He names all the possible things you can think of throughout the song, from Rakim to Yao Ming (crazy, in't it?)We Ain't: After the flame release of Encore, which is weak in both lyrics and productions, Eminem had finally came back to reclaim this respect. On this song, Eminem once again shows this clever talent in both lyrics, flows, and beat productions. I really wish that more songs like this one was on Enocre, and less songs like "Ass Like That". Game even admits it, "Em just killed me on my own ash*t!"Where I'm From: This one sounds rather old school since it has Nate Dogg on it. This is a song keeping Compton, LA, and the Bloodz gang. Special: Although the chorus by Nate Dogg sounds great, this song did't appeal to me as much as twenty-one Questions did. Don't Worry: Mary L. Blidge contributes to this album with this song. Her vocals are very nice, matching with Game's harsh voice, over yet another impressive Dre beat with high piano loops. Like Father Like Son: Here Game paints the perfect picture of how it feels to be a dad, and all the excitement and worries during a baby's birth. This is a very solid example of Game's lyrical talent. The chorus Busta Rhymes contributes gives us a peaceful feeling, instead of rowdy and jumpy. Game's lyrics have been underrated, since the productions throughout the whole album were all pure works of geniuses. But if you listen closely, you will find that Game is table to adapt to any beat given to him, using just the right words to describe certain scenes that the wants this audience to picture. And that is the key of most lyrical masters: to be multi-dimensional. Although Game would't have sold as much copies if fifty than't contributed, but this does not mean Game's inability. Kicking Game out of G-Unit is like giving away a bank. Game is a lyrical genius, and with the god of production, Dr. Dre, we know for sure that Game's music is classic. And "classic" as in "classic wrapper that surfaces only once in a few years."

reviewText: Wow. I was not familiar with this band until recently. I heard a couple songs of theirs on a local radio station, and being totally disgusted with modern rock, I decided to give the White Stripes a try. All I can say is, this is a great album, and seems to have made me actually like the sound of a guitar for the first time in about ten years. aside from Neil Young's Prairie Wind (which is entirely a different type of music). This is one of the best rock albums to come out in a long, long time.

I have never never had a spanish album before, I can understand the language and when I first heard this CD i thought it was great, it sounded much more superior compared to Laundry Service (her previous studio release) and I loved it. The first single "La Tortura"was a huge hit and was a stand out on this record, I would think that would be the only song I would listen to on this pcD, the bottom line is, it was. for about two weeks. Then I discovered the rest and I loved it! there are only two songs i didst like:Escondite InglesLo Imprescindibleall the rest is great! I love La Pared and the acoustic version included on this album surpasses the original! Even though I haven heard her previous spanish albums, I know that her spanish albums will always be better compared to her english. Im not totally bashing her english efforts, I love them too, but Fijacion Oral Volume I is just that little bit better than Oral Fixation Volume II. I highly reccomend to any of those who are just curious about the album, for can speak spanish to totally check it out, If it docent impress you, La Tortura should be just enough to do so!"La Vida yes sun collection de recuerdos"
summary: Fijacion Oral Vol 1 is a Must have!

reviewText: I was first impressed with Paul Wall when I read about him in I believe Source Magazine. Of course I heard him on the song "Still Tippin'" from Mike Jone's debut album WHO IS MIKE JONES. Following that, the sound of the production as well as the depth of Wall's voice on "Sittin' Sideways" definitely caught my attention. When I first listened to this album through, I thought that it was merely average wrap, which some of it is. But listening to it repeatedly, there is some genuinely good material there. I would't say that Wall's debut trumps say Young Jeezy's for Slim Thug's, but it is definitely worth a listen. If you have been following the Houston Hip-hop scene throughout two thousand and five, you will love this album because it is more of the slow beats and slow craps. My favourites on this album are "The Don't Know" feat. Bun B, "Smooth Operator", "Sittin' Sideways" (which in't trumped by any of the other tracks in my opinion), "Internet Going Nutz", and of course "Drive Slow" which is Kanye West feat GLC and Paul Wall from the album LATE REGISTRATION. Overall, I was't as blown away by the release as some of the other wrap releases of this year have, but I think that this is an excellent album over. three one/two stars I think.

"Hypnotize," the second half of System of a Down's two thousand and five opus, is clearly a continuation of their first album, "Mezmerize" (which was released earlier in two thousand and five). In addition to not being very far removed musically from "Mezmerize," this album also follows about the same blueprint. The songs on "Hypnotize" are very corky and energetic. It combines jokes with serious, bold political messages, and heavy songs ("Stealing Society") with slower, ballad-esque numbers ("Lonely Day"). Plus, many of the songs have several tempo changes. ("Dreaming" combines "Chop Suey"-esque singing with tempo changes that bring "B. Y. O. B." to mind, and "U-Fig" and "Holy Mountains" are chaotic, off-the-wall itunes with whiplash speed changes and even acoustic guitar breakdowns.) And, finally, guitarist/songwriter Daron Malankian gets more time at the mic than the did on the band's first two albums. But most of this singing, there, is actually pretty good. (Track one, "Attack" begins with fast, ultra-crunchy riffs, before Daron begins to croon nasally, and the actually sounds as good as Serj.)There are a few throw away tracks on there. "She's Like Heroin" goes absolutely no where, and "Vicinity of Obscenity" is so silly, it could be a "Steal This Album" of-side. But there are several more good songs than so-so's, and there are a few mature moments (i.e. "Kill Rock `N Roll" and the title track), which sound more along the lines of a traditional System of a Down song. Upon my first listening to this album, I was not at all impressed. I thought System were trying to hard to be funny, but usually ended up coming across as goofy. Fortunately, however, I gave this disc repeated spins and it grew on me quite a lot. So I recommend you do the same; buy it, and give it time to sink under your skin (something it will most definitely do). It in't a great C. D., but it's still quite good, and worth buying if you're a fairly big SOAD fan; if you're a casual fan, however, you could probably just be satisfied with any one of System's five records.

hypnotize the second half of system of a downs two thousand and five opus is clearly a continuation of their first album mezmerize which was released earlier in two thousand and five in addition to not being very far removed musically from mezmerize this album also follows about the same blueprint the songs on hypnotize are very corky and energetic it combines jokes with serious bold political messages and heavy songs stealing society with slower ballad esque numbers lonely day plus many of the songs have several tempo changes dreaming combines chop suey esque singing with tempo changes that bring b y o b to mind and u fig and holy mountains are chaotic off the wall itunes with whiplash speed changes and even acoustic guitar breakdowns and finally guitarist songwriter daron malankian gets more time at the mic than the did on the bands first two albums but most of this singing there is actually pretty good track one attack begins with fast ultra crunchy riffs before daron begins to croon nasally and the actually sounds as good as serj there are a few throw away tracks on there shes like heroin goes absolutely no where and vicinity of obscenity is so silly it could be a steal this album of side but there are several more good songs than so sos and there are a few mature moments i e kill rock n roll and the title track which sound more along the lines of a traditional system of a down song upon my first listening to this album i was not at all impressed i thought system were trying to hard to be funny but usually ended up coming across as goofy fortunately however i gave this disc repeated spins and it grew on me quite a lot so i recommend you do the same buy it and give it time to sink under your skin something it will most definitely do it int a great c d but its still quite good and worth buying if youre a fairly big soad fan if youre a casual fan however you could probably just be satisfied with any one of systems five records

Rock in roll is a very pure part form, in the sense that in its ideal form it does't often take a lot of training to get to the point where an artist is table to express him/herself. This of course is a double-edged sword. For bands like The Ramones for Nirvana, for example, the untrained thing worked brilliantly. But for too many young bands, I am increasingly finding that a punk aesthetic is used to mask an inability to write songs for play instruments. Perhaps that's why I tend to be the anomalous early-thirty-something who spends quite a lot of listening time on music like that found on the "Morph The Cat" disc. Call this what you will - it tends to get labeled "adult contemporary" for some such - Donald Fagen's work is really a smartly sleek extension of Steely Dan's sophisticated jazz-pop. Meticulously sculpted with witty, clever lyrics that often tell a story, the music sounds modern and oddly retro at the same time. The musicianship is of course refreshingly excellent, and repeat listens reveal new aspects of these carefully layered compositions. It's something you can really sink your teeth into, so to speak, and will reward repeated listens. I can't wait to hear a new band that plays music like this. Until then, at least the old guard is still reliably cranking out collections that give music fans something worth their time.

This CD is a strong rock music CD with very powerful lyrics to every song on it. If you are never feeling down, hurt, left out and so forth then get this CD and listen to the lyrics because they will impact you as much as they did me as I listen to the CD. I do have my favourites off it they include Pain, Animal I have Become, Riot, and Get out Alive. But the whole album is amazing start to finish so if you have a passion for rock music like me then pick this up and sit back and enjoy hard rock music with passionate lyrics behind each song.

reviewText: I am not familiar with John Mayer's work prior to "Continuum", but this dude got it right with this particular disc. I was drawn in by this breakout song "Waiting on the world to change" impressed with its political conscience. But after listening to the whole disc a number of times, the other outstanding songs unfolded. The song "Slow dancing in a burning room" was the first song to jump out at me; any person that has been in a tumultuous relationship can definitely relate. The lyrics in that song are amazing. After I wore that song out, I noticed "Gravity" and its awesome lyrics. Next, was the old Hendrix song "Bold as Love" Mayer might not be on Hendrix's guitar playing level, but the does a masterful job on this one. The more uptempo "Belief" then caught my year. A song I believe is ultimate truth. Finally I felt the flavor of "Dreaming with a Broken Heart" A very haunting and compelling song and performance by Mayer. He will be performing with Eric Clapton tommorow Bryant PK NYC seven.zeroAM free. They say get there early, but if the is with Clapton you might have to camp out the day before. I don't know the classification of Mayer's music, but I do believe this record brings back "excellent" lyrical content to the mainstream.

One of the most creative bands around today. Some bands can write good lyrics, some bands can write catchy itunes. few can do both. The Decemberists are ahead of their time with every album they release. The Crane Wife is no different. The Island (the three songs in one song) is what happens if Pink Floyd decided to rerecord The Tain. I was't sure how they were going to bring me back after The Island because that song emotionally drained me, and then am, they hit you with Yankee Bayonet arguably the best song on the pablum. All of the songs contain beautifully crafted music couched in the imagination of the lyrics. One, if not the best albums of the year.
summary: Hard to believe they could top themselves.

reviewText: By any stretch of imagination, "Not Too Late" is an immediate masterpiece. Gone are the cover versions of songs that were't hers, and those dull lullabies that seven people took to cowrote. In its place are some gorgeous melodies with self-written lyrics that elevate this album from being a run of the mill affair to one of those rare animals - a bonafide classic. A note about the music - let the reviews not deter you. The music is very Norah-ish, in the best way possible, but there is something new there. What could be previously termed as "boring" is now "inspired". You won't fall asleep halfway through this album if you pay attention to the lyrics. It is so great to find an album these days that does not only speak about Love. And even though there are political messages on some of these songs, its muted enough to pass you by without offending you. Also, while I consider "Come Away with Me" and "Feels Like Home" contemporary American jazz albums (debatable by most, I agree), I think "Not Too Late" is her hands down "Southern" album, even though it speaks of the very things the South hates to hear about. Its amazing that an album like this would find an audience if Norah was't who she is, but that's the beauty of it all, I think. The standout there is "Wish I could", the opening track. Wow. The harmonies blend perfectly. The wonderful thing about this record is that Norah's voice is allowed to shine without the distraction of too much instrumentation (like on her second album). And while "Thinkin' About You" is hummable enough, its easily the most insipid track there - speaking of love in the most infantile sense possible. I think that she can afford to move beyond songs like these, pretty as they are. Will "Not Too Late" win any awards despite being at least twice as better than her "Come Away with Me" album? Probably not. The reason being that Norah is not perceived as "new" for "fresh" anymore. However, if you listen to this CD, it's the freshest thing out of the Jones stable so far. My favourite little piece other than the opener is "The Sun Doesn't Like You" - listen and discover! What makes me really happy about this album is the Repeat Value it carries - I have already played it about six times at work through and through and it just gets better on repeat listening. Do yourself a favor and pick this up, just to discover where American music is headed in general. This is a wonderful time for American music, and it's a testament to her growth and evolution that Norah Jones is the flagbearer for a new music generation. Yes, true talents like Joanna Newsom, Regina Spektor and Fiona Apple still don't get the adulation that they deserve, but if artists like Jones can win acclaim, it proves that there justice after all. Five Stars. Recommended without any reservations!
summary: An Immediate Masterpiece : The Evolution of Miss Shankar

reviewText: How odd and appropriate and utterly wonderful that the Brits should so decisively breathe life back into the R&B genre. Soul music has been stone cold dead in the United States for quite some time, but these retro-leaning new albums by Amy Winehouse and (to a lesser extent) Duffy bring American music back to life in much the same way that the Beatles and the Stones revived rock in the early 'sixtys. Guess all those English "Northern Soul" parties paid off, after all! Winehouse is a brilliant song stylist and performer. More power to her. (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue music reviews)
summary: The British are coming, the British are coming...!

reviewText: I am another who first heard "A Fine Frenzy" on Pandora and then bought this there. I will come back and update this review as I have more time with the CD, but already I am quite taken with it. Not since Sarah and "Red Delicious" have I been so impressed by such confident vocals at first listen. Alison is an incredibly talented singer with an intriguing style and sense for inflection that is quite wonderful. I'm late to the party, but definitely having a good time!two thousand and eleven-eleven-twenty-four: Have not had time to come back and do a full review, but take my word for it, this is a great CD. I have been grabbing everything I can find by "A Fine Frenzy" (Alison Sudol) there and elsewhere. Lots of great songs on this CD. "Almost Lover," "You Picked Me," "Think of You," "Near to You," and the very beautiful "Last of Days" are among the more popular, but there really in't a bad song there. A great talent and lots of goodness there. See also her other CDBomb in a Birdcagewhich is also great.
summary: Beautiful, incredible, talent, voice, songs, wow!
