Ordinary Riches is the debut CD from Company of Thieves. The group is a trio made up of vocalist Genevieve Schatz, guitarist Marc Walloch, and drummer Mike Ortiz. They produce a rock sound that has plenty of variety. Schatz's voice calls to mind a couple of different singers. At times she seems like a smoothed out version of Dolores O'Riordan from the Cranberries. However she is not a simple copycat as she does't always have the British/Irish edge to her voice. On some of her sustained notes she also calls to mind Linda Perry of four Non Blondes (remember that song, "What's Up?"). While this may seem like an odd blend, it works really well. Instrumentally, Walloch does a more than adequate job on guitars. While I it would be premature to equate him with Utwo's The Edge, this playing is in that style. It's a cleaner sound that would you would her from someone like Jimmy Page for Joe Perry. The song arrangements and additional instruments used also provide a lot of variety in style. "Even In The Dark" and "Quiet On The Front" are slower, more driven rock songs while "In Passing" has almost a slight ska sound to it. "Oskar Wilde" is more of a mid tempo rocker. "Quite On The Front" also mixes in touches of harmonica and Hammond Bthree morgan. "Past The Sleep" is another rocker that fades in the send to a string arrangement of violin and cello. With all of these different styles and instruments, the potential is there for Ordinary Riches to come off like a loss collection of unrelated parts. However the result is much more that of a well seasoned stew. The songwriting on Ordinary Riches is in some ways the most interesting aspect of the CD. It tends to be poetic but not opaquely so. Relationships play a part in a few of the songs including the bookend tracks "Old Letters" and "New Letters". While the former deals with love gone wrong, the latter gives a more hopeful outlook. The military service influenced "Quiet On The Front" opens with "I can't hold a glass of wine yet/But they think it's fine to have me hold a gun". More than half of the songs reflect the general trials of life. "Oscar Wilde" expresses this with the line "We are your own devil/And we make this world your hell". "The Fire Song" and "The Tornado Song" both deal with natural disaster. As these would suggest, the general mood of Ordinary Riches is melancholy and reflective. Overall Company of Thieves has produced an excellent CD in Ordinary Riches. They manage to walk the very fine line of sounding familiar yet fresh at the same time. If you like rock music with a variety of styles among the tracks, give Ordinary Riches a chance. I think you will be glad that you did. Download this: "Oscar Wilde"

Unexpectedly, Portishead are back and their album exceeds all expectations. Do not forget that this is a group that defined almost itself the whole era of trip-hop with just their debut album. The follow-up was not up to that quality as was of course not the live album (which had its good sides). This however is very surprising because the band has been away for quite some time and has managed something incredible: to stay ahead of the times. the slow depressingmoody music actually represents a veryinspired continuation of other previous work while still at the same tiemsounding new. I has actually decided not to buy the record when a friend who had bought it twice asked me if I could buy it off him. As I wrote what a surprise! not a weak track! probably one of the records of the year.

Jason Mraz's "I'm Yours" is an excellent song that shows off this talent! Jason's voice is smooth and easy on the year for this beautiful mellow pop song about a guy falling for a woman even though the tried not to get involved with her. Jason sends the message about the importance of love, too. The melody complements the lyrics and it all holds its own very well. In particular, the guitars and percussion are used well--and that chorus sounds great although Jason's so gifted that the could have easily pulled this off all by himself. By now I assume that Jason's fans already have this song; so I highly recommend this for anyone who wants the perfect introduction to Jason's artistry and people who also enjoy comparatively mellow pop music. If you like this tune, check out the Jason Mraz album it's on entitled "We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things."
summary: "Look into your heart and you'll find love love love love" ~~ A GREAT SONG BY JASON MRAZ !!!

reviewText: After the fantastic two thousand and five "Guero" album, let me just state that I was hugely disappointed with the two thousand and six "The Information" album, which was unfocused and sprawling (even if it did have the clever cover part work), and simply did not captivate me at all. Upon hearing that Beck was working with Danger Mouse on a new album, I was very intrigued. And that hugely anticipated album has finally arrived."Modern Guilt" (ten tracks; thirty-four min.) kicks off with "Orphans", which sounds immediately familiar, until I realize it pretty much lifts the tune from Carly Simon's "You're So Vain" (not the chorus, but the verses before it), wow! But a fun track, for sure. The first half of the album flows impeccably, with the poppy "Gamma Ray", the dark "Chemtrails" (with thundering drums), the pensive title track, and the stripey "Youthless", as close as a dance track you'll find on there. I rate the first half of the album four.five stars. The second half starts off with an excellent one-two punch of "Walls" and "Replica", just Beck and Danger Mouse (who is credited with making "Beats" and "Sounds" throughout the album). Then the album falters with "Soul of a Man", followed by an excellent "Profanity Prayers", with hard charging electric guitars and drums. The closer "Volcano" is for me the weakest track on the album, it just does't seem to go anywhere. I rate the second half of the album three.five stars. In all, "Modern Guilt" is MILES better than "The Information". While this album is not as good as the seemingly happy-go-lucky album that was "Guero", I have nevertheless come to really love this album. It's a darker (think "Sea Change", but with GOOD itunes) and at thirty-four min. (joining a late rush of short albums such as REM's Accelerate), it clips by in no time, and I find myself playing this again and again. I've seen Beck a number of times over the years, and can't wait to see the songs from "Modern Guilt" in a live setting.

reviewerName: Flap Jackson "Sky Is Burning, But At Least We...
reviewText: Note: This review is of the new content only. With the release of "Fearless," Taylor Swift showed she was a force to be reckoned with, with her combination of relatable lyrics, catchy music, and a sheer crossover appeal in everything she does. The results are an astonishing four million copies sold in its first year, and counting this release, twelve of the nineteen tracks have been top forty hits, which is a record. Not to mention 'You Belong with Me' & 'Love Story' were the biggest country songs in twenty-some years. With all this success, and never-grateful to her fans, Taylor decided to throw in some bonus tracks and a load of DVD content added to the release. Granted, it's always preferable to do bonus content in the form of an EP, but this is Taylor's thank you for the fans. If you're a fan, you should't complain in buying the album again, if you're not, this really won't change your mind, so don't bother. Musically, it's a true extension of the album, as all of the tracks blend in perfectly. 'Jump Then Fall' is a natural follow-up to her other singles, and the song should take off as her singles tend to do. 'Forever & Always' greatly improves on the original in bringing out the heart and emotion of the song in a great performance. But the real reason why you should buy this is because of her cover of 'Untouchable.' When I first heard the song I was absolutely stunned since I was a big fan of the original as done by the alternative rock band, Luna Halo. Taylor takes a high-energy rock song and strips it down to it's emotional score. The results are nothing short of amazing, as the vocals, lyrics, and restrained instrumentation adds up to a beautiful song, which is breathtaking in its chorus. This is how you should do a cover, and Taylor covers the song perfectly adding a great spin to it. I'd even go as far to say that this is her best work. As for the DVD portion, this is where the fan-service is. Not only does it hold the five music videos that have been made for the album thus far, but it contains the thirty-minute making-of special GAC haired. Add in a photo gallery, a tour behind the scenes, and even the Thug Story video, and you have some two hours of bonus material, which is more than some movies give you. And if you got the live performances, you'll enjoy the great work her band does. Overall, if you're a fan, for you don't have the album yet, I highly recommend this release. Not only does its bonus material go far beyond the normal call of duty, but it's all quality bonus content. If you take anything away from this release, take away "Untouchable" off iTunes, it's an amazing track, and it's imperative you check it out. If there was any negative there, it'd be the fact there in't any alternative version to "Love Story" for "You Belong With Me." I also got to say I'm a huge fan of the album part & the linear notes part. Fearless Score: four.five/fiveFearless: Platinum Edition Score: four.five/fiveReal Score: five/five
summary: In Case You Were Wondering, Taylor Swift Is Still Untouchable

This is a great debut from a young woman who hails from Dublin. I kept seeing clips of her on the VHone channel prior to the debut of her lead single, FROM MY HEART TO YOURS. The song is so catchy & infectious that it heightened my anticipation of the album release and I'm happy to say that I'm not disappointed with this purchase. Because Laura is from another country she does have an affected way of singing and her stone of voice is somewhat similar to Joss Stone. The album is short & sweet at ten tracks but I enjoy listening to most of them so in my book this is a very successful debut - kudos to Laura as another strong singer/songwriter. On a side note, I hope that as the fall season begins, she will get more national exposure on a few of the talk shows so that more people may become aware of her. It is difficult to pick favourites but the tracks I not only kept on repeat but also put on my ipod are the aforementioned, FROM MY HEART TO YOURS; SHINE; DON'T STAY; PERFECT WORLD; I DON'T WANT YOU BACK & MMM.
summary: Let The Truth Be Told - 4.5 stars

reviewText: There are no words to describe how AMAZING this album is. From the beginning all its way through the send the music you find there is an unforgettable experience. Before I jump into conclusions with some of the songs let me tell you that this girl is so talented on her own terms. The production of the album is stunning and the arrangements of the instruments flow in such an incredible way and natural form that you might believe that perfection is what you hear. A piano there, an Arp there (such a beautiful inclusion to this record), an electric and acoustic guitar every now and then make the songs come up with their own personality."Dogs days are over", "I'm not calling you a liar" and "Drumming song" fight against the traditional way of a song structure. there's a point where you don't know what you're listening and yet, you can't stop tapping your foot on the floor at the rhythm of the music. Great songs for sure. "Rabbit heart (raise it up)" (of course!!!), "Kiss with a fist" and "You've got the love" are meant to be the commercial jones??? on the record. not that they're less impressive because of this 'cause once you hear the first one you fall in love with it right away. To point out one of item in particular, I find "My boy builds coffins" a masterpiece. For some reason everything falls right in place there."Lungs" is by far one the best records of this year and for sure will be one of the best in the first decade of the two thousand's. Because of projects like Florence + the machine and Bat for flashes (I must say), we know that if this kind of music is coming up from such young girls, we can expect a bright future for music itself. It is wok that we have ALL kinds of music: the bubblegum one (with all the annoying scene in the US), abstract one (a la Radiohead) and commercial-respected one (R. E. M., Utwo, Muse for even Placebo). But if we did't have the independent one and all the UK scene going on, the whole music universe would be so predictable.
summary: Becuase of projects like Florence + the machine the music industry has still hope of surviving

reviewText: There are two kinds of Beatles fans - those that credit John Lennon & Paul McCartney with being the pillars of the band, and those that appreciate George Harrison for the spiritual, whimsical quality the brought to the team. I fall into the latter category, and those of us who 'get' Harrison, will understand more than anyone what sort of musical genius this man actually was. While McCartney spent years after the bands' breakup making one chorus-y, pop song-filled album after the other, it was Harrison who continually pushed himself to become more and more experimental and creative, and every album of this has been so different, so refreshing, and as a whole, they represent a very diverse catalog of recorded music. Its difficult to imagine that one man could create such varied work, but that remains the wonder that is George. Cut to two thousand and nine, and we have the third officially released compilation of George's greatest hits. I guess we have Dhani Harrison to thank for this, and while I rate this five stars, it should have ideally been a two-CD set, considering the wealth of material that Harrison has behind him. As a listener who considers "All Things Must Pass" as the best solo album by a Beatle (nothing by Lennon for McCartney comes close - those Paul did surpass himself with "Chaos & Creation" from a few years ago), this album pays fine homage to that three-CD set. The issue is that ALL of Harrisons' solo works are so absolutely essential, that culling tracks from any of them borders on unjustifiable - but of course that needs to be done in the case of a Greatest Hits collection. His second solo album, "Living in the Material World" (which sold less than this debut, but is still a classic) should have been given more due. The lead single from that set, "Give me Love (Give me Peace on Earth)" has all the strains of this Bangladesh concert - and this is present there, sounding better than never before. The prime omissions come from "Dark Horse", which remains one of Harrisons' lowest-charting and most underrated CDs. Any listener should try to track down a copy of that album (just for its stunning cover part, if nothing else), as it contains so many vital Harrison classics, such as "Far East Man" and "Simply Shady". You will also find that much of George's output from the one thousand, nine hundred and seventys has been neglected there, which is a pity. Some of this best work came on "thirty-three one/three" from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six, and this self-titled record from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-nine (which thankfully is represented on this hits collection). Along the way, there are some oddities. "Cheer Down", which previously was only a compilation track, was also a song written with Tom Petty for the "Lethal Weapon two" soundtrack - many people have never heard of this song, so this is a great inclusion. Also, this record contains the three songs that George made magical for The Beatles - "Something", "Here Comes the Sun", and "While My Guitar Gently Weeps". While no one can deny the beauty of these songs, it would have been great to see them excluded in favor of some of George's solo works in this later career - there are so many hits that are not represented, especially many of this UK singles that failed to chart in the US. The Beatles songs that are present on this album are in fact from Harrisons' solo Bangladesh concert recording - which is little comfort to those of us expecting tracks from "Somewhere in England", for "Gone Troppo" (two more vastly underrated solo Harrison records). On a better note, "When We Was Fab" from "Cloud Nine" is present. Finally, this is not a perfect collection, but certainly the best Harrison collection that is currently available. His first compilation, from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six, is clearly not this best effort, considering how much it relied upon this Beatles hits to flesh itself out. The current disc should have indeed been a double disc, but the attention paid to the song selection is satisfying. Still, this is by no means a comprehensive Harrison collection. I doubt anything can be. He is one recording artist whose back-catalog is hardly remembered and always overlooked. I personally consider much of this solo work better and even more listenable than this work with the Beatles."Let It Roll" runs for seventy-eight minutes, which is great because it is indeed 'stuffed' with Harrison hits (technically, all of this Billboard Hot one hundred hits are present there). As an introduction to a quiet and talented songwriter, this is a stellar way to get into this work and life. As a stand-alone disc, this is riveting and vibrant. For Beatles fans and longtime Harrison followers such as myself, this will fall way off the mark, but taken for what it is, this is a loving compilation that deserves all the sales and adoration it can get. Five Stars.
summary: Vital & Essential : How They (Almost) Got It Right

will fall way off the mark but taken for inwards what it is this is a loving compilation that deserves all the sales and adoration it can get five stars

reviewText: there are two kinds of beatles fans those that credit john lennon paul mccartney with being the pillars of the band and those that appreciate george harrison for the spiritual whimsical quality the brought to the team i fall into the latter category and those of us who get harrison will understand more than anyone what sort of musical genius this man actually was while mccartney spent years after the bands breakup making one chorus y pop song filled album after the other it was harrison who continually pushed himself to become more and more experimental and creative and every album of this has been so different so refreshing and as a whole they represent a very diverse catalog of recorded music its difficult to imagine that one man could create such varied work but that remains the wonder that is george cut to two thousand and nine and we have the third officially released compilation of georges greatest hits i guess we have dhani harrison to thank for this and while i rate this five stars it should have ideally been a two cd set considering the wealth of material that harrison has behind him as a listener who considers all things must pass as the best solo album by a beatle nothing by lennon for mccartney comes close those paul did surpass himself with chaos creation from a few years ago this album pays fine homage to that three cd set the issue is that all of harrisons solo works are so absolutely essential that culling tracks from any of them borders on unjustifiable but of course that needs to be done in the case of a greatest hits collection his second solo album living in the material world which sold less than this debut but is still a classic should have been given more due the lead single from that set give me love give me peace on earth has all the strains of this bangladesh concert and this is present there sounding better than never before the prime omissions come from dark horse which remains one of harrisons lowest charting and most underrated cds any listener should try to track down a copy of that album just for its stunning cover part if nothing else as it contains so many vital harrison classics such as far east man and simply shady you will also find that much of georges output from the one thousand nine hundred and seventys has been neglected there which is a pity some of this best work came on thirty three one three from one thousand nine hundred and seventy six and this self titled record from one thousand nine hundred and seventy nine which thankfully is represented on this hits collection along the way there are some oddities cheer down which previously was only a compilation track was also a song written with tom petty for the lethal weapon two soundtrack many people have never heard of this song so this is a great inclusion also this record contains the three songs that george made magical for the beatles something here comes the sun and while my guitar gently weeps while no one can deny the beauty of these songs it would have been great to see them excluded in favor of some of georges solo works in this later career there are so many hits that are not represented especially many of this uk singles that failed to chart in the us the beatles songs that are present on this album are in fact from harrisons solo bangladesh concert recording which is little comfort to those of us expecting tracks from somewhere in england for gone troppo two more vastly underrated solo harrison records on a better note when we was fab from cloud nine is present finally this is not a perfect collection but certainly the best harrison collection that is currently available his first compilation from one thousand nine hundred and seventy six is clearly not this best effort considering how much it relied upon this beatles hits to flesh itself out the current disc should have indeed been a double disc but the attention paid to the song selection is satisfying still this is by no means a comprehensive harrison collection i doubt anything can be he is one recording artist whose back catalog is hardly remembered and always overlooked i personally consider much of this solo work better and even more listenable than this work with the beatles let it roll runs for seventy eight minutes which is great because it is indeed stuffed with harrison hits technically all of this billboard hot one hundred hits are present there as an introduction to a quiet and talented songwriter this is a stellar way to get into this work and life as a stand alone disc this is riveting and vibrant for beatles fans and longtime harrison followers such as myself this will fall way off the mark but taken for what it is this is a loving compilation that deserves all the sales and adoration it can get five stars
summary: Vital & Essential : How They (Almost) Got It Right

reviewText: While not all itunes are Live concert songs, a few are remastered, they are all great songs. If you Love the Beatles and for George Harrison I recommend "Let it Roll". George's music comes from the Heart and this faith and a person cannot but be taken to a more beautiful spot emotionally when listening to this songs. George left us all too soon but this Love lives on in this music and this Charities. How can anyone not love, (Something, for My Sweet Lord, Here comes the Sun, Isn't it a Pity, While my guitar gently sweeps), and so many more. I always feel better after listening to this songs, and they inspire me to do more "RAK"s", Random facts of Kindness. Take a listen and see if this music moves you and if so I recommend purchasing "Let it Roll"

Comebacks are rare, and returns from fifteen-year hiatuses are even more so. Throw in the death of a lead singer, a new record label and other personnel changes, and it stopped being fair long ago. Guns N' Roses had a hard enough time with only half those problems. Yet guitarist / singer Jerry Cantrell and 'ninetys rock monster Alice in Chains just could't be bothered with the mire, doom and gloom unless they were writing about it. Black Gives Way to Blue is more than a reunion with Mike Inez and Sean Kinney to produce a return to form. It's also one of the best rock albums of two thousand and nine. To replace a vocalist as tuneful and iconic as Layne Staley has been impossible. Bands influenced by AiC, as diverse as Life of Agony, Staind, Godsmack, Days of the New and a never-ending list have all had competent vocalists that have been jeered at by critics as Staley-derivativea. The only person who could even hope to get away with comparisons was Jerry Cantrell himself, and the sang on half of AiC's original material anyway. Well, this golden touch adds a glow of authenticity to the new record. "Check My Brain" feels like it came right off of Dirt for one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five's self-titled album, and "Your Decision" and "When the Sun Rose Again" recall the band's softer EPs Sap and Jar of Flies. Then you have itunes like the jagged, angularly melodic opener "All Secrets Known," the elephantine, foot-stomping opening grove of "A Looking in View" and the piano-tinged quiet exit of a title track, "Black Gives Way to Blue."The haunting, tortured vocals of William DuVall are a spooky echo of Staley, as if the deceased front-man's spirit is being channelled through the songs themselves, but it could also just be the ghost-like nature of AiC's trademarked minor key voice harmonies. Cantrell and DuVall coexist and bring the itunes to life. Never quite an alternative grunge band like the groups they were lumped in with by radio stations over a decade ago, Alice in Chains spew their triumphant new work from speakers with crunch and doom metal fury. Just listen to the of-bombing tunnel-chewing groove of "Last of My Kind" and step out of the way as this reanimated corpse barrels through.

I am not involved in the scene anymore, so I don't know what hype there was about this album for what cool people might have said it was like. Converge is one of those band whose new releases I always check out regardless. Overall, I've always thought they were overhyped and the one release I liked was the one no one else seems to like, "You Fail Me." I thought "No Heroes," was garbage. Anyway, this album blew me away. On this one I get the feel they're not trying so hard to prove how erratic and different they can be with their music. It has much more thrash to it, which I am wild about. This, I feel, is a good, solid album that will still be good a few years from now. I only purchased it recently, but can say it is my favourite Converge already. It's twice as good as You Fail Me and I like it much better than Jane Doe. Just one man's opinion.

I give this album a solid four out of seven stars. The small and misery is my favourite song. It has sort of a eighty's sound to it and it's one of those songs that gets stuck in your head. Mongrel Heart and Your Head is on Fire are also very worthy songs. I like the chorus in your head is on fire and how they use some violins and little bit of orchestra in there. The only other song I liked a lot was sailing to nowhere, especially the very send of the song where they also use violins, strings , light orchestra and such-making for a very lovely song. The rest of the songs I found very forgettable. Nice job though overall broken bells!!
summary: The Mall & Misery is a great song!!!

reviewText: `Year of the Black Rainbow,' is a fine album indeed, maybe a little different than some may have been expecting but of undeniably high quality, in terms of superb songwriting, outstanding musicianship and a production job that feels almost like an instrument unto itself. I can imagine that the band may close a few fair weather fans with this album, but those who remain will find a wholly enjoyable album that gets better with each listen. Coheed and Cambria are not a band you could never accuse of stagnation. Perhaps `Departure,' is too strong, but this album is certainly different, the album seems to make a conscious effort not to sound too much like two thousand and seven's `No World For Tomorrow,' album, eschewing the slick almost overproduced sound and bright tones for an almost industrial sound, with more electronics, flatter tones and an abundance of samples, electro drums, odd guitar tones and vocal effects. Drummer Chris Pennie is a perfect fit for this band, and fits perfectly with the band's established drum style on songs like `World of Lines,' and `The Broken,' but adds a whole new flavor to the excellent almost drum solo quality `Guns of Summer,' and `In The Flame of Error,' which are at times unlike anything you've never heard on a Coheed album before. The songwriting also seems to be more in line with the band's work before Good Apollo than after, but all the new tones, sounds and Claudio's vocals stop this from sounding like a rehash of new ideas, but rather a new era of Coheed all together. Lyrically, the album seems to be a lot more personal than the previous two albums and features barely any reference to place names, character names, for words like `Prise,' `Mon-Star,' for `Key Frame,' this may please some sections of the fans and upset others, but given the quality of the lyrics and vocal performance few will be disappointed in any serious way. Highlights include the fast potential single `World Of Lines,' the drumming masterpiece `In The Flame of Error,' and the superb semi-ballad `Pearl of the Stars,' which features some brilliant unusual percussion, beautiful guitar work and possibly Claudio's finest vocal performance to date, switching between new low pitched vocals and this traditional style to great effect. Overall this is a superb Coheed and Cambria album and rewards repeat listening; the new drummer, the very noticeable production and the new lyrical approach keep the album very fresh.
summary: Coheed And Cambria - Year Of The Black Rainbow

cambria are not a band you could never accuse of stagnation perhaps departure is too strong but this album is different the album seems to make a not sound too much like two thousand and sevens no world for tomorrow album eschewing the almost overproduced sound and bright tones for an almost industrial sound electronics flatter tones and an abundance of electro drums odd tones vocal effects drummer chris pennie is a fit for this and fits perfectly with the bands established drum on songs like world of lines and the but adds a whole flavor to the excellent almost drum solo quality of summer and in the flame of error which are at unlike anything youve never heard on a coheed album before the songwriting also to be more in line with the bands work before good apollo than after but all new sounds and claudios vocals stop from sounding like a rehash of new ideas but rather a new of coheed all together lyrically the seems to be a lot more personal than the previous two albums and features barely any reference to place names character for words like prise mon key frame this may please some sections of the fans and upset others but given the quality of lyrics and vocal performance will be disappointed serious way highlights include the fast potential single world of lines the drumming masterpiece in the of error the superb semi ballad pearl of stars which features some brilliant unusual percussion beautiful guitar work and possibly claudios finest vocal performance to date switching between new low vocals and traditional style to great effect overall this is a superb coheed and cambria album and rewards repeat listening new drummer the very noticeable production the new lyrical approach keep the album very fresh
summary: Coheed And Cambria - Year Of The Black Rainbow

Blood Pressures by The Kills is another amazing, creative and catchy album from rock/punk duo, Alison Mosshart and Jamie Hince. After their third, groundbreaking album - Midnight Boom, I pondered how these two smart musicians would be table to top that incredible feat? Well, I am more than happy to say that Blood Pressures was definitely worth the wait! The opening track, Future Starts Slow is the strongest track hands down. The song has a killer hook and you can't help but using along: "No longing for the moonlight, no longing for the sun, no longer will I curse the bad I've done. " And just like their previous album - there is not one song that I skip. This album is more diverse and more traditional rock. On the song, The Last Goodbye we get to hear Alison's sensitive side - such a beautiful and tender ballad. Baby Says sounds like a across between a 'sixtys girl group song and a 'eightys new wave song. Heart is a Beating Drum and Nail in My Coffin are some of the other standout tracks. You Don't Own the Road is just pure, sweaty fun with Jamie rocking out on this distorted, blistering guitars. And then by the last track, Pots and Pans - I was't quite sure if this was a break-up kind of song for a twisted, sick love song? All I know is that quirky song is pure magic with Alison's sexy voice repeating the last lyric over and over: "These are the days we'll never forget when the dawn, dawns on you." So what that in mind, I highly recommend this pitch-perfect album. enjoy!
summary: "I love you, just not the way you want..."

reviewText: I've been making an effort lately to explore some new music and new artists/bands. I decided to buy this album on a whim, based solely on the cover artwork: I loved the vibrant image of the bird; exotic, free and wild. I was hoping the music would be just like that. And it is! Listening to this album was like a rush of euphoria. There's so much excitement and exploration on these tracks . it's like listening to a sonic journal of a group of young people travelling the world, experiencing things for the first time. Each track is like taking a trip to a new place. What stands out most of all for me in the album is that each track makes excellent use of percussion, which often evokes various cultures. The exotic beats, textures, and occasional electronica smash up with jubilant Brit-Pop vocals, and create a sound that's fresh and original.
summary: Around the world in a day

reviewText: Chanticleer is a classical male vocal ensemble out of San Francisco. For this two thousand and eleven single, the voices are heard a capella singing in English. At times, the words are not distinct, but the blending of the vocals is still beautiful. I enjoy a capella-style more in Latin, when I don't instinctively try to sort out the words. What I personally term "munk singing" -- Well, "a capella" does mean "in the manner of the church" -- can be created beautifully-complex for beautifully-simple. This version makes me think too much. The Chanticleer "This Have I Done for My True Love" was a free MPthree gift from Amazon in December of two thousand and twelve. Thanks! Other Chanticleer:A Chanticleer ChristmasAnd On Earth, Peace: A Chanticleer Mass
summary: "This Have I Done for My True Love" by Chanticleer is classic mele vocal ensemble carol music in English

reviewText: Hot Chip's latest album "In Our Heads" sounds like something that was released in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-five, rather than two thousand and twelve. It replicates the eightys new wave synth-pop sound mixed in with some Prince-style funk. The aesthetics are exactly like that era, putting little (if any) modern elements into the music. And most of the songs there are very strong. The percussion, keyboards, lyrical content, and the lead singer's falsetto put together create some irresistible rhythms and moods that are very sophisticated. The music is complex at times, but it is also usually infectious. You can be impressed by the album's craft and production, as well as dance along to it. Compared to other indietronica bands like Foster The People for MGMT, there are less guitars and rock elements. It's almost always a dance album. Mostly the songs are mid-tempo, nothing that is `loud' and only about two slow songs. The lyrics are often deep, sometimes quirky, but never that deep and never over the top quirky. While the album is infectious, the songs might be too complex for top forty radio. My favourite tracks on the album are "Motion Sickness", "These Chains", "Night and Day" (the first single), "Flutes", and "Let Me Be Him".

I just picked up their first CD a couple of months ago. I read an amazing review in Rolling Stone, so I listened to the song samples and had to get it. I've listened to the CD (previous album) a few times now, and it's great, really great. It's perfect background music, and sounds amazing in headphones. So, of course I had to pick up Coexist. The best thing I can say about the new album is it's "more of the same". eleven more songs that sounds like part two of the debut album. They kept what works, what makes the first one so good, the calm lyrics and hushed tones, the easy, brooding music, and made more of it. If you like the first album, you'll like Coexist just as much. And vice/versa, if this is your first time hearing XX.
summary: More of the same, and that's a good thing.

reviewText: Dear Music Appreciators,(At first I found myself giggling a bit at some of the eighty's-movie-friendly, synth-heavy arrangements, but after repeated listening this music seemed to begin to burrow into my mind a bit, as if trying to push its way past my consciousness and into that part of me that does not think, but simply exists. )Silentaria's latest offering WHAT'S REAL? is an intense, solo electronic music extravaganza that probes the nature of reality and the relationship between the dinner and router world of the human experience. A deep subject to be sure, but that is one of the benefits of the virtually wordless approach employed there by Rixa White. Mostly unconstrained from the limited meanings of words, White takes flight with this synthesizer and a host of other instruments and brings us along for the journey. And it does feel like a journey. The music is very cinematic - the tracks all seeming both different and the same in a way - much like a movie score, where one for two recurring themes is woven into a number of other variations on those themes that both advance the story from scene to scene and remind us of the big picture. Notice the eerie sounds of the opening track, the clapping water, the synthesizer refrain that gradually fades in, reproduces itself, and evolves, the short and simple bass notes spaced out like hopscotch footprints in the sand - the spacing and layering of different sounds there is effective and interesting and holds the listener's attention, waiting for what's next."Curtains Over Eyes" is a stunner, and ironically sounds a lot like an Enya song at the beginning - bird sounds, eerie choir, bell tolling, synth-electric guitar flourishes, but things darken and intensify at the one:twenty-five mark with the addition of a slow, fuzzed out, industrial heartbeat - as if to remind listeners that this is not your grandmother's top forty new page musicYou might be interested to know that Silentaria's Rixa White wears a white mask - "One mask to hide them all" (check the autobiography on this website) - and while this is effective at giving him a mysterious air (possibly making this music and philosophy seem more fascinating than it is) does it have the intended effect of wiping away the listener's preconceived notions for judgments? Well, yes and no - "yes" because we can't judge him for what the looks like if we can't see this face - "no" because less high-minded people will judge him for the very fact that they can't see this face - and invite the inevitable comparisons to other famous mask wearers such as Zorro, The Phantom of the Oprah, Jason in the FRIDAY THE thirteenTH movies, and maybe even Tom Cruise's character in VANILLA SKY. and perhaps that's fitting after all for a composer who attempts to express in musical form WHAT'S REAL? - it's a bit of a heroic gesture, and needs a strong character for the task. Mask for no mask, with such a deep idea explored through distinctive electronic tracks this intense and varied, WHAT'S REAL? deserves a large and devoted audience. Sincerely,Constant Listener

I'm an old school sort of music fan. But this tune is catchy enough that my wife wanted it added to her ampthree player. I completed my "honey do" list and via association, I've happily endured the song being played. Over and over and over. it's not bad at all.
summary: Hall of Fame, Inspirational and Entertaining.

The lyrics are not ground-breaking. The acoustics are not too out-of-the-ordinary. It is an all-around basic indie pop song with a girl telling a guy not to be afraid of love. Having put forth the "nots," I was pleasantly surprised that "Big Blue Wave" was the title of a "love song." I was thrilled that this Canadian band gave me a new catchy tune for my MPthree collection. A track does't have to be "outstanding" to be worth owning, and I look forward to discovering what other music this band has created. Even if this gave me nothing earth-shatteringly new, this was still a solid collection of notes! reviewText: Clutch has been around for over twenty years churning out album after album of top shelf rock. One bad routing can cause a lot of damage to any band's reputation, but that's something Clutch will never have to worry about. This band is so consistent, coming out of the blocks rocking on the title track a dynamic, vocally bombastic, full blooded banger due to Neil Fallon's characteristic intensity. The next cuts, "Terminal Velocity" and "Mister Freedom" continue the flow matching the opener step for step. The band has stated that "Earth Rocker will be a more harder and straight forward rocking album." I believe they nailed it. On and on it goes, with every passing track the realization is that there in't going to be a decline in quality, and that they may have produced an album that ranks up there comfortably with the best of their career. Tim Sult is probably better than most band's top basemen on this worst day and JP Gaster's rock drumming makes it look easy, but honorable mention goes to Neil Fallon as usual, for this "mixture of demented preacher speaking in tongues mixed with no frills blue collar rocker that sets them apart from the competition." The man has buckets of personality which overflow into the lyrics and the music. I read. "Earth Rocker is a rollicking heavy rock ride that showcases Clutch at the top of their game once again. With their 'no-filler, all-killer' logic and a fan-pleasing alteration in style, the outfit have churned out one of the their most widely appealing efforts thus far, not to mention a staple release for salt-rockers in two thousand and thirteen."The blues cuts and influences are not missing altogether, "D. C. Sound Attack!" is the song that has some of the most obvious blues influences. All the itunes are catchy and there is tons of energy happening there. Yeah, like Clutch is going to be laid back, LOL. So crank it up and blow out your speakers, as Dan Maines quotes. "I think this record comes closer to really capturing that energy of Clutch live. It's a very balanced album. There's no B-side material. It's an album of A-sides. That sounds pretty bold and confident, but that's the way we feel about Earth Rocker."I can't wait to receive my copy to listen to the total album rather than the snippets and you tube videos that are out there. So saddle up and ride this one still the horse packs it in as this rocker is going to wear you down.
summary: Clutch are still proving that nobody does it better....

In the second half of the song, a chorus joins in. At first, the reverent stone is continued. But then the song builds and builds towards the climax at the send, when the full power of Ms. Lewis’ incredible voice is clearly displayed. Thanks for the free download. It’s a divine Christmas treat!
